Watching the wheels come off of S.W.A.T. is quite a sight.
A clinic for how this genre should be done.
Surprisingly enough (in fact, I am shocked), this film gets a lot of laughs.
Shrek 2 is the rare sequel that can compete with the original.
The movie is clearly written and produced around the persona of Will Smith, which is either glorious news or cringe-inducing, depending upon who you are.
Hanks is excellent and I applaud Spielberg for delving into some new territory.
This is intense, provocative filmmaking on every level that is sure to be one of the best American films of the year.
Wayne Wang directs the film as if he gets an extra commission for each Latifah reaction shot.
If this is where Indie comedy is headed, I guess I should find some other shenanigans to get into. Right, homeskillet?
MacFarlane knows his audience and A Million Ways to Die in the West is one of the funniest films of the year - provided you're a member of his audience.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I, Frankenstein leaves itself open to be franchised, but the chances of that happening are equal to Eckhart putting this film at the top of his resume.
Finally, a summer movie. Edge of Tomorrow is an engaging and exciting sci-fi film that has a lot of fun with its premise.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a sad, angry excuse for a comedy that contains exactly one chuckle and infinitely more cringing.
Willow Creek is an unexpectedly restrained and atmospherically effective slow burn.
It's easy to poke fun at some of the more far-fetched scenes and, at times, cheesy dialogue, but this is still one hell of an action movie.
Life Itself is a glorious celebration of Ebert and everything he accomplished throughout his life. It's tough at times, but always fair.
Writer/director James Cameron has made his fair share of groundbreaking, great movies, but pound for pound True Lies is his most flat-out entertaining.
This is one bonkers movie, filled with enough sci-fi concepts for an entire series and just enough grisly action to get by during its sub-ninety minute runtime.
Need for Speed provides some excitement for its target demographic while proving to be an overlong slog for everyone else.
Guardians of the Galaxy breathes new life into an otherwise stale story thanks to a great script and Gunn's crafty direction.
It's nearly impossible to gauge what constitutes a "good" Turtles film, but this one delivers the requisite thrills, visual effects, and humor as well as one can reasonably ask for.
The Expendables 3 delivers despite some narrative speed bumps, questionable acting from the rookies, and iffy visual effects.
It has a handful of eye-rolling moments, but they're few and far between thanks to Moretz's presence, a refreshing teen romance, and understated drama that works.
Director Tim Story puts a competent visual polish on Ride Along, but it's simply not funny or action-packed enough to warrant a recommendation.
It is a grotesque, shrill, never-ending effort that always finds a way to sink a little lower just when you're positive there's no way it can.
A reheated mishmash of ideas that is decent when neck-deep in violence and cringe-worthy when fumbling its way through endless exposition.
It's just unfortunate that it falls prey to gradually making each character a little bit dumber to progress the narrative.
Dear White People stares race relations right in the face with a combination of biting satire, understated anger, and a whole lot of thoughtfulness.
While at times repetitive, John Wick builds up plenty of goodwill with its lean, no-nonsense story and some highly-impressive action set pieces.
Birdman is a true original; a work of technical wizardry, virtuoso acting, and compelling storytelling unlike anything we've seen before.
Chef is far from groundbreaking or even original, but it is the kind of well-made comfort food that we don't get often enough at the movies.
From the puns to the slapstick to the toilet, Dumb and Dumber is performed at such a high level that it transcends many of its influences.
Interstellar is a unique, sometimes enthralling, often thoughtful piece of filmmaking from one of our best directors.
Dumb and Dumber To contains enough laughs, clever references to the original film, and two all-in performances from Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels.
Happy Christmas is watchable throughout, but to say it's worth the journey is another matter.
Force Majeure is a challenging, character-driven slow burn and one of 2014's best films.
The Great Invisible is a stirring, sad, and well-made account of a catastrophe that will be haunting us for decades, whether we believe it or not.
As an account of the events that shook Penn State to its core in 2011, Happy Valley is complete and very level-headed - but not especially revelatory.
The Boxtrolls is a weird, completely original experience recommended for fans of this morbid animation sub-genre.
Ivory Tower is a competent, slickly-produced documentary that takes a hard look at the cost and perceived benefits of higher education in the United States.
Adam Sandler, reigning king of the Filmed Vacation, is back for another luxurious trip short on belly laughs and long on gooey sentimentality and familiar slapstick.
Key components missing: a point, a sense of awe, serviceable acting, and fun.
Neighbors is the funniest film of 2014 to this point.
Edward Jordon's script is loaded with witty dialogue and well-developed characters.
Taken in sum, Blackfish is a punishing indictment of a multi-million dollar industry and one of the finest documentaries of the year.
In many ways The Fugitive represents the pinnacle of a genre not much in style any more: the suspense/action picture.
Kelly is what makes Good Ol' Freda such an involving film when it covers otherwise well-traveled Beatles lore.
With Hollywood recycling and "rebooting" the same stories and sights more than ever, Gravity stands out as a spectacle not to be missed.
All Is Lost should have been a movie that has you thinking for days; instead it ends with a brief sigh of relief and a shrug.
It won't get any bonus points for breaking new ground, but it does for being very entertaining.
12 Years a Slave is an authentic, stunning, and moving work about the darkest reaches of American history.
As a biography about a man going through a very new, very scary disease and his will to help others, Dallas Buyers Club is a good, not great, effort.
With a tighter plot and more consistent tone, American Hustle could have had a shot at greatness.
Saving Mr. Banks makes you want to go back and revisit Mary Poppins, and that in itself is the highest compliment one can pay the film.
Nebraska is gentle, heartfelt, and strikes an emotional chord that falls right in line with director Alexander Payne's other recent works.
As a biographical drama Fruitvale Station works, though you're not going to pick up anything about the actual shooting that you don't already know.
Thanks to a stellar cast and some great one-liners, Grudge Match is a funny, albeit completely disposable, time at the movies.
As a retelling of Belfort's rise to power and influence, The Wolf of Wall Street is as electric as any movie in years.
It's a sweaty-palmed, relentless thriller - and a damned good one.
...a thoroughly detestable piece of gutter trash masquerading as some kind of abstract piece of pop art.
Draft Day is a passable sports drama for those interested in the behind-the-scenes hi-jinks of the title event. For everyone else, there's not much to see.
You know fun? Think the exact opposite of that and you'll be in the right mindset for Sabotage.
It piles on the beheadings, throat slashings, and impalements to near-unprecedented levels. No sign of brains, however.
Non-Stop features such a brilliant set-up that you spend most of the film wondering if it can pay it off. The answer is no.
Pompeii may have razor-thin characters and the least-convincing romance of the past few years, but one thing it is not is boring.
A generic, factory-sealed action film that is actually more interesting before Alex Murphy makes his transformation to RoboCop.
In The Theory of Everything, director James Marsh has crafted an emotional, affectionate tribute to Stephen Hawking, love, and life itself.
This is a high-energy, smart, and surprisingly touching family film that truly delivers something for everyone - and maybe even more so for adults.
You let one-man shows do their act, and Carrey's entrance to Hollywood is still a fun ride.
If you like bizarre, confusing tonal shifts wrapped around a sloppy, never-believable-for-a-minute story, look no further than Labor Day.
A lean, old-school espionage thriller that never tries to be more than it is, Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit is a very pleasant surprise.
It's difficult to even discern what the appeal is, but if you like choppy action sequences, hammy acting, and are completely bored out of your skull...no, I can't even recommend it then.
Her is a gorgeous creation, and one of 2013's finest films.
It's a pretty by-the-numbers war flick that does itself a disservice with its spoiler-ridden title.
A dreary and largely uninteresting film about events that shouldn't be dreary and uninteresting.
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone won't blow you away with originality, but I'll be damned if it's not the most consistently funny comedy in recent memory.
Thick with atmosphere and rife with foreboding happenings, The Babadook is one of the best horror films so far this decade.
Wild doesn't trek over new ground, but its stream-of-consciousness narrative style and an Oscar-worthy turn from Reese Witherspoon make it worth a look.
Though still worth a look, Where to Invade Next falls in the bottom half of the Moore canon, neither as organized or potent as previous offerings.
99 Homes is a timely topical drama that packs real punch the deeper it goes into the rabbit hole of lawless capitalization on destroyed lives.
Though overly melodramatic at times and absent the full details of the toll CTE really takes, Concussion is at its best when operating as an underdog story.
Though light on plot and in need of a runtime haircut, Sisters is as rapid fire, energetic, and raunchy as any comedy this year.
The Big Short is a crackling, live entertainment that elicits as many laughs as jaws agape that this could happen.
Led by two first-rate performances, 45 Years is an intimate, introspective work that ranks among 2015's best.
Joy doesn't resonate as a hard-hitting, memorable biography, but as a lightweight, ultimately charming slice of entrepreneurial spirit, it works.
Anomalisa embodies what we've come to expect from Kaufman: a venture into the strange while somehow staying grounded in reality. Just like life.
13 Hours is a visceral, pounding experience that works as a vintage Bay action film even as it skirts the bigger overall picture.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With Hail, Caesar!, it's baffling to see the Coens deliver something with next to nothing at stake and zero involvement from a character perspective.
Profane, hyper-violent, and never hesitant to take things a step or two beyond overkill, Deadpool is just the swift kick to the junk the genre needs.
How To Be Single is unfocused, horrifically shot and edited, and not nearly as raunchy as it thinks it is.
Like most contemporary comedy sequels, Neighbors 2 is essentially the same film as Neighbors, minus the freshness and purpose of existence.
Free State of Jones features a handful of moderately powerful moments that don't add up to a powerful overall experience.
Watching Room is essentially the act of barely breathing and nearly crying for two hours.
Padded by too many lame jump scares to count, Blair Witch becomes a near-literal remake of its predecessor once the group enters the fateful woods.
While not nearly as unforgettable as the events on which it's based, Deepwater Horizon works well enough as a spectacle and tribute to the fallen.
It's hardly high art, but director Taylor and screenwriter Wilson make The Girl on the Train work just well enough to warrant a look.
Fans of the original know what to expect here. If you can't get enough of Bad Santa's mean streak, you'll find plenty to enjoy in Bad Santa 2.
The opening frames of Jackie lead one to believe they're about to see a horror film. One wouldn't be far off.
It Comes at Night is a relentlessly bleak exercise in paranoia and distrust that taps into some of the deepest fears within the human condition.
47 Meters Down is an impressive picture from a technical perspective. It's a shame the dialogue isn't given the same consideration.
Given little context and even less character arc, Dunkirk emerges as an emotionally hollow exercise in wartime spectacle.
Good Time is thematically spare, but the savvy, energetic direction of the Safdie brothers and Pattinson's wide-eyed, intense performance keep it afloat.
No one will ever call this series high art, but it does aim to please and built-in fans will find a lot to like in Kingsman: The Golden Circle.
The best films of this genre always show a path and provide a takeaway for being a better person. Lady Bird does just that.
While certainly not a new classic, The Man Who Invented Christmas is an enjoyable experience that succeeds in rousing the Christmas spirit.
The Disaster Artist is an enormously entertaining look at film making dreams and the legacy that comes with making a truly terrible one.
Downsizing thinks it's playing with fire but is really just rubbing two twigs together and hoping for the best.
Like many recent entries to Neeson's canon, The Commuter is fairly involving until it comes time to explain what's going on.
Overlong and often struggling to balance action and comedy, The Magnificent Seven is an uneven effort with some sensational action.
The Revenant is another sweeping accomplishment for Iñárritu and one of 2015's best films. Just make sure you know what you're in for.
Amy is a celebration of all she accomplished as well as a cautionary tale about the grave price to be paid for not getting an addict the help they need.
Spotlight is one of the great journalism films; compelling, flawlessly acted, and successful in its invitation to join in the hunt for the truth.
Seedy, drug-fueled, and absent any type of sense we're used to in film, Inherent Vice is a film destined to divide any audience that watches it.
A joy and sight to behold from beginning to end, The Grand Budapest Hotel is pure filmmaking delight. It's one of 2014's best.
Dry yet fascinating, and always carrying an air of hushed immediacy, Citizenfour nicely documents a revelatory piece of recent history.
Headlined by career best work from Jake Gyllenhaal, Nightcrawler is one of the darker and craftier thrillers to come along in quite awhile.
Sharp, powerful, and engaging from the first frame on, Whiplash is as intense and satisfying as any movie in years.
Featuring three fine performances and intriguing, coldly effective storytelling, Foxcatcher is compulsory viewing for genre fans.
Zamperini's bravery and will to live gets pounded into cinematic submission in Unbroken, and it's more relief than inspiration when it finally ends.
Two Days, One Night is a focused, frankly heartbreaking take on personal morals, selfishness, and what we're willing to sacrifice for others.
Into the Woods is eighty minutes of energy and joy followed by forty more of tiresome, by-the-numbers visual effects. The drop-off in quality is notable.
Though overlong, The Interview elicits a good number of laughs from its go-for-broke execution and boundless energy.
A Most Violent Year is a compelling exercise in minimalist intensity, drawing power from characterization and well-paced plotting.
Boyhood, which started filming in 2002 and continued off and on for twelve years, is the greatest coming-of-age story ever put to film.
Selma is one of the great emotional experiences of recent years; a fiercely powerful look at one of the Civil Rights Movement's most triumphant victories.
The Imitation Game both brings to life and pays tribute to Turing's history-altering and pioneering work that paved the way for modern computing.
The ongoing struggle to make cyber crime an exciting time at the movies continues with Michael Mann's Blackhat, a ridiculous mish-mash of genre stereotypes.
Jupiter Ascending sure looks nice, but beyond that it's an incomprehensible mess of a story and certainly the last big-budget gasp for the Wachowskis.
As films about people with devastating diseases go, Still Alice is understated, thought-provoking, and written and directed with a steady hand.
Brooklyn is a fine serving of comfort food, innocent and successfully operating at a deeper level when exploring the difficulties of leaving home.
Secret in Their Eyes, a remake of the 2009 Oscar-winning Argentinian film of the same name, is an old-school, taut, and endlessly involving thriller.
Love the Coopers is as much a comedy as a Christmas movie, in that it's neither and more a drama taking place around Christmas that eeks out a few laughs.
Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead serves as the perfect time capsule of National Lampoon's run and the influence it has on comedy to this day.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While plenty of questions permeate the air as the end credits roll, The Wolfpack is a compulsively watchable, borderline hypnotic experience.
Spectre, despite its lush locales and trademark superb action set pieces, is a mostly downtrodden, robotic exercise in wild goose chase plotting.
American Sniper is at its freshest and most insightful when examining the physical and mental effects warfare takes on a soldier.
San Andreas is lightweight, crowd-pleasing summer entertainment that knows its place and delivers the goods.
There's "paying the bills," then there's something this lazy, uninspired, and hackneyed.
The law of diminishing returns strikes big-time in Avengers: Age of Ultron, an overstuffed mess of one-note characters, gaudy CGI, and bad one-liners.
For all its melodramatic mopey-ness, The Age of Adaline mostly treads water to its anti-climactic conclusion.
Unfriended is a by-the-numbers, scare-free slasher package that will likely test your patience for watching people yell at each other on Skype.
McFarland USA won't win any awards for originality, but it's a prime example of a proven formula done right.
Fifty Shades of Grey may be the first film in history made specifically for the purposes of hate-watching.
What the films have going for them are fun characters and clever writing, both of which keep Pitch Perfect 2 from being a lazy rehash of the original movie.
Identity Thief is a cinematic shart - a huge mess that's no fun to clean up.
Just because you know you're a lame retread doesn't mean you're not a lame retread.
As a showcase for Cirque's astonishing assortment of shows, it's a must-see for fans.
Body of Lies is certainly one of most well-crafted and intellectually engaging political thrillers to come along this year.
An Oliver Stone film often takes a few years to ripen, and it will be interesting to see how this biopic plays a decade or so down the road.
This is the kind of movie that Chuck Norris would have made 15 years ago, except there would be two dozen bad guys and plenty more excitement.
While Casino Royale was the perfect mix of the old and new, Quantum of Solace, while oftentimes thrilling, is more of a downtrodden experience that only shows a sporadic sense of humor.
Four Christmases is simply all-too-familiar and exceedingly mediocre - and will likely be forgotten by the time we take down our Christmas trees.
Will Smith wants an Oscar. That much we understand. But if he thinks he can get one by playing a tragic character in very mediocre-to-bad movies, he's likely mistaken.
It's a formula picture all the way, but Carrey and the supporting cast sure make it seem better than that.
Plot holes notwithstanding, Inkheart is a well-timed and well-made family film that seems too good for the traditional January dumping grounds.
Real life aside, The International is a compelling and suspenseful thriller that features one of the best shootouts of the decade.
Friday the 13th may be the only film I can think of that could roll the credits after the first twenty minutes and have most people leave happy.
Watchmen is no doubt a love letter to those who have been awaiting this film for two decades, but the drawbacks outweigh the advantages for the uninitiated.
It's one of those movies where the reactions of those around you may be more entertaining than the film itself.
Here's the simplest way to put it: if you liked the over-the-top, brutal finale of Pineapple Express, you'll most likely find yourself enjoying Observe and Report...
This is premier summer entertainment.
The Hangover is a breathless stroke of comedic genius; one of those movies where, when it comes out on DVD and you have a bunch of friends over, you won't be able to watch just one scene.
In what has been an alarmingly weak summer, Transformers 2 really doesn't contribute much to improve it.
The narrative has a few holes, but on the whole this will please fans of the genre and those looking for an accessible document of John Dillinger's life.
To say this is Hitchcock-esque is an understatement. I wish the whole thing had been shot in black and white.
Some heartwarming moments do spring up here and there, but this more of a cinematic red carpet for current Hollywood talent than an actual movie.
...gets bogged down with a very talky script, little-to-no action, and a convoluted plot involving an energy corporation cover-up, corrupt government, and nuclear weapons.
We're not talking Because I Said So bad, but at least Couples Retreat bad.
...a film so bent on hiding and joking its way around its subject matter that it simply becomes a TV movie with recognizable faces.
Water and Chap Stick may be difficult to come by in the post-apocalyptic world of The Book of Eli, but ammunition certainly is not.
Religulous will almost certainly not change your opinion of Maher, but the film is exceedingly well-made, intriguing, and awkwardly hilarious.
It has a good heart, is well-made, and will definitely get the job done as a savior from the January doldrums that are bound to surface in the coming weeks.
Capitalism: A Love Story is his [Moore's] most heated and searing film since Fahrenheit 9/11, but not necessarily his best.
We should be leaving the theater in awe of what was accomplished, but the movie feels too by-the-books and unfortunately does not leave a lasting impression.
If you feel like you've seen all this genre has to offer, save your ten dollars and take comfort that you're probably right.
There's only one winner in this film, and it's Applebee's. Take my word for it and watch some Travel Channel instead.
Director Ruben Fleischer and his team have crafted one of the most enjoyable black comedies of the year.
While familiar comedic chords are struck, the film feels unfocused and incomplete.
As a Christmas diversion, it will work for some. As a tribute and effort to introduce Sherlock Holmes to a new generation, it's a notable disappointment.
Burton and his team have put style over substance here, resulting in an uneven and frustrating experience.
This is about as innocent and well-intentioned as teen movies get any more.
Remember Hide and Seek? Yeah, the twist is that obvious.
This series has promise, but The Golden Compass is a letdown.
The film is a pleasantly ambitious smorgasbord of genres.
What starts off as a compelling drama descends into a stock B-grade horror flick with some of the worst big budget special effects of recent memory.
These guys have the skills, and in a time of monotonous, poorly executed, and introspective-free Hollywood romantic drivel, there's plenty of opportunity.
In addition to the faulty premise, which effortlessly lends itself to writer / director David E. Talbert's preachy agenda, the movie just plain isn't funny.
It's an event movie in January, and when was the last time we had one of those? Experience it on the big screen with an enthusiastic crowd.
Sure it's predictable, but what do you want in this movie? A sad ending? That would be called a drama.
Rambo delivers big-time and simultaneously gives a big, blood-covered middle finger to all the neutered action movies of late.
This January has been surprisingly pain-free, a rarity for sure, but this heap brings matters back to a stark reality.
It's true, writer/director Malcolm D. Lee does pound home a few life lessons, but it mostly comes at the expense of animal attacks, farts, and all-around comedic laziness.
How is this for a proposition? From now on, Working Title Films is the only production company that is allowed to make films in this genre.
The fact that the screenplay refrains from smug political commentary and instead focuses on action and mystery enhances the experience.
Had a script been written, I'm confident that we could have had a great comedy on our hands.
Rather than dwell with a bunch of debating politicians, Peirce explores the serious psychological issues that many soldiers have upon return from any war.
I was halfway expecting Leslie Nielsen to make a cameo appearance as the coroner.
The film offers some witty one-liners, but it's largely a by-the-numbers affair that really just made me feel better about myself.
Chan and Li both deliver in their own unique ways, and there's enough action and humor to satisfy even the less enthusiastic martial arts fans out there.
...a thriller that's not suspenseful enough and a drama that is not daring enough.
Her [Faris'] charisma and comic timing, coupled with the schizophrenic script by Karen McCullah Lutz and Kirsten Smith, makes The House Bunny a recommendable comedy.
...the movie's pure energy and flawless comic timing make it a quality late summer diversion.
High entertainment this is not, but as a period-driven action picture loosely based on a tumultuous time in Los Angeles' history, it's a strangely entertaining and bonkers experience.
This is the kind of movie going experience that people tell their grand kids about.

We've come to expect a lot in recent years in terms of storytelling with Batman Begins and its ilk, and Hellboy II still feels like a relic from four years ago that hasn't evolved with the rest of the field.
The screenwriters, four in all, and director D.J. Caruso completely squander any opportunity to be original and instead opt to make a generic and completely unsatisfying thriller.
Only Pixar could pull off a story about robots in love with this much success.
It's loud and in-your-face, and it does maintain the same "we know this is crazy; just go with it" tone that made Iron Man so much fun.
The fact of the matter is that this review doesn't matter.
That same smile you had as a wide-eyed ten-year-old will be duplicated as you watch this joyous cinematic exercise that cynics may believe is outdated and stale.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is absurdly complicated for such a young demographic, and at 135 minutes it will be a monotonous chore for most others.
We may not see a better movie this summer.
While Guantanamo Bay isn't as consistently funny as its predecessor, it does capitalize on the fact that the world is even more screwed up now than it was four years ago.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though these adaptations usually produce horrific results, Get Smart is a cut above thanks to some fun performances and preposterously entertaining action.
Of all the Judd Apatow-era imitators, She's Out of My League is one of the better ones.
The majority of the gags, as crude as they can be, hit the mark and the interplay between Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly keeps the film from becoming a repetitive bore.
It sounds crazy, and it is crazy, vulgar, over-the-top and very, very funny.
Green Lantern isn't just bad, it's Fantastic Four bad.
Did no one, at any point, simply ask, "do we really want Larry the Cable Guy carrying this movie?"
Transformers: Dark of the Moon, the third in the Earth-destroying series, delivers the goods, plain and simple.
...there is a wholesome, even naïve (by today's standards) outlook at work that really comes off as refreshing.
You'll get your laughs, but you'll also wish it had gone for the throat in the end.
A tense, first-rate thriller that will have you running for the soap and water once the end credits start rolling.
The laughs aren't quite as consistent and you kind of get the feeling that Kal Penn and John Cho are outgrowing this stuff, but it nevertheless delivers for fans of the stoner now-trilogy.
Interesting things happen onscreen, but there is an inexplicably empty, sterile feel to the whole affair.
Why are these movies so depressing?
It's funny, moving, quick-witted, and way better than anything your kids are watching on TV these days.
What we're left with is a procedural that's difficult to get completely invested in.
Red Tails has Lucas' fingerprints all over it in that the action scenes are thrilling, but pretty much everything else is half-baked and a cliché of a cliché.
You're never bored, but you're also aware of how much better it could be.
Creepy only in its few moments of psychological horror, The Woman in Black is really nothing more than a jump scare marathon.
Whereas the original had the wonderful epiphany of watching a comedy that actually didn't suck, The Hangover Part II sticks strictly to its own formula - and to a fault.
For those starving for a gritty, competently-made action film that's not loaded down with corny CGI, this is the ticket.
Engaging, exciting, and successfully cross-breeding elements of Terminator and even Pet Sematary, Looper is a solid work of palatable science-fiction.
After a string of disappointments, it's nice to see Burton get back to his bread and butter: giving us a demented blend of laughs, drama, and scares.
Hitman may represent some progress in the video game adaptation genre, but it's not enough to recommend.
A warmed-over relic from the 90's incompetently directed by Rob Cohen, Alex Cross is a mess from top to bottom.
Affleck has crafted a truly old school suspense movie that is as involving as any film I've seen this year.
Flight is amazing while it's airborne, but much less so on the ground.
It's a fine action film. I just wish I could say it was more fun.
The Invisible War is a crushing indictment of a system that is way off the rails.
Safety Not Guaranteed is an original worth seeking out.
Hyde Park on Hudson is a disappointingly bland mix of drama and comedy that never comes close to gelling.
A well-made spectacle that makes up for overall lacking story and character development with one incredible action scene after the next.
Hitchcock is most engaging when concentrating on the nitty gritty of Psycho's development, as opposed to the potboiler subplot involving his wife that leaves very little at stake.
Zero Dark Thirty has nary a wasted scene and very little in the way of respite from the intensity and power of its story and execution.
Lincoln is Spielberg's best film since 2005's Munich, and one of 2012's finest.
The first half alone warrants a watch and fans of Ferrell and Galifianakis will not be disappointed.
On Stranger Tides has the faint stink of a phoned-in cash grab, and box office receipts will likely confirm fears that this is not the last we've heard from Jack Sparrow and company.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It provides a compact runtime (oh, how I've missed you, 90-minute movie) and a quality laughs/minute ratio.
You won't think too deeply about the supernatural possibilities presented in the film, but you will respect them as clever and absorbing storytelling devices.
As a send-up of the buddy-cop action/comedy, it's serviceable, but it's no Hot Fuzz.
This is one of those movies where the grandiose vision is there, but it never gels.
Nolan dares the viewer to jump into his multi-layered world, his own maze, and dedicated moviegoers will not be able to resist - even for a second, third, or fourth time.
This could have been a killer black comedy without a whole lot of rewriting, but the Duplasses opted for the awkward social comedy that doesn't deliver the consistent laughs one might expect.
Where's the fun? We're talking about characters that can throw fire and water. Where's the excitement and sense of wonder?
This is as flat, lazy, and uninspired of a comedy as any in years.
As a piece of action/comedy filmmaking with plenty of retro winks, Wright can put another feather in his cap.
...one of Pixar's top-three finest works and, if the Academy does what is right, a surefire Best Picture candidate.
By now everyone knows the drill, but this new Karate Kid proves that the formula still has life.
This is in-one-ear-out-the-other kind of stuff, but it will get the job done as an air-conditioned refuge from the summer heat.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At this point it's virtually impossible to escape the cruel irony that Sex and the City, the show, ended when it did so that it wouldn't become what this movie is.
The spoof genre had appeared dead for many years, but MacGruber has a spirit and determination to entertain that is reminiscent of a lot of the spoof films from the glory days.
It serves its purpose by providing ninety minutes of consistent laughter, though no scene really stands out from the others.
Well, at least I know what setting $70 million ablaze looks like in 3D.
It's not a film I can recommend except to those who fully know what they're getting themselves into, but it's also effective and professional enough that it can't be immediately dismissed.
