Just when we think we 'get' where Cody and Kusama are taking us, they thwart expectations and cinematic standards%u2026but not always in a good way.

As one of the last great proprietors of motion picture prestidigitation, Gilliam is his own protagonist. As you follow the fall of Parnassus, you see the story of the director's rise, rejection, and reinvention of himself.
A Single Man should have been stellar. Instead, it's just oddly engaging without being emotionally immersive.
Set against an enigmatic and atmospheric backdrop, the duo avoids the standard sci-fi trappings to forge something meaningful and memorable.
a mindless waste of time
It might take you a while to see it, and maybe more than one viewing, but in the end, The Lovely Bones becomes a heartbreaking, harrowing expression of love and loss
When it doesn't try to be everything to everyone, Tooth Fairy works, more or less. The rest of the time, it is relentlessly inane.
If you've seen it in the endlessly running ads, you've "seen it" in the film itself
The showdown with Gibson almost singlehandedly saves the movie -- almost
the "art of movement" has been replaced by the same old Hollywood histrionics.
Without (Travolta), the movie would be a royal waste of time. With him, it's redeemed, if only super-spy-ficially.
gets so many things right that when it goes astray that you kind of wish it hadn't tried in the first place
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: As a general rule, gimmickry does not lend itself to fine art
Wolfman...is all bark and very little bite.
The Secret of Kells is eye candy sweeter than most. It's mesmerizing in its never-ending innovation and caloric in pure creativity.
...this is the first great movie of 2010, a pristine example of cinema at its most sly and seductive.

While George Romero would come to redefine horror once again with his brilliant Dawn of the Dead, this interesting action thriller illustrates the talent it took to be such a consistent genre visionary.
all tone and atmosphere, with very little dread to go around.
Cop Out is not a flop by any stretch of the late Winter/early Spring, post-Awards season sense of movie marketing. It's just a genial, generic romp.
As a rule of thumb, if you're going to revisit formula, you better have a spectacular story to tell or a great set of compelling characters to occupy it. Fuqua has neither...
...just a single casting decision away from being another brilliant update. Instead, it's just a wonderful, if flawed, entertainment.
The movie musical can still be a splendid bit of escapism. With Nine, the only thing you'll want to flee is the movie theater itself.
In a year filled with audacity (Antichrist, Inglourious Basterds), nothing is cheekier and as out and out ballsy as The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call - New Orleans.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: ...one of 2009's best experiences, a narrative highway where every mile represents another revealing rest area, where each conversation pushes us closer to our formidable final destination.

As titles go, Jackson's own self-penned label lingers with hints of what could have been and what never will be. Still, for anyone still looking for a little bit of his magic, This Is It contains more than enough.
a smart-ass slap in the face
all science and little sentiment
Neither as quirky as it thinks it is nor as witty as it wants to be, The Men Who Stare at Goats is a low grade military send-up.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Step right up and prepare to be mesmerized, bowled over, and generally blown away by Roland Emmerich's 2012, a movie that is guaranteed to be the last word on impending cinematic Armageddon for the foreseeable future.
Winning, witty, and wearing out its welcome toward the end, Pirate Radio is either a noble failure or the slightest of successes.
Most tragedies provide a final act of catharsis. All Precious has to offer is more and more malice.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Clerks remains a defining debut, a symbolic shot into the darkened domain of legitimate moviemaking.
Like a raw nerve tweaked over and over again by emotions both radiant and revealing, Chasing Amy is as close to a masterpiece as Smith has ever created.
Like one massive inside joke that only regulars to the View Askew Universe will get, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back is the ultimate measure of Smith's undeniable nerdiness.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: this time around, Rodriguez is vying for Father of the Year
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Gone with the Wind is still dated, but it's a dynamite kind of antiquity.
dull and lifeless, moving inertly from point to point without offering much that's memorable or amusing
Even if it weren't true, The Blind Side would be a special film.
(T)hanks to Hillcoat's reverence to the source material and his desire to visualize McCarthy's mind's eye Armageddon, we wind up with something so harsh it's almost unbearable.
While there is more to Ninja Assassin than endless gory excess, what's remains is like an arterial spray afterthought.
...a wholly unique piece, a contemporized take on Dahl's 1970 book with as much interpersonal angst as kid-friendly fun.
What his other movies have done summarily or languidly, Lock, Stock, and Two Smoking Barrels does with some clear novice stumbles. It's creative and very clever. It's just not a classic.
movie_title: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1999)

movie_review_blurb: It's like getting into a time machine and going back to the days of great mouse detectives, lion kings, and open-hearted beauties and their lovelorn beasts.
...every sports movie cliche, combined it with a relatively revealing look at the early days of the Nelson Mandela administration...
a stunning masterpiece.
It would be acceptable if all this fakeness lead to something legitimately funny. Instead, we're left bemused and bored.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fight Club is still today a definitive film, a statement as strong as any rock anthem and twice as packed with power chords.
Sukiyaki Western Django is Sergio Leone on LSD. It's every '60s/'70s revisionist western riff supersaturated in stylized bombast and a purposed perversion of the motion picture mannerism.
When it comes down to it, Hostel Part II is the near perfect sequel, a money mandated continuation that actually works as a companion piece to the original effort
when the entire movie revolves around rooting for (or against) the success of a massive suicide bombing campaign, you're asking a lot from the popcorn and nacho crowd.
Madea's Class Reunion is no work of art. But as populist amusements go, it is hard to deny.
On the grand scale of adaptations, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy falls...closer to Lord of the Rings than it does The Shining, or I, Robot.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The best way to describe Red Cockroaches is unattractive people doing vague things for no apparent reason.
No Direction Home ...becomes a portal back in time, a chance to relive some of...the most exciting years in the history of politics, personality and music.
Proving that a lot of great cinema came out of the Australian scene circa the 1970s, Long Weekend [claims] its place as a legitimate member of the masterful macabre.
[I]n the light of a new millennium, Wertmüller deliver[s] the first girl power picture, and it's a stunning masterstroke of a movie.
movie_title: Swept Away (Travolti da un Insolito Destino nell'Azzurro Mare d'Agosto) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: With final words that are both exhilarating and sad, and [a]...message that maligns wars of all types...Wertmüller has crafted a political protest out of the tenets of tragedy
As gentle and soothing as a summer wind, this evening in the heat of political and physical passion is an affair to enjoy. Remembering it may be another matter all togethe
movie_title: Summer Night (Notte d'Estate Con Profilo Greco, Occhi a Mandorla, e Odore di Basilico) (1986)

movie_review_blurb: We keep expecting more from...Ray - more blood, more boobs, and more beasts. Instead, we get standard sandal and sword shtick that barely satisfies our lust for loincloths.
There is a great film to be made about the grappling glamazons who helped blaze a trail that lead to legitimizing women's athletics. This is not that movie, however.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While far from perfect, the buckets of blood mentality really works well here. Too bad the rest of the film couldn't compliment, instead of constrict, the splatter.
Watching the three films on this disc is like walking into a time machine and setting the dial on "deranged".
This is the great calamity of The Man Who Fell to Earth. For humans, the hurt ends at death. For Thomas, it may continue on indefinitely...perhaps, forever.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Loud, illogical, and without a single redeeming character, Jungle Juice is the Korean cinema's idea of an American mob comedy.
You have to admit, The Fallen Ones is good old fashioned goofy cheddar cheesiness.
Instead of destroying a "classic," as many people feared, Burton has completely reinvented and reinvigorated it, creating something terrific and timeless.
This bravado brainchild...is like watching Peter Jackson's private personal video experiments, or Sam Raimi's first forays into Evil Dead-based fright.
Gimmicky, pat, and just a tad too brutal at times, Imagining Argentina is a powerful statement rendered oddly ineffectual by a consistent desire to avoid controversy.
Heat feels like a cobbled-together conclusion to this so-called trilogy, a movie that offers little of what made the other offerings...so terrific in the first place.

BloodRayne is a movie of unconnected plot dots. In the hands of director Uwe "German Tax Dodge" Boll, a simple sword and sorcery story with vampiric overtones turns into genre-jumping attempts to find an audience.
Poseidon is 90 minutes of endless meandering, heroics via happenstance and shoddy F/X work.
Something like Meet the Browns manages to resonate, even without the wisecracking woman who made Perry a near-household word.
Indeed, everything about The Da Vinci Code is insular and insipid. Somewhere inside this creaky, crappy film is a real adventure romp waiting to be revealed.
Just like the spies' mission as they hunt for secrets and significance inside massive corporate databanks, [Cypher's] point is unclear.
Imagine...The Kingdom directed by Peter Greenaway, or Brazil helmed by David Lynch and [that's] the type of hallucinogenic horror show you are getting here.
Jem is a lot like cartoon crack: you know it can't..be good for you, but once you've sampled...its sugary charms, you instantly...would sell your soul to obtain [more].
You have never had such a...bad time with a Hong Kong action flick as you will if, by some evil act of fate, you are forced to witness the witless Shaolin Revenger.
As a work of cinematic sensation, Suicide comes up short. But on the level of moviemaking performance art...this import is intriguing.
Outlaw Prophet is a work of warped genius that has to be seen to be believed.
Agent 15 is a schizophrenic slice of smart alecky fun. It is also an occasionally overreaching bore.
[Feeders 1&2] are examples of what is right with no-budget moviemaking, of how individual vision can exist and thrive in even the most cutthroat of industries.
Rock and Roll Goldmine is a nice collection of classic clips disadvantaged by the attempts to be all-inclusive, sentimental and overly important.
Just let it be said, in as simple a manner as possible, that Cracker is the best that television can get, and be done with it.
[D]on't mistake this as some manner of musical statement. It's just a spoiled rich kid living out her rock and roll fantasy for the whole world to see.
Gut-Pile is so under-developed, so slapdash in its narrative approach that we never get completely involved in the story (what little there is).
Demon Summer is yet another example of how ability and agility can overcome even the most minimal monetary considerations when it comes to moviemaking.
Dr. Hackenstein is only an occasionally funny, but mostly meandering motion picture about sutures and stupidity.
[T]he Fangoria Blood Drive is well worth a look, especially to see some of the sensational directorial flair on display.
Eddie Presley is...close to perfect, almost overcoming its low budget obstacles to turn into something truly classic...
Vendetta is a movie for the people, by the people, because of the really low standards set by most of the people.
The Real Story of Half-Caste may be trying to recreate "reality" to shock and scare, but all it [does] is challenge your charitable nature regarding independent film.
Slim Susie makes the case that imitation is not only flattery, but the most effective language of postmodern cinema.
If you want to see The Grudge on steroids, or The Ring with real spook spunk, check out this Thai treat.
Street Trash is a celebration of all that is excessive and exciting in the world of splatter films. It is a truly misguided masterwork.
Reflections of Evil is a work of stunted genius...[the] effort of a freaked-out filmmaker overdosing on '70s TV, horror anthologies, and a...lack of psychotropic drugs.
Cold Blood is a decent, but ultimately disappointing thriller. Instead of a throwback, we end up with something only slightly better than a throwaway.
The only thing scary [about Parts of the Family] is how bad both versions of this movies are.
There is so much wasted potential in Fortress of Amerikkka it's like visiting you're average class of high school seniors.
Dazed and Confused is a perfect movie. It flawlessly captures the spirit of the '70s while arguing for a clear universality in the high school experience.

Nothing ruins a gag faster, be it in humor or horror, than someone having to explain it to you. But in the case of The Omen, we already knew the tale. The constant repetition and reminders are just onerous overkill.
Because this movie was made in Korea, and not in the focus group fancying US of A, The Host tends to avoid most of the genre's obvious stumbling blocks.
Zodiac crackles with a kind of corrupt electricity, an overriding feeling of discomfort that makes even the conversations between couples ache with an aura of unease.
Call it an attempt to jumpstart our imagination or a metaphoric map to rediscovering our inner joy, but 300 is built for spectacle, not scholarship.
Grindhouse...is a slam bam smash 'em up celebration of the freedom given film by the exploitation industry.

It's so effortlessly formed, so wholly its own entity that you consistently find yourself giddy with satisfaction at how good the film makes you feel. In a domain that's forgotten how to satisfy, Hot Fuzz is the very definition of a crowd pleaser.

Spider-Man 3 is an 'almost' success...it 'almost' has us convinced that this trilogy will transcend its blockbuster necessities to mean something more - either as art, precedent, or simply a great way to spend some time at the Cineplex.
If there is such a thing as a successful piecemeal horror film, 28 Weeks Later is it.
Shrek the Third plays like missed opportunities purposefully planned out that way. It's a film so afraid of letting down the demographic that it never ventures beyond the safe.
By downplaying the physical and emphasizing the cerebral (or in some cases, the spiritual) Lee was looking to take the genre to another level. For that alone (Circle of Iron) is very important.
(Knocked Up is) hilarious, heartfelt, endearing and just a wee bit evil in how it depicts the rigors of adult responsibility, and the inherent human desire to shirk same.
Like the popcorn movies of old, (Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End) is an experience as much as it is a film, a chance for audiences to get lost in elements they rarely experience in life.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fido [is] a wildly entertaining comedy. It has as much humor as horror, and a wonderfully wonky way of making its many cogent social critiques.
Evan Almighty is expertly forged to be a superficial audience friendly phenomenon, the kind of movie that has critics and the cultured scratching their heads over its continued success.
While not actually scary, 1408 is unsettling and intense, taking its own sweet time building to a truly disconcerting climax.
SiCKO is sensational. It's perhaps the best movie Michael Moore has ever made
In a summer that's seen underperforming tre-quels and more than its fair share of warmed over sameness, Transformers is offering something similar, but in a much more exciting and evocative guise.
Constantly pushing beyond its narrative and visual capacities, Ratatouille ends up one frighteningly effortless entertainment.
But for full fledged fantasy that doesn't skimp on the imagination or the intrigue, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is a brave, exciting entertainment.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Eagle vs. Shark is more interested in whimsy than wit, and when it comes to milking its characters for a little goofball charm, we are stuck with mostly peculiarities vs. personalities

Hairspray is the perfect example of cinematic synchronicity -- flawless casting, amazing material, brilliant production design, stellar songs and directorial magic all rolled up into one big wad of motion picture cotton candy
I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry is not as hilarious as it thinks it is, profound as it pretends to be, or tolerant as it intends.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Call it dystopian or future shocking, but Children of Men is nothing more than a sensational cinematic allegory as bona fide art.
But the main problem with the film, one that keeps it from reaching the highest elevations of popcorn entertainment, is its lack of real emotional resonance.
Apocalypto may not be one of the best movies of the year, but it surely stands shoulder to shoulder with those exceptional efforts of 2006 -- at least from an artistic perspective.
(The director's) ponderous use of pauses and long, languid tracking shots lack the gravitas he hopes to gain, and a few of the narrative flourishes ring ridiculous and false.
While it may not seem like it now, (Cars) will wind up another cartoon classic from a company that, apparently, can produce nothing but timeless treats.
(W)hile it doesn't have Napoleon Dynamite's wealth of quotable dialogue, (Nacho Libre,) does contain enough clever moments to warrant a real recommendation.
Click is sappy and saccharine, but it's the good kind of cleansing, cathartic corniness.
Bryan Singer's Superman Returns is good ... damn good. It's just not great. As a matter of fact, it misses greatness by a margin measured in just a few filmic fractions
There is more of everything in the new Pirates of the Caribbean movie: more spectacle; more exotic locales; more convoluted story contrivances.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: (Y)ou'd have to be brain dead to defend such illogical plotting, one dimensional characterization and aimless middle act meandering supposedly passing itself off as humor.
All throughout it's running time, Lady in the Water tends to make up its rules as it goes along...out of a sheer need for plotting or cleverness.
This joyous jeer-athon, filled with...dirty-word laden depth and instantly quotable moments... is a love letter to the unbridled ecstasy in speaking one's mind.
(Monster House)...is a Goonies to get lost in, an amiable adventure yarn that has action and atmosphere to burn.
Beautiful to look at and difficult to embrace, this is a movie of moments, not of overall narrative force.
For my money, (The Descent) is one of the most overrated and poorly realized spook shows in a very long time.
In fact...World Trade Center is one of the few cinematic efforts that wants to accurately recreate the confusion and chaos that derives from unexpected disaster.
Snakes on a Plane is the missing badass cousin of the original kitschy Airport films from the '70s
The Black Dahlia is not a black mark on the talent track record of anyone involved. Yet with such a potentially powerful story, it should have been something very special.
The new Texas Chainsaw Massacre movie is so desperate to create some indelible horror imagery that it forgets everything else that's required of a standard big screen movie macabre.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is, without a doubt, one of 2006's best movies, another milestone for a man whose career path is paved with such accolades.

The Prestige takes its title literally, asking us to believe in the power that stature and esteem has over two dark, desperate men, to witness how far both will go to achieve it...and more importantly, prevent it from happening for the other.
Unlike the current concept of over the top bloodletting that thinks the sequence is more important than the sluice, this inspired auteur gets his groovy grue just right.
(In Ganja and Hess) we get a devastating art film that raises more intriguing philosophical questions than hairs on the back of one's neck.

Saw III may not be the scariest, or most successful horror film ever made, but if you're looking for your pound of fright fan flesh, you'll get a nice craven corpse-full with this shockingly sick flick.

This is not to say that the movie is a bomb. In fact, (Borat)'s one of 2006's most light-hearted and warm surprises. It's just not the greatest, most daring, or controversial film in the history of humor.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If one would simply switch on their inherent intellect, they'd see the truth behind the tricks -- that is, that The Fountain is an astonishing, evocative experience
From non-detailed human faces to overly drawn vacuous villains, Marco Polo: Return to Xanadu is family entertainment at its worst.
What makes Midnight Skater such an enigmatic piece of enjoyment is the principle that...the film is just a bunch of friends, all out to share...the joy of creating.
This dreary bit of 'to the chateau born' is enough to make you burn all your material possessions on a ritualistic pyre and go homeless.
Michael Palin's Himalaya is...as majestic as the mountains he is hiking through and as rich in culture and history as the countries he comes in contact with.
Constantine does generate some mid-level amusement and F/X interest in the epic battle it's based on, but has very little to show for it once the final credits role.
Though it pales in comparison...At Last, The 1948 Show proves that Monty Python's Flying Circus was not just some act of silliness synchronicity.
Jail Breakers is an acquired taste, one that American audiences may have a hard time swallowing.
No Way Back may not be a flawless film, but it does deliver a quiet, quaint story with persuasion and passion.
[ Sleepaway Camp] is...a gritty, sleazy Grade-Z rip-off of what Sean Cunningham and the gang more or less perfected over at Crystal Lake.
With a solid humor lineage...Elvira: Mistress of the Dark is one of the best comedies of the late 80s.
Even at his most mean-spirited, Kinison demanded respect. Outlaws of Comedy does not.
[An} apropos motion picture maxim for Shark Attack 3: Megalodon would read "this time...it's miserable...Or horrible...Or copyright infringeable."
All inferences to the famous poet aside, Boccaccio '70 is a celebration of the opposite sex, a foursome of testaments to the undying connection between women and life.
Prison a Go-Go will probably inspire some minor mirth for those who don't look for sense or sensibility in their wit.
Dramatically powerful, exceptionally well acted and not without its tearful moments of reexamination and redemption...The Browning Version is a...masterwork of a film
Time Barbarians is a total hoot, a helplessly ham-fisted mess of a movie...
There is new beauty in what Truffaut is trying to show us, an exquisiteness that..forever alter[ed] the face of cinema.
Combining the best elements of horror, exploitation, grindhouse...and direct to video classicism, The Stink of Flesh is an incredibly good homemade fright flick.
Though it is strictly a bargain basement affair...and not without its miscues and missteps, this is still a wonderfully warm film that deserves to find a fanbase.
Marc Bolan definitely had it - whatever 'it' is - and even without a definition, 'it' is prevalent all throughout Born to Boogie.
A half century later, Bernstein's brave attempt at mixing classical with commercial still has issues. Thankfully, they have nothing to do with the marvelous music here.
Though falling short of being a masterpiece, this is still a dazzling document to a time long gone - and very much our own.
[W]hile it's competent and pleasant, there are no long lost revelations to be found during this humdrum Homecoming.
movie_title: Nazareth: Homecoming - The Greatest Hits Live In Glasgow (2002)

movie_review_blurb: While he was never a Top 40 hitmaker, Klaus Nomi was an important artist...and The Nomi Song is a cinematic anthem to his unorthodox individuality.
G.I. Executioner is a glorious goof, a spree so silly and stupid that it is easy to take pleasure in its problems.
Though it has the puppet skills to pay the bills, Tom and Francie just can't walk and talk the lampoon lane.
This is the Twin Peaks of terror, the Mulholland Dr. of mad Martian chronicles - expect, it's really none of those things.
As a character study, Flyerman is near flawless.
This is the kind of movie that makes you mad, that angers you in a way that's fundamental to your place within a democracy.
Quote not available.
tends to play like Dr. Tongue's 3D House of Hackneyed Sight Gags.
If you can't rejoice in David Lynch, what is there to be happy about?
An icon of irreverent comic brilliance.
The Grudge is a decent horror diversion: barely a classic, but still pretty atmospheric and suspenseful in its own right.
This is what makes Au Hasard Balthazar so powerful, and yet so distant. It asks as much of its audience as it does of its characters...
Frightmare fumbles so many of the standard scare tactics that it's almost impossible to see where it gained such a supercilious legitimacy.
Instantly taking its place in the canon of stirring, seminal documentaries, A Certain Kind of Death is destined to be remembered...
Gunner Palace is not a great film, but it is a contentious one.
Without a doubt, Crazed Fruit is a lost masterpiece of early Japanese filmmaking.
Half Japanese: The Band that Would Be King has all the hallmarks for a great rock doc...
movie_title: Half Japanese: The Band that Would Be King (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Double Dare is more about camaraderie than competition.
[Sunset Story] isn't a movie about retired activists. It's a stunning meditation on the battle between mission and mortality.
Sparkling and thought-provoking, Hukkle is the cinematic equivalent of a puzzle box wrapped up in ethnic enigmas and rural riddles.
The River is a sumptuous visual feast, yet another example ... of Renoir's amazing ability at using his camera as a paintbrush.
Land of Silence and Darkness is a tremendous testament to the strength of the human spirit...Werner Herzog is a filmmaker of substantive skill and talent.
movie_title: Land of Silence and Darkness (Land des Schweigens und der Dunkelheit) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: This searing documentary argues against the use of near-slave level migrant labor, implying that the United States' economy would collapse without it.
...Herzog and Penn don't challenge [the Loch Ness] myth. They are out to create their own. And they almost pull it off.
About the closest French Sex Murders comes to those yellow Italian pulp paperbacks is the ancillary 'giallo' moniker plastered on the production.
Like listening to an absent-minded blue comedian telling dirty jokes and forgetting the punch lines...
Uproariously wicked, cheekier than a carload of cockneys and about as addictive as a gross of Reese's Peanut Butter Eggs smothered in crack...
[Filthy McNastier/Filthy McNastiest] provides a lot of lowbrow, scatological yucks-in any connotation of that word.
Daniel Kraus and his talented cast and crew knock this one out of the park. Ball of Wax is an All-Star of an independent film.
Not only is this one of the best of the recent Asian examples of the fright flick, but it's one of the best movies about individual isolation and loneliness ever made.
Polyester may be one of the few times when Waters tried to expand his cinematic language at the expense of his usual verbal variety
Certainly Waters would argue that all his films end on an upbeat note. But [Hairspray] is the first time the joy seems genuine, not just perversely plastered on.
Pecker is Hairspray with Kodak film stock, or Crybaby without the juvenile delinquency angle
A Dirty Shame is a fabulously funny exploration of fetishism, a look at the ever-more-insane ways people find to 'get off'.
Yes, there were Style Wars back in the day. But they weren't just battling over graffiti design. The war was over which way the cultural landscape would swing.
Wishing Stairs is wishy-washy. It flounders its fear and confuses ephemeral with evil.
[E]ntertaining, just a wee bit self indulgent, and highly emotional at times, Jay-Z's farewell performance [is] a sensational, if occasionally shallow, concert experience.
You don't need a bully pulpit, or a barely visible bandstand, to make your point. The Roach Approach proves this in fascinating, near flawless ways.
movie_title: The Roach Approach: The Mane Event! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At least from this audience member's vantage point, this is not a Night to remember, but to avoid.
Colors Straight Up! is not about to offer a fairytale version of life... Yet it doesn't allow enough of the real world in to satisfy your sense of outrage, either.
Madea's Family Reunion is a great deal of fun -- improbable, overdone, and arch -- but a great deal of fun anyway
As a freak show..., Tetsuo certainly deserves its reputation. It contains memorable sequences of sickening imagination, and unique takes on tired sci-fi/ action ideas.
[A] stellar, visually involving piece of subtle science fiction, Viral Assassins transcends its no budget trappings to be a smart, involving thriller.
Watch Me Jumpstart will teach newcomers that there once was a group of Dayton daydreamers with a desire to be pop rock gods and illustrates how close they...came.
movie_title: Guided By Voices - Watch Me Jumpstart (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A Killing Spring is no worse than the...melodra-mysteries that Lifetime passes off every day as presentable female pastimes in easy to forget two-hour segments.
Prof. Harold Hill may believe the "think" system will teach his..."band" to play. But no amount of brainpower could make...this Music Man ...anything but derivative.
Indeed, while flawed and sometimes failing, this collection of short films is definitely worth your time.
As a musical piece, it is...able to convey mixed emotions within a very dissonant setting. But the film that goes along with it has a harder time selling its sense of self.
[The] movie...is packed with so much unbelievable asp crap that you'll wish your brain had been yanked out through your nose by a hook and a spiced onion inserted in its place
WOW, is Bloody Tease weird. Not in a good way weird, but in a "who in the Hell thought this was a good idea for a film" kind of weird.
While that may be asking a lot...if the one Lord can allow sinners to recant on their death bed, he should at least give this great, goony groove-a-thon a little dispensation
Desperate Living [is] a movie that feels like three separate films fused together. The first and the second are fantastic.
Combined with...Waters' own private peculiarities, Female Trouble stands along side Pink Flamingos as a sure sign of this director's depth and talent.
[A] demented comedy that defecates on everything the '60s stood for, and then allows the drag queen in the lead to eat in, right on camera.
Colorz of Rage is the "kinda movie" that thinks because it speaks of, to, and by "the street," it speaks for it. And it couldn't be more wrong.
If you're looking for a comedy that is truly black, or a slice and dice with lots of gooey goodness, Touch of Death will delight and disgust.
movie_title: Quando Alice Ruppe lo Specchio (Touch of Death) (When Alice Broke the Mirror) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: When viewed like this...without the interruption of commercials, constant preempting, time slot changes and rerun ennui, Millennium transmogrifies into a masterpiece.
Rubber's Lover is just a mess of a movie, an attempt at pushing the boundaries of acceptable cinema that ends up making a mockery of its own self-important idealism.
Perhaps the most pathetic excuse for a movie ever made, Operation Midnight Climax is a...self indulgent bit of claptrap passing itself off as an inspired comedy.
Disco: Spinning the Sound is...a wonderful primer on the music that defined the 70s.
Rick James: Super Freak Live 1982 is a stellar concert showcase that suffers only slightly from some minor technical and cultural glitches.
With the exception of Scooby Doo, no other children's show recalls the doped-up dementia of...60s better than the Krofft brother's baffling pre-pubescent psychedelia.
movie_title: Saturday Morning with Sid and Marty Krofft (2005)

movie_review_blurb: You may not enjoy every single aspect of Grace and the Storm, but you will see the potential in Christopher Baldi's vision.
While it is not a masterpiece, it is not an outright failure either. It exists in a metaphysical zone all its own.
Feeding the Masses has its flaws, but it also illustrates that all zombie horror needs is some imagination to experience its own rise from the grave
On par with South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut in the way in which a beloved TV series can be broadened and deepened by the cinematic experience, The Simpsons Movie is a major triumph.
Instead of just giving us the glorification of violence or vice, [Cerdà] digs down into the true heart of death's darkness. And he delivers the goods with...sensational skill.
Re-experiencing this series again will produce enough bliss to last another three decades.
[T]he Make Your Own Damn Movie DVD box set stands as a monument to the dedication and desires of [Troma's] Lloyd Kaufman.
[L]ike Peter Jackson's Dead Alive transported and mutated to fit a South African mentality...Pure Blood is..an interesting take on [a]...controversial subject.
Big Meat Eater has a kitchen sink feel to its formulation, a creaky cobbling together of ideas, genres and styles that don't always play nice with each other.
Pigs [plays] like a Shake-N-Bake version of A Touch of Satan, or any number of early 70s excuses for morose middling macabre...
Beginning with a...hymn to the...power of musical harmony, SMiLE is the definitive utopian view of the [US] as filtered through the...twilight of the Summer of Love.
Let's get the title-based buffoonery out of our collective system, shall we. Yes, Ripper 2 is a Ripper-off.
Philippe Mora has purposely made a movie about a criminal that has very little to do with crime. Instead, Mad Dog Morgan is about how an outlaw is crafted.
There are far too many amateurish and overreaching moments in Sixteen Tongues, as well as a few outright fumbles, that keep the film from singing with sci-fi relevance.
[The Great Rock N Roll Swindle is] a document of a particular time and place, a rarified work of scrap art that creates as many myths as it debunks.
[T]his tawdry triptych is a celebration to...exploitation. While your particular deviation may not find representation...there is...plenty of sexual and surreal imagination...
Let's just call Hamlet 2 Waiting for Guffaws, and be done with it. Sadly, said laughter rarely comes, if at all

Though this kind of film has been done dozens of times before, Herzog's desire for authenticity, along with his unusual approach to the underlying politics of the era, drive Rescue Dawn far above other battle scar epics.
(W)hat Boyle and Garland accomplish here is nothing short of a miracle.They manage to allude to previous motion pictures and yet make the riffs and references seem wholly their own.
For Street Kings, being an above-average example of an overused idea is not necessarily a bad thing.
(W)hat many will remember about this otherwise informative film is the way in which we get to know these men.
Indeed, what's clear about The Counterfeiters is that it is intended to be a Holocaust film where the archetypal facets associated with the era...are reduced to a filmic footnote.
Is it possible to recommend a movie based on a single scene alone? If it's The Forbidden Kingdom, the answer is an obvious "Yes."
The middle hour is magnificent, as fascinating a portrait of the beleaguered region as you're likely to see outside the Travel Channel.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While the actual ending does give audiences a reason to cheer, it's the final fade out that will make viewers the happiest. It means this tepid terror is finally over.
Written with a sensationally smutty Woody Allen expertise and loaded with big fat bawdy barrel laughs, Forgetting Sarah Marshall is another wacked out winner.
not really a film you enjoy, per se. It's more like a feeling you get used to before finally accepting.
a whiny, juvenile mess
During its slightly surreal scenes, Harold and Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay crackles. At other times, it's the same old smoke out.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Iron Man is fantastic, a sure fire blockbuster that will leave audiences breathless and fanboys wanting more.
For all its noble intentions and universal truths, Snow Angels is not a great movie. It's not a grand movie. It's barely a very good movie.
The battle for the human heart has official morphed from witty, sophisticated banter between star-crossed lovers to something akin to mixed martial arts.
Forget all the curmudgeonly criticism that argues for this movie's optical overload capacity - Speed Racer is a modern masterpiece
Young@Heart is a classic. May we all live to be so youthful in spirit and soul.
Just when you think (Mamet) can't plow more storylines into his situations, the slightly bloated script finds room for five or six more.
(Surfwise) delivers facts with fanciful shading, sequences that explain the lure of the ocean with images of the vast waves washing over their would-be conquerors.
On the page, The Chronicles of Narnia thrived on fiery faith-based fantasy. On film, said belief is rendered bland.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes, a story is just not worth telling, and while Mimi's life is definitely an unusual one, it's not iconic.
Frontier(s) still finds a way to mine the past while staying rooted in the present. It may seem recognizable, but it's a well made and effective awareness
CJ7 is a deceptive little delight, a movie that wisely avoids the pitfalls of its obvious homage to set its own cinematic course
You've got to give Clooney credit for trying, especially when most of Leatherheads is a jaunty, jazz age dream.
Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is clearly a movie geared toward anyone under the age of 30 who memorized every moment of their Raiders VHS.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Shine a Light does deliver in a way few concert films can - especially given the timeless talents on display
Maudlin and melodramatic when it doesn't need to be, but insightful and engaging when it counts, Under the Same Moon represents both the best and worst of the revelatory road trip narrative.
a brilliant little allegory
We view this event from every possible point of view except a logical -- or entertaining -- one.
should once and for all spell the end of Larry the Cable Guy's horrendous run of Hollywood hokum.
superficial and staged
Resembling the kind of tale Aesop might spin after one too many vats of homemade Ouzo, Penelope plods along on a desire to endear. All it really does is infuriate.
Semi-Pro may look like recycled Will Ferrell, outrageous personality and all, but there is an attention to detail and a surreal '70s splash that makes it all work.
Unfortunately, for all its superficial entertainment value, Perry-ites won't recognize much of Why Did I Get Married? And in this case, a lack of familiarity just may breed contempt.
frequently overreaches
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: (The Bank Job is) efficient without being pedestrian, tweaking the suspense here and there to add the proper amount of intrigue to the elements.
...when it plays to our sense of selective memory and fills in the blanks on issues long forgotten, Sputnik Mania is masterful.
As a series of set pieces looking for any available fable to keep it afloat, 10,000 BC is really nothing more than computing power and implausibility.
The only real torture here is the one Haneke inflicts on the audience.
As scattered as it is senseless.
Bereft of jokes while overloaded with keenly observed individual moments, Drillbit Taylor can best be described as an almost success. This also means it's a figurative failure.
a genial, generic effort attached to an intrinsically interesting premise.
In many ways, Married Life is a Coen Brothers knock-off without a bit of the boys' accomplishment or bravado.
In fact, the real problems with Chapter 27 is it vagueness. Everyone here - Leto, Lohan, Friedlander - leaves us in the lurch, and nothing Schaefer does can save our confusion.
...more of an artillery based Abercrombie and Fitch road trip than a concise character study.
For all its faults however, this is a romantic comedy that works - if just barely.
Superhero Movie should be taken as a well-meaning but ultimately uneven lesson in how to handle future parodies.
perhaps Perry's time in the limelight may be shorter than he -- or his fans -- think.
Nim's Island is all too insular, lost in its own unique universe somewhere between Swiss Family Robinson and Joe vs. the Volcano.
Persepolis is astonishing, a revelation realized in masterful monochrome strokes.
Indeed, Postal is THAT kind of movie, one that substitutes rancor for real wit, that utilizes splatter when a few script rewrites would have worked much better.
As a so-called novel filmmaking device, the "found footage" approach of first person POV storytelling has just about run its course.
consistently goes for the cheap laughs, mining way too many jokes out of puns, pratfalls, and the occasional reference to poop (these are apes, after all)
flash-foiled by motion picture incompetence
Like a symphony where every note is exactly where it needs to be, or a painting without a brushstroke wasted, The Dark Knight is an unabashed, unashamedly great film.
In a summer that's seen its fair share of outsized spectacle, everything about X-Files: I Want to Believe is somber, subdued, and in the end rather minor.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to deny how absolutely hilarious Step Brothers really is. You may feel guilty as Hell for laughing at it, but it definitely does earn its cheap and childish giggles
Merchant/Ivory with a fastidious political viewpoint
a slipshod spectacle
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stripped of all its summer swelter and hip hip revisionism, The Wackness is really just another in a long line of quirky indie character studies.
Wonderfully vulgar, brilliantly performed, and accented with action reminiscent of an '80s buddy film, Pineapple Express is one late summer success.
this celebration of a giant leap for mankind is really just a small, insignificant step for film fans.
a satisfying, if slightly syrupy entertainment
Hell Ride comes off as a Devil's Rejects reject.
horrific, and quite honorable
an unapologetically brazen celluloid slur -- that is, of course, if you get what it's going for
This director deals in faces and facts, the camera closing in on his actors so they can deliver their big picture pronouncements while crying on cue.
Vicky Christina Barcelona is really nothing more than rich people bitching. Now where exactly is the fun in that?

Clearly, the powers behind this convenient cash grab can't see the real reason Star Wars remains culturally significant. The Clone Wars is proof that, in some people's minds, it's nothing more than an easily reconfigured revenue stream.
Sadly, The Rocker is so rife with formula that a pre-school could wet nurse on it indefinitely and still never go hungry.
Like big steaming chunks of charred animal flesh, or a fleeting glimpse of a gal's ample cleavage, Death Race taps into something very primal (and very male) about the action movie experience.
[REC] is ridiculously good. It's a show-stopping terror trip through something that really shouldn't work all that well.
Unlike other attempts at bringing these characters to life... the TV cast really captures the inherent insanity of the roles
With its amazing bug footage, and psychobabble scripting, it's The Hellstrom Chronicle (an obvious influence) taken into Twilight Zone territory
The politics of War, Inc. are not problematic so much as pedestrian. There's nothing new in embracing the anti-conservative screed to show how off kilter the country really is.
As it chugs along like a novice marathon runner aware of its inability to win the race, Journey to the Center of the Earth 3D does nothing to dissuade us from its earnest need to entertain.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: only first-trimester zygotes will find this funny
ridiculous and regressive.
The Strangers is a deadly dull experience in boredom, strangled by two cinematic stumbling blocks -- one external and one of its own unfortunate making.
Wistful and a little wonky, playfully recreating a fanciful early '80s UK summer, Son of Rambow definitely feels like someone's personal experiences reinterpreted for public consumption.
If the Shaw Brothers had access to CGI and the post-modern voice talent, Kung Fu Panda would have definitely been part of their stable of wuxia epics.
From the wholly insular and yet perfectly realized fantasy world it creates to the nonstop barrage of ethnic slams, You Don't Mess with the Zohan is a comedy of contradictions..
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Hitting the ground running and never giving up for 90 nasty minutes, Mother of Tears is Dario Argento's final statement on his precedent as the definitive Delacroix of dread.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: one of the worst attempts at end-of-the-world ominousness since the Robot Holocaust battled the Ninja Apocalypse
It has to be said that one of the most "incredible" things about this so-called reinvention of the Hulk is how close it is to Ang Lee's vision.
...if anyone wants to have a serious discussion about the entire supplement situation, this excellent film is a good place to start.
Roman Polanski deserves his badge of dishonor, no question about it. This amazing documentary argues that others need to start sporting one as well.

Like El Topo on even more peyote, or a spaghetti western as directed by Kenneth Anger channeling Federico Fellini, The Legend of God's Gun is an absolute masterpiece of style over surreal and slightly stereotyped
Somewhere, sitting in a room cluttered with Mr. Pibb cans and half-consumed bags of Funyuns is the adolescent writing staff responsible for The Love Guru
Quick -- name three subjects you think would result in a surefire family film hit. If you said The Great Depression, hobo culture, and the social pariah realities of both, you'll love this movie.
Built out of the 'asshole as hero' mode of amusement...The Foot Fist Way is a collection of contradictory ideals gelling effortlessly into a smart, savvy whole.
In a current comedy climate where such scant superficiality just won't cut it, Get Smart is nothing but shallow.
"...if they're not careful, those Marvel superheroes better watch out. Wanted could usurp their position as 2008's best popcorn escape.

In some ways, Standard Operating Procedure is too appalling to appreciate. It's like watching the Nuremberg Trials, Nazis purposefully passing the buck higher and higher up, fully aware that no one above a certain rank is around to take the blame.
WALL*E announces yet another massive leap in technological talent for the fabled filmmakers, a textural, tactile quality that continues to push CG 3D into uncharted artistic arenas.
Hancock is either a brilliant disaster or an often uneven masterwork.
The Children of Huang Shi is so desperate to be the Asian Schindler's List, an example of atrocity draped in abject artistry, that it forgets to lay out the context.
The Doomsday Machine marks a MST3K Season 4 level challenge. At one point, Frank Conniff states exasperatedly that this experience is like 'watching someone else watching Manos: The Hands of Fate'.
This is big screen fantasy as a wish fulfillment free for all, a far out fairytale told in the most intricate of celluloid calligraphy.
Jumper is junk, a halfway decent premise destroyed by some of the worst hiring choices in the history of motion picture personnel.
a Ghoulies for the post-millennial crowd, complete with lots of short attention span flash
for anyone wondering where the well-made, expertly-acted comedy went to, Roscoe Jenkins is a "welcome" return for the cinematic form.
If Feast of Love was indeed a food, it would be a purposeless pan pizza decorated with every topping on the melodrama menu and extra schmaltz inserted into the talky, twice baked crust.
Fact is, The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford should have been better. It should have followed the real focus on the story and done away with at least an hour of subplotting.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Heartbreak Kid ... is a disaster, an unmitigated humorless horror that never once plays as raunchy or as outrageous as it thinks it is.

Though it frequently feels like its missing most of its formative folklore, and trails off into fits of formless meandering about two thirds of the way through, The Seeker is actually a rather good ripping yarn.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Clayton is a lot of things - somber, menacing, heartfelt, and heroic. It tells an intriguing tale in a wonderfully evocative manner. Unfortunately, there is one thing that it's not - and that's great.
Gray really does offer nothing new here. We get the same old statement of blood being thicker than watered-down business associations.

Playing fast and loose with the facts, and generating little big picture meaning, Elizabeth: The Golden Age, stands as a series of individual court intrigues that fail to add up to any great epiphany.

By capturing a sense of society lost, by using both the media focus and the behind closed doors denouements that seem to follow such situations, Affleck produces tragedy on an epic Greek scale and moviemaking of classic neo-noir artistry.
Laced with amazing visual stunts, standout performances, and a perspective of our nation that's nearly incomprehensible, we wind up tramping right along with our wide-eyed hero.
Rendition is the result of such pompous over-pronouncements. It's a well-intentioned screed undone by its desire to make all sides of its conflict saintly simplistic.

As yet another example of a gifted foreign filmmaker...fudging up their reputation by traveling over to Tinsel Town for some Western promise, Things We Lost in the Fire is Lifetime lite cinema masquerading as actual A-list excellence.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is a failed fright flick that is so inspired by Stephen King that the famous horror scribe should consider suing.
While some will feel his previous works better illustrate his gift of film, Lust, Caution creates an unmatched statement of cinematic wisdom all its own.
Like a once in a lifetime trip that only grows grander with the passage of time, The Darjeeling Limited is idiosyncratic filmmaking at its finest.
Avoiding cliche while exploiting the obvious comic possibilities of a man's obsession with a 'anatomically correct' love doll, Lars and the Real Girl is a satiric, sentimental jewel.

If the original Saw was the kernel of a potential terror universe, Saw IV is, by this time, a series of satellites and lesser celestial bodies bound together by some of the best bloodletting in modern macabre.
Maudlin, mawkish, and slightly misunderstood itself, Martian Child is the perfect example of good intentions wrapped in Hollywood-lite logistics.
Though it goes a bit wonky toward the end and seems to travel a very long way to drive home a rather simple point, Wristcutters: A Love Story remains a wonderfully evocative experience.
While never as clever as it thinks it is, and lacking the internal logic that makes a Pixar project hum with indescribable brilliance, Bee Movie is still a witty, imaginative romp.
American Gangster is an oddly one note movie made more or less grandiose by Ridley Scott's insatiable desire to overload the screen with superfluous details.
For all its studied sturm and drang, Lions for Lambs is superficial, piecemeal, and woefully unprepared to argue its points.
The Kingdom is such a strong entertainment, such a substantial 'us vs. them' example of wish fulfillment that it's easy to ignore the many mixed messages.

Constantly upstaging the rest of the cast, and reminding us over and over that we are watching a stogy, old fashioned stage play, Branagh's loopy lens is indeed the best part of Sleuth. Everything else is just plain pointless.
A masterful companion piece to the various supplements surrounding the perfect popcorn hit, it's the smart and insightful sugar coating on three decades of fascinating fish stories.
Perfect for the kids and inviting for adults, Sydney White is a surprisingly effective film that produces nothing but piles of smiles - and Amanda Bynes is the reason why.
As with any last acts, the inevitable clash between mystery solved and said truth's significance offers a sizeable challenge. Here, it creates a compelling and clever espionage thriller.

While the script and direction definitely drag El Cantante down, the portrait of Puchi in this film -- true or false -- places the final perfectly groomed and polished nails in the movie's creative coffin.
Underdog is so piecemeal it should come with a roll of duct tape. It's so desperate to be everything to everyone that it ends up being very little to nobody in particular.
Rush Hour 3 is junk - witless, uncomplicated, consisting of disposable vignettes of vaudeville like burlesque.
There are parts of this film that actually try to fly. The vast majority though is grounded in a level of labored levity that never provides the wings - or the wherewithal - to get airborne.
If you ever wondered what Sixteen Candles...would look and sound like fashioned after the aesthetic mindset of someone like Kevin Smith, Superbad is the answer
The Invasion's conceit is so laidback that it actually takes a while to realize the world is going to Hell.
Even with its occasional faults, Manda Bala does what documentaries do best - illuminate an intellectual or social situation that our otherwise narrow Western viewpoint would never even consider.
A great deal of silent era slapstick has only grown better with age. The exploits of Mr. Bean have vinegared.
Right, you guessed it. It is Enter the Dragon with dorks.
Halloween is brilliant. It's a stroke of slice and dice genius.
Death Sentence is a wonderfully tight little thriller, the kind of statement cinema an up and coming filmmaker needs to establish his overall eagerness to achieve.
3:10 to Yuma has its off moments, and its unexplored potential, but for the vast majority of its running time, this is an excellently made and superbly acted throwback.
(Y)ou gotta love the primal potency of Shoot 'Em Up. It's been a long time since any movie has made such a strong connection to our cave dweller cravings.

With a title that suggests the start of an epic poem or perhaps a fairy tale, The Brave One is a startling achievement for stars Jodie Foster and Terrance Howard, and yet another notch in the growing artistic oeuvre of Neil Jordan.
Mr. Woodcock is not really a crowd pleaser or some kind of 'dumb as dirt' delight. Instead, it's an apparent attempt to reset the demarcation when determining the lowest common denominator.

You have to work so hard at forgetting everything you know about the boys from Liverpool, even as the movie constantly throws their monumental achievements directly at you, that it's frequently not worth the effort
(I)t has to be said that Hatchet's homage to the goofy, gloppy vivisection-fests of two decades before has a strange way of satisfying.

(Poultrygeist is) bloodier, ballsier, and bluerer than anything the company has ever done...the kind of crackpot genre gem that gets its kicks out of wallowing in feces,...exploiting same sexiness, and undermining standard cinematic expectations.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cronenberg isn't out to explore that particular narrative thread. Indeed, many of the standard crime story motifs that have come to define the cinematic category are completely ignored by this wonderful film...
Wearing its holier than thou attitude on its blood-soaked sleeves, In the Valley of Elah is the most underhanded, backdoor anti-war film ever attempted.
The King of Kong is proof that you don't need Earth shattering events of cosmic import to create a compelling film.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes a hoary old cliche can come bubbling back to life if handled in a respectful and direct manner - and this describes P2 perfectly.
Fred Claus is the perfect post-millennial holiday film. It's funny, smart, wicked, warm, and above all, completely clued-in to our growing crass commercialization of Christmas.
Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium is a lighthearted and less noxious Night at the Museum.
nothing more than a series of ADD driven vignettes held together by the flimsiest of plots, helmed by the dude who made 3 Ninjas.
an intriguing if incomplete experience
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As a movie, The Great Debaters misses too many possibilities, and harps on too many ancillary issues, to be stellar. It's solid, but that's all.
...an epic told in incomplete lyric lines, a classic fable forged out of slowly strummed guitar, lilting piano, and strained, struggling voices.
It would take a viewer with the aesthetic skills of an Olympian to overcome the horrendous hurdles placed in entertainment's way by this well-meaning but misguided adaptation of the famed bestseller.
...without a sense of justice, Atonement just doesn't pay its penance. It turns a potentially magnificent movie into something that's merely good.
Juno is a snarky afterschool special for the Pinkberry crowd.
is all facade and no force
an astonishing achievement
Everything here is overly simplified for easy digestion -- dialogue, jokes, characterization, storyline, and payoff
Another lame copy of every crappy sword-and-sorcery epic ever made.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cloverfield is the first great film of 2008.
When you remove the turn of the century pretext, There Will Be Blood is really nothing more than a battle between two ancient religions - Christianity and Capitalism.

Trying to balance the demands of his well-meaning motives with the requirements of the genre leaves Allen unsettled and ineffective, two words that encompass the creative drought evident in Cassandra's Dream.
maudlin and manipulative
In a genre that's already died a thousand mediocre movie deaths, Untraceable is not the last stab into its heart of darkness. Instead, it's the cinematic equivalent of a blueprint...
Just like the actor playing him, our hero no longer looks or acts like his predecessor. Oddly enough, as long as he covers his tracks in the entrails of his enemies, we could really care less.
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly is...a sensational cinematic canvas created by a man who understands the inherent beauty in form, function, and now filmmaking.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: stupendously bad
Meet the Spartans can't even get its fart jokes right. How incredibly sad is that?
in a realm where politics purposely cloud the issue, a little stark reality is a welcome relief.

Witty, wacky, and wildly inappropriate for our Puritan PC times, this story...breezes of effortless engagement, filled with performances so potent they act like double shots of soothing Southern Comfort.
As the perfect marriage of maker and material, this dark, disturbing splatter-etta stands as the best film of 2007.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the awards season's silliest -- and most satisfying -- surprises.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like much of the story of Harlem in the '70s, the truth is the least important part.
This is not Walk the Line, or even Ray. It's more like Lisztomania, and other outrageous biographical freak shows created by that cinematic savant Ken Russell.
Shockingly effective and incomprehensibly great, No Country for Old Men proves that the Coen Brothers are America's reigning motion picture Gods.
Beowulf brays and boasts, it overwhelms and it soars. Like the tendency to exaggerate inherent in its hero, it's a majestic movie that doesn't quite add up to the epic we anticipate.
The Mist is destined to go down as a modern horror classic.
Enchanted is a sugar spun delight. It's as fluffy as a bunch of newborn bunnies and as cute as an entire collection of buttons.
Heavy-handed, undeniably saccharine, and about as magical as a clown at a kid's party, August Rush is an implausible, pus-covered pixie stick.
Hitman overstays its welcome from the moment the ammunition starts flying, and never finds a satisfying way of winning us back.
One of 2007's best 'believe it or not' documentaries.
stinks like a mangy animal's fetid coat
So obvious in its intentions that it screams 'teenager scamming for the car keys', Redacted fails to fully embrace the proposed genius of its premise.
(N)o matter the factual flaws here, Talk to Me generates so much period appropriate juice and evocative energy that you can't help but feel caught up in the events transpiring before your eyes.
Bolstered by cinematic atmosphere so ripe you can practically pick it and eat it, The Orphanage is a deliriously delicious creep out.
Before the Devil Knows You're Dead is kinetic. It's dynamite laced with electricity. It's a perfectly played puzzle that's final images make for an astoundingly satisfying statement.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As a stand alone effort, something styled to entertain us now, The Golden Compass is incomplete.
Walking precariously between real world gravitas and the far too isolated and idiosyncratic, The Savages is a wonderful premise undermined by some unnecessary pretense.
preplanned pandering at its most callous.

Though it proposes to discuss how music made all the difference in Estonia's fight for independence, The Singing Revolution is actually more focused on the behind the scenes wheeling and dealing that helped determine the end of Russian influence.
Busy, overdrawn, and working much too hard to get to its less than impressive point, Margot at the Wedding is entertainment as inference.
Like Short Cuts absent Altman's metaphysical heft, Look is an oddly compelling little film.
I Am Legend is a depressing experience. For everything it gets right, dozens of things go horribly, horribly wrong.
par for the course in a town that sees every old idea as something waiting to be deconstructed, reinvented, or reimagined.
nothing more than a big hunk of bantha podo.
Like a series of subplot ships slowly meandering downstream to a final narrative focal point, Midnight Eagle has to be one of the most languid political thrillers ever conceived.
A dialed down approach to the otherwise apoplectic action film that easily wins over those tired out by the continuing Michael Bay-ing of the genre.
Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho set the standard and post-modern horror has been hobbling to catch up ever since.
a sloppy, subpar slasher flick
In a summer filled with engaging entertainments, this is one of the best.
the same old showbiz story we've heard time and time again, told in a tired, uninspired manner

decent

let's just call this Grumpiest Old Men and get it over with

a dumb, dopey excuse for something that could have been both entertaining and insightful.

dull and perfunctory
a bad idea handled in a hackneyed manner.

a loud, obnoxious mess

greater in sum than as a collection of inconsistent parts

a window into our shared human experience, and a terrific one at that.

another sour note in the continuing symphony which is Eddie's contemporary career irrelevance

Segel is a warm-and-fuzzy presence in everything he's in, and Blunt is delightful. Some bits are funny, some vulgar, some sweet.
Yakin, who wrote and directed the film, keeps things moving with ever-inventive ways to kill and maim.
I wouldn't use it as a study guide for Victorian history, though it would be fun to see the reaction on the teacher's face when the test was graded.
Movies like this are supposed to be ridiculous on some level. It's part of the fun. But, dang.

Lawrence is a tremendous talent, and she is what makes "The Hunger Games" ultimately worth spending time with. She doesn't elevate the film to the heights to which one might have wanted, but she takes it a lot higher than it would have otherwise risen.
It's based on Guy de Maupassant's 1885 novel, but an old-school must-see-TV sitcom has more depth.

I know, when Sandler's not trying he's an easy target, and he's not trying here. But honestly, this is one of those movies you feel stupider just for having sat through. I think I'm already worse at math.
So much more satisfying than the cut-rate romantic comedy that it could have been.
Either they're getting better as they go along, or they're wearing me down.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to tremendous performances from Tommy Lee Jones and Meryl Streep, "Hope Springs" is a charming film.
"The Campaign" is a good idea with no place to go.
"The Queen of Versailles" is funny, sad, infuriating, instructive. It's the American Dream inflated to ridiculous extremes, until it bursts.
Taken on its own terms, "The Bourne Legacy" is a pretty good action thriller.
That Gelber can make Abe appealing in any way is a triumph. That Solondz can orchestrate such a feat is an even bigger one.
It is sweet but tries to avoid sentimentality, at least for as long as it can. And the casting of CJ Adams as the title character goes a long way toward forgiving the lapses.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Truly, this is one animated film that would work just as well as a live-action movie.
Yes, the characters are impossibly beautiful and hip, but beyond that, they seem real.
As "Kumaré" plays out, both Gandhi and the film become something else, something much more thoughtful and moving.
"The Imposter" becomes more than just a missing-persons drama. It hints at something much darker: a real-life horror story, the full truth of which may never be known.

There is nothing in the film that will keep you awake at night. Instead, "The Awakening" works much more subtly, with a profound sense of dread and resignation, a death-obsessed movie given life by Hall's performance.
A somewhat offbeat romance shifts gears and becomes something more menacing and violent.
[Friedkin] has retained his touch ... all these years later. And in Matthew McConaughey, he has the perfect vehicle for madness.
It just sort of hangs around, trying to find its way, fun at times but mostly kind of lost.
If you like music, a good mystery or, better yet, a combination of both, you won't be disappointed.
For those who found "Speed" too thoughtful, there's "Premium Rush," the new king of brainless chase flicks (at least until Razor scooters finances its first feature film).
An exercise in preaching to the choir.
At its core, this is a film about men doing violence to men. And they do plenty of it.
Every day is gloomy in "The Day," Douglas Aarniokoski's film with a creepy, paranoid atmosphere that's more effective than the performances.
"The Possession" isn't exactly "The Exorcist," but Ole Bornedal's film hits enough high notes to make it a worthwhile addition to the exorcism-film heap, somewhere in the lower middle.
Langella ... is tremendous.
Think of all the gags you think might go too far, and then watch as Nørgaard takes them even further.
A lot of talent comes up empty in "Red Lights," a thriller that doesn't thrill.
It's not a masterpiece, but it is a fast-moving thriller, one worth revisiting (and, evidently, remaking).
It's big and it's loud, but ultimately not much more than that.

A charming movie that blends comedy, romance and science fiction -- not necessarily the most obvious combination of genres, but one that director Colin Trevorrow and writer Derek Connolly manage with assured ease.
You have to give the producers of "Otter 501" points for trying something different, even if it's not ultimately all that successful.
"Brave" is either a welcome throwback to old-time animated fairy tales -- albeit one with all the latest high-tech advantages -- or a stalling pattern for Pixar.
I liked "Seeking a Friend for the End of the World," the notes it hit, the questions it asked. And if Scafaria is guilty of playing on emotions, at least she's good at it.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's such a mopey, navel-gazing affair that even Gerwig has a hard time saving it.
The one-note joke plays out longer and better than you might expect, at least for a while. But not forever.
"Headhunters" is an absurd amount of grisly fun, which is a good thing, since, looked at in any great detail, it probably doesn't hold up all that well.
It feels like a journey of self-discovery; Clayman constantly reminds us of how difficult that journey is.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's nice that these people found peace on their motorcycles on top of the world. But for the rest of us, it never really gets off the ground.
Watching Garfield swinging through New York or toying with criminals after he captures them is reason enough to welcome another telling of the tale.
While making such movies as "JFK" and "Natural Born Killers," Stone seemed fearless, both in what he put on screen and how he put it there. A lot of that spirit returns here.
To truly enjoy it, you must be willing to pretend that some of the songs from one of the worst periods of the rock era -- the late 1980s -- are inspirational anthems instead of commercial pabulum.
I'm not sure what I was expecting from "Katy Perry: Part of Me," but I know it wasn't this: a pleasant surprise.
They keep pumping out more "Ice Age" movies, as if it were some sort of "Rocky" for kids or something, and if they never reach the heights of the best animated fare, they chug along efficiently.
It's a sort of slow-boil Russian noir, if that genre exists, and if it doesn't, it does now.
If uncompromising honesty is the quality you seek for a film, Michelle Williams is your go-to star.
It's unlike any film you've seen.
If the film is not quite the achievement "The Dark Knight" was -- and maybe that's the real question -- it's still a fitting end to a very ambitious series.
Te movie seems more like a searing portrait of self-discovery and realization, with the understanding that not everything you learn about yourself will be pleasant.

It means to be an interconnected story, in which one coupling leads to another in increasingly ridiculous fashion, until you're not only no longer interested, you're grinding your teeth, hoping it will end.
Like Young, Demme often takes an iconoclastic route. This is in part a concert film, yes, but not a traditional one.
If you want a descriptive term, "disappointment" should cover it.
What's so remarkable about the happiness the film brings is its simplicity.
For all of Kessler's annoying traits, he did get results. Perhaps a different approach wouldn't have yielded a film as satisfying as "Paul Williams Still Alive."
Even as small movies go, it's tiny, with a budget to match. But it's got a big heart.
Several good performances are left adrift, as the characters roam from scene to scene, singing (quite well) as they go. Even as a sort of long-form music video, it's disjointed.
[An] absorbing and ultimately harrowing look at Ian Curtis' short, unhappy life.
Everything about "Made in Dagenham" is predictable. But thanks to Hawkins and the other women involved, it's entertaining as well.
How much you ultimately like The Rocker will inevitably depend on how much you like Wilson. And a little goes a long way.
Anderson's take is ultraviolent, ridiculously stupid and kind of a rush. If your brain has an 'off' switch, you're well-advised to use it. And the carnage is relentless.
For a film like Hamlet 2 to work -- even the title is hilariously ridiculous -- it has to sell the absurdity completely. It does.
Cheadle is outstanding. That's no surprise; he's a fantastic actor. Here he's given a lot of room in which to navigate.
Frozen River, a story of abject desperation, feels so real and immediate that it plays almost like a documentary.
Elegy is a rare treat: a serious film that, thanks to Kingsley and the rest, doesn't seem to take itself too seriously.

The Women isn't terrible. There's too much talent here for that, even if it's displayed unevenly. But it's something that might be even worse: unnecessary, at least as long as you can rent the original.
A film that deserves to be seen (or seen again).

Mostly we're along for a curious ride. Individual scenes are enjoyable, some laugh-out-loud funny. But it's not a story being told, really, so much as an exercise in ongoing and increasing stupidity on the part of the characters.
Ricky Gervais is a genius.
The truth eventually comes out, as it must, and it's not exactly a stunner.
Ultimately Miracle at St. Anna aims too high, or at least at too many targets. Lee would have been better served to concentrate on one of the many aspects of the story.
There's plenty to offend here. But there's also plenty to enjoy, Rockwell's performance topping that list.

The Lucky Ones takes a decent premise -- three soldiers returning from Iraq facing domestic challenges upon their arrival home -- and crams so much forced drama into it that the movie devolves into a hack buddy picture.
It's too much, too heavy-handed. Disturbing is one thing. Prurient is another.
It comes up a little short of the classic it might have become, but it's still a knowing portrayal of young love lost and found.
In his effort to make a grand statement, Meirelles piles on the drama, as well as the affectations. The resulting effect dilutes the film's power.
Really funny and well-made.
Kinnear captures both the distracted-genius absentmindedness of a man inspired and the crumbling psyche of a man possessed. It's easily Kinnear's best performance in years, maybe ever.
The world of New York magazines is ripe for satire. How to Lose Friends looks at first as if it's going to give us a peek inside that world, but it eventually settles into a rote romantic comedy.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ambition is a great quality in a filmmaker, especially when it's realized. Yet there is something to be said for just telling a story, and with Appaloosa, Harris does a fine job of it.
The Duchess is clearly Knightley's movie, ultimately rising or falling on her performance. She's up to the task, capturing both the charm and grace that made Georgiana so captivating.
It's no surprise that Leonardo DiCaprio and Russell Crowe are so good in Body of Lies, Ridley Scott's thrilling film about the war on terror, its costs and its frustrations.

Stiller, Black and Jackson are all fine. Downey is great -- no surprise. Jay Baruchel, as a newcomer, holds the strained plot threads together, playing the only actor not so narcissistic that he can't see what's going on around him.
Whether by coincidence or intention, City of Ember hits home, leaving you hoping that we'll find our own Doon and Lina to get to the bottom of things before it's too late.
Sure, you'll laugh. It's funny. But your memories soon will be fuzzy, a little out of whack, and the next thing you'll know you'll have eaten an entire bag of Doritos. Or at least wish you had.
By the end of the film, you'll be firmly on the side of each of these kids, hoping the best for them.
It says something generally about the acting when Mariah Carey, playing herself, is as good or better than just about everyone else.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kung Fu Panda isn't the kind of movie that will make you gasp with surprise as it moves toward its believe-in-yourself destination. But it is the kind of movie that will make you enjoy the journey.
Big, loud, messy and most of all fun, The Incredible Hulk offers more evidence that, when done right, the comic-book hero story can indeed be, well, super.
Boasting outrageous laughs and a performance with real heart beneath its dim-bulb exterior, The Foot Fist Way is a ragged delight.

Instead of shocks, we get moments of tension, suspense and violence between stretches of running scared. Nothing wrong with that, except that the stretches are awfully long in places. And in the end, it all comes to not much.
Get Smart is by no means a great movie. Would you believe . . . a good movie? Would you believe . . . a passable couple of hours with a decent laugh thrown in here and there?
Laughs forgive a lot. Just ask Judd Apatow. But when the funniest line in the movie is an outtake from Verne Troyer, you've got problems.

The film, a foreign-language Oscar nominee, is epic in scope, in scale, in story, in everything. It has as much action as any brain-dead Hollywood blockbuster, but Mongol also has heart and intelligence.
