The animation is stunning; the landscapes of the futuristic Earth offer the Pixar folks ample opportunity to show off their wares.
A genuine thrill ride that has the added bonus of being an action movie you don't have to turn your brain off to enjoy.
Although it isn't a particularly deep look at the world of pressures and performance anxieties faced by high-school phenoms, Gunnin' is a welcome treat to anyone who follows the game closely.
There's no shortage of scenes that you'll watch through your fingers, groaning -- but you'll watch all the same.
A ton of potential, but ultimately a mess.
This tale of a little girl's determination and grit during the Depression is an honest-to-goodness family movie, one that parents and children can enjoy equally and together.
Much more than a big-action, small-brain summer movie.
The real star here is the pair of 3-D glasses you're handed when you walk into the theater. With them, Journey is a kick (if not much more).
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever trepidations Ledger may have had about taking on such an iconic role, he blows past them brilliantly, carrying The Dark Knight along with him.
Mamma Mia! is not going to make you think, nor does it want to. But it will make you sing, as long as Brosnan keeps his mouth shut.
It'll keep the kids entertained for a while and give their parents a chuckle or two along the way.
Levine, who wrote the film as well as directed it, re-creates 1994 with the painstaking detail usually reserved for period pieces and costume dramas.
Step Brothers is stupid. Childish. Moronic. Simple. Juvenile. Silly. Just ridiculous. Man, is it funny.
The ingredients are still there for what made people love the series in the first place.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: After years of misfires, Kevin Costner has hit upon a strategy to make himself likable in a movie: by playing someone completely unlikable.
If you're in the market for a veddy British drama and miss seeing Emma Thompson in her natural environment, Brideshead Revisited is a worthwhile two-hour meditation on faith (and the lack thereof).
It's another entertaining look at making films and a reminder that, with many of them, what goes on behind the scenes is the best part.

Nothing wrong with a weeper, as long as it earns its tears honestly. Bees does for the most part, largely through performances that rise above the sometimes too-pat material to convey -- and elicit -- real emotion.
With a powerhouse performance in Rachel Getting Married, Anne Hathaway slams shut the book on princess diaries and such with authority.

The Tale of Despereaux gathers a host of vocal talent for a relatively complicated story of heroism and loyalty, requiring that its young audience pay attention and is all the more rewarding for it (for kids and grown-ups).

How do you critique acting that's willfully bad, a story that's purposefully crazy and dialogue that sets out to be stilted and cliched? You say The Spirit looks great but there's not much else there.
Need a shortcut to manipulate an audience's emotions? Always go with the dog.
Director Bryan Singer keeps the pace fast, and although we know the ultimate outcome, it's easy to get caught up in the excitement of what-if thinking.
A curiosity, you might say.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Winslet is outstanding, particularly given that Hanna is such an unsympathetic character. We never quite feel sympathy toward her, and it's testament to Winslet's skill and confidence that she never really asks us to.
Gran Torino is an unlikely tale made plausible almost solely by the quality of Clint Eastwood's performance.
Unlike the novel, which you can set aside and take a break, with the film version of Revolutionary Road, you're in for the duration, and it's ultimately too much to take.
The Wrestler isn't a perfect movie, but Rourke's performance gives it the impact of an atomic elbow drop.
Plays at times more like a soap opera than what it really is, a story that more of the world deserves to know.
Although younger children will doubtless love it, Hotel for Dogs is too often cute for its own sake to really entertain anyone else.
[Hoffman and Thompson's] talent and experience allow them to make Last Chance Harvey more than it might have been.
Give this to Paul Blart: Mall Cop: It delivers on everything it promises. Which is to say, nearly nothing.
It's ultimately Rourke who makes the film worth watching.

Complex, challenging and at times difficult to watch, Waltz With Bashir is nevertheless wholly unique, unquestionably powerful and, ultimately, a devastating indictment of war and its effects on its victims and its participants.
Inkheart is entertaining enough, if not always easy to follow. And if it does nothing else, at least it may inspire kids to read, if for no other reason than to help make sense of it all.
If Chandni Chowk to China is any indication, a combination of Bollywood and kung-fu movies is something the world needed without even realizing it.
Taken is movie junk food -- fun while it lasts, but not much more. Nothing wrong with that kind of snack every now and then. You just won't want a steady diet of it.
By the end of the film, The Uninvited is genuinely compelling. But despite the scares along the way, the rest of the film doesn't make an especially compelling case for doing the work to get there.
Van Damme is so good, and El Mechri's storytelling so entertaining, that JCVD takes its place alongside The Wrestler as one of the unlikeliest but most welcome comeback vehicles in ages.
Even at this length, there's not enough time to fully service many of the characters.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tales of alternate worlds are always fascinating when done right, and Coraline fits that description.
Martin is such a likable personality it's tempting to say he makes the movie worthwhile. Sorry, that's too tall an order for anyone.
Is Yes Man worth the trouble, then? Not to belabor the point, but yes.
It's only Smith's performance that makes the tears worth crying.
Howard keeps the pace brisk, light when it needs to be, heavy when that's called for. Along with Langella, he turns Frost/Nixon into one of the most entertaining history lessons imaginable.
Doubt, John Patrick Shanley's film adaptation of his acclaimed Pulitzer Prize-winning play, is a showcase for actors -- and it never lets you forget it.
The story, involving conspiracies, doesn't always make sense. And the surprises are easy to predict; director John Moore doesn't try to hide them.
If Judd Apatow revived the raunchy sex comedy with such films as Superbad and Knocked Up, Sean Anders happily advances the genre with Sex Drive.
Whatever you want W. to be, you'll almost certainly be disappointed.
Expertly directed by Mike Leigh, Happy-Go-Lucky is not only joyous but substantial.
There's nothing new about the film, including its basic problem: a cast of talented actors cut off at the knees by stilted, cliched writing.
Zack and Miri ends up as an interesting hybrid: a sweet, feel-good comedy that makes you feel like you need a shower after you've watched it.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gonzo is an excellent reminder that Thompson was more than just a wild man. He was, at least for a time, a first-rate writer who covered his times and helped shape them.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Changeling is a fine-enough movie. It's just that it's aware of the fact, and neither Eastwood nor Jolie ever lets the audience forget it.
RocknRolla, though not the most original movie ever made, is a blast, an adrenaline rush of punked-out rock-and-roll-fueled action and crime.
Although there are some inspired bits, too often the movie takes what worked well in small doses in the original and beats them to death in the sequel.
Soul Men is a raucous send-off for the late Bernie Mac, a gleefully profane take on the road-trip movie that earns its R rating early and often.

From the running time to the plot development for each character, which grows to beating-a-dead-horse lengths in at least a couple of cases, the whole thing would have been better served by holding back a little.
Enjoy Quantum of Solace for what it is: a high-octane, winning installment of the Bond series that hits the ground running and never lets up.
It's a strange trip, to be sure, but a worthwhile one for those willing to take it.

Twilight will doubtless thrill fans of the books, who have long waited for its release. And while it's not a failure, everyone else will wish that the film had, if you'll excuse the expression, a little more bite.
The film is a delight.
The story is somewhat predictable, but it's sweet and happy and the animation is first-rate.
With the combination of Van Sant's direction and Penn's masterful performance, it's moving, and important, as well.

If Luhrmann takes too long to tell the tale, it is at least a tale worth telling, shining a light on racism and mistreatment, folding it neatly into a crowded film that entertains us for most of the way.
John Ajvide Lindqvist's script (from his novel) nails adolescent pain perfectly and is realized by Tomas Alfredson's expert direction.
The music is, of course, great. But the real strength of Cadillac Records is found in the stories behind it.

Although sometimes too self-consciously odd for its own good, the film is at times rollicking good fun, with Alan Rickman having a ball offending everyone within earshot as the brilliant, self-centered Eli Michaelson.
Better to just sit back and enjoy The Day the Earth Stood Still for what it is: a fair amount of fun.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The animation is well done, but the story meanders between kid-pleasing slapstick and more serious good-vs.-evil fare.
Although it's told from the perspective of a child, The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is as shattering as any film about the Holocaust could be, perhaps more so.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull plays heavily on the fondness of the audience for the first three films. Without that, it's basically a better-made version of the National Treasure series.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Take out all the elements of The Big Chill that made you like that film and keep the ones that annoyed you and you've got The Wedding Weekend.
movie_title: Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian offers kids and adults an entertaining escape into the world of C.S. Lewis' books.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bah. Humbug.
Before the Devil Knows You're Dead is often an uncomfortable film to sit through, but the rewards it offers make it well worth the effort.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Redford (who also directed), Tom Cruise and Meryl Streep might just as well have appeared on-screen for a couple of minutes with signs that said, 'War is bad,' and been done with it. Saves everyone the cost of a ticket.
When it belongs to a character played by Bardem, it's a treat, indeed.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Wonder is the key, and it's lacking in a major way. Should you decide to see it anyway, you might wonder what you're doing there.
Harden's performance lifts The Mist above the rank-and-file horror film. It's not a classic, but it is scary, and you'll definitely leave the theater thinking about the ending.
I'm Not There is brilliant, if often brilliantly surreal, filmmaking.
The Golden Compass: controversial statement on free will vs. religious oppression or disjointed, hard-to-follow fantasy-action flick for kids? Let's go with the latter.
Part highbrow British drawing-room drama, part gritty war film, all entertainment almost all the time, Atonement is a masterful study of both the hurtful and redemptive effects of imagination.
It's a fine-enough kids movie. Cute. Nice lesson. And better than you'd think.
I Am Legend is carried for a long while on the strength of Smith's performance, but even he can carry it only so far.
Once [Page] - and her character - move beyond the too-cool-for-school act, Juno becomes something special, and memorable.
Let's not kid anyone here. This franchise is all about dumb fun.
What do you get when you stick a talented, interesting cast in an uninspiring chick flick? Short answer: P.S. I Love You.
When Charlie Wilson's War is on target -- pretty much every time Tom Hanks and Philip Seymour Hoffman appear on-screen together -- it's a really enjoyable movie.
[It] boasts one of the best performances by a child actor, ever.
It's the role of a lifetime for Reilly, who plays Cox from a teenager to an old man (older actors playing kids are a running joke).
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Dismal sets, cartoonish gore and Johnny Depp singing -- what's so appealing about that? Just about everything, actually.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: No surprises, really, just a nice-looking movie with good digital effects and a cute kid.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The quality of the performances is uniformly good.
There Will Be Blood is a masterpiece; Daniel Day-Lewis' performance as a ruthless oilman is without flaw.
The Orphanage (El Orfanato) is the rare horror film that breaks your heart even as it makes it race.
The Bucket List must have seemed like a good idea -- around 1985.
If it's not Toy Story, well, what is? But Bee Movie offers plenty of entertainment for all ages -- though, truth be told, the older the better.

American Gangster shoots for epic stature and misses, but Washington hits the mark from start to finish in one of the year's best performances, the one element that earns the larger-than-life status the rest of the film so desperately seeks.
An exercise in frustration and wasted opportunities.
Sweet, moving and heartfelt aren't necessarily the first words that come to mind when describing the tender tale of a young man and his sex doll, yet all three apply to Lars and the Real Girl.
Every kid believes the world around him is changing in ways it hasn't before; for these kids, it really was. Or had.
Block Party is an uproarious good time, part documentary, part concert film, part who knows what?
It's a lot of fun.
Slither is an enjoyable stab at spoofing the genre, but it won't send you away feeling completely slimed, which in this context is another word for satisfied.

Broken up into four episodes of the television show, who knows, this might be a masterpiece. Seen at one sitting, it falls well short of that. Not for lack of trying. More for trying a little too hard.

One day some enterprising company will probably package Ferrell's sillier comedies together for a boxed DVD set. It has its moments, but Blades of Glory probably won't be the first one of the bunch you watch.
If you stick with it, it's an enjoyable film, a futuristic puzzle with an ending worth the trip for those who make it there.
These films are the equivalent of a low-rent, all-you-can-eat smorgasbord. You get a lot of everything, but somewhere along the line you can make yourself sick.
No matter how much it costs and what its flaws, Spider-Man 3 still gets a lot of bang for the buck.
If there's a saving grace, and there is, it's that the movie strives, in its often-awkward way, for acceptance. And how bad can that be?
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What is required is a sense of humor. Bring that to the theater with you and you won't be disappointed.
The film offers plenty of kid-level humor (as well as a few references adults will pick up on), a decent story and, as you might guess, a positive message.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you're going to remake a movie a third time, you'd better have a compelling reason.

Amid the laughs, the one thing Closing Escrow proves is this: It's a lot more fun watching other people trying to buy or sell a house than going through it yourself, particularly if Realtors like the ones here are involved.

All of the acting is first-rate, but Thompson is fantastic. He makes Hal both sympathetic and hilarious, never giving in to self-pity but, in a refreshing take, not above the occasional scream (or cheer).
Death Sentence most certainly is not a good movie.
Self Medicated is that rare treat: a really good movie and, one hopes for Lapica, the start of something even bigger.
An ugly, manipulative mess.
In the Valley of Elah rises and falls on the strength of Tommy Lee Jones' performance, which is to say that it rises to great heights, indeed.

though it's easy to dismiss McCandless' hippified musings and near-suicidal choices as the misguided actions of a kid who read Walden a little too closely in college, Penn's film aims for something more, a deeper telling of a tale of yearning and escape.
Wonderful, hilarious documentary.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Phoenix is unquestionably the star of the film. His journey is particularly angst-ridden, and he shows it every step of the way.
Smart and exciting, Michael Clayton takes the audience on a ride whose pleasures almost sneak up on you and are all the more satisfying because of it.
This is a full-on, non-stop horror film. You're either on the bus or off the bus. But if you are on, you're hanging on with both hands and your hair flying back for the better part of the movie.

It sounds like the ultimate chick flick with crossover potential -- Scarlett Johansson learning a lot about life and a little about love in a film based on a cornerstone of chick lit -- but not even chicks will get much out of The Nanny Diaries.
While there is plenty of gore and gratuitous sex, the movie acknowledges the ridiculousness of it all, trusting that the audience -- one hopes -- is in on the joke.
A twitchy thrill ride that's relentless in its escalation of tension, merciless in its intensity.
It's all in service to a workaday script that leads to a cop-out of an ending that makes the whole thing seem even more generic than it should.
The Hammer isn't going to sneak past Raging Bull in the boxing-movie pantheon (or even Rocky, for that matter). But like its star, it is an underdog you can root for.
Taxi to the Dark Side is a stunning indictment of torture as policy, a brilliant documentary whose arguments are so well-supported and reasonably made that you can't ignore them.
Blindsight is hugely affecting, the rare experience that will make those who watch it thankful for what they have, yet make them realize that they aren't nearly thankful enough.

Despite sharing a producer in comedy-genius-of-the-moment Judd Apatow, a co-writer in Seth Rogen and somewhat similar territory, Drillbit Taylor doesn't measure up to the raunchy classic that gave the world McLovin.
Meet the Browns, the latest Tyler Perry film, has a good heart. But it's a mess of a movie.

It may be the kind of film that will make you smile more than laugh, but you'll smile a lot. And although it practically forces you to root for its hero, you won't mind a bit because the hero is played by Simon Pegg.
Stop-Loss goes in too many directions at once, and most of those directions are predictable.
It's the equivalent of a busted play, with the players scrambling in different directions, making any kind of forward progress nearly impossible.
Yes, it's painful, but Snow Angels is so full of rich performances and characterizations that even gunshots can't kill its power.
Nim's Island is an old-fashioned kids' movie. Parents might find flaws, but the 12-and-younger set will find characters and a movie worth rooting for.
Although the film is expertly made it offers almost nothing new for fans of the Stones, or of Scorsese.
James Ellroy wrote the script; he also wrote the novel on which L.A. Confidential was based. If you're hoping for a similar intelligence, you're out of luck.
First-time director Noam Murro successfully creates a world you want to spend time in, even if it's a world marred by self-absorption and missed opportunities.
By the time the film moves toward its conclusion and the gross-out factor really starts to rise, any semblance of even an exploitation story has fallen away like so many lopped-off limbs.

Forgetting Sarah Marshall is a hilarious movie, a brilliant deconstruction of the romantic comedy, a film that, assuming you have the appropriate sense of humor, will make you laugh out loud again and again.

The humor outweighs the holes in the story, Fey and Poehler look to be a comedy team built to last -- let's hope so -- and those who find Judd Apatow's comedies lacking in decent female roles have found their film.
Deception is kind of like the Oscars. Both plod lamely at the beginning, milking inane dialogue, before trying to squeeze far too much into the last little bit.

How you feel about Made of Honor depends on how you feel about Dempsey. If you like Grey's Dr. McDreamy, you'll like Tom and the movie. If not? There are plenty of other nondescript romantic comedies out there from which to choose.
The movie rises and falls on the strength of Downey, and it rises pretty high.
Ultimately, Speed Racer comes down to the lesson your parents taught you: Despite the flash, looks aren't everything.
All part of growing up, an experience Son of Rambow portrays with genuine insight.
Before it sort of punches itself out in the final few minutes, it's a surprisingly compelling story about honor and betrayal.
What Happens in Vegas . . . should have stayed in Vegas. Or in New York, where most of this predictable, uninspired film takes place. Or in Hollywood, where such lamebrained ideas are hatched.
An enjoyable story of hope and resilience, buoyed by the performances of Kate del Castillo as Rosario, the mom, and Adrian Alonso as Carlitos, her son.
Relentlessly downbeat, with a glimmer of a payoff in the last couple of scenes, Sleepwalking is a film that has 'indie' written all over it -- for better and for worse.
The funny bits are kind of funny. But the dramatic developments, in particular the one that drives the bulk of the story, are far less successful.
It's not a fun ride, but Funny Games forces us -- almost against our will -- to examine its characterization of violence and our response to it.
Persepolis may be a crudely drawn, two-dimensional cartoon, but it packs more genuine emotion than plenty of live-action dramas.
The experience of seeing a concert movie, no matter how technically remarkable, will never replace the experience of being at the show. But U2 3D comes awfully close.
There's a good movie to be made about the power of the virtual mob, the ethical consequences of participating in it, the costs of free will. But Untraceable isn't it, not by a long shot.
It's confusing. Rambo makes you root for the wrong things.
The line is fine between cute and annoying.
Some movies are critic-proof -- some for the wrong reasons, some for the right ones. This one falls into the latter camp.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Roscoe Jenkins works best when it aims lowest.
It's Langella's performance that anchors the film.
Definitely, Maybe is definitely a cut above your standard-issue genre fare, maybe way above.
Jumper strains credulity, even for a fantasy-action film; its lead character isn't particularly likable; and Samuel L. Jackson sports funny hair.
The Spiderwick Chronicles, while not without its virtues (including a genuinely sweet ending), goes too far on the frightening front, especially for a young audience.
If you must see only one film about a family's downward spiral into despair, it probably should be Before the Devil Knows You're Dead, not Cassandra's Dream.
The dialogue is front and center, in spite of the picturesque setting and all the goings-on, and it's the best thing about the film.
Perhaps Gondry realized the sum wasn't going to be greater than its parts and just left it at this: two halves, one more intriguing than the other, that don't add up to a coherent whole.
The problem with Vantage Point, or at least one problem, is that it depends too much on coincidence. The film relies on things breaking a certain way for nearly every plot advancement.
It overdoes the quirkiness and underdoes the character development, but, in the end, it's salvaged by a remarkable performance by Robert Downey Jr., who hardly ever gives any other kind.
Will Ferrell's latest comedy splits time between being a goofy basketball movie and . . . a whole bunch of other stuff, none of it particularly interesting.

City of Men is outstanding in its own right, a moving story of the bleak lives of those living in the favelas, or slums, slaves to the drug-gang violence there, so immune to the constant danger that it simply becomes part of their lives.
It probably shouldn't be the way in which high-school kids learn about Henry VIII and his court, but it's a fun movie.
There is an underlying sweetness to Penelope, a root-for-her vibe that's only slightly diluted by the predictable story.
In Bonneville, a talented cast is wasted, falling victim to a tired, cliche-ridden story.
It gets right the twists, the humor, the tension, the sexiness and, yes, the violence of a really fun, taut British thriller.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day isn't going to change your life. But it will make it a lot more enjoyable for a couple of hours.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although the voice talent is good and the animation amazing, Horton Hears a Who! has never needed more than Geisel's simple words and drawings to get its points across, brilliantly.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Diary of the Dead works much better as a horror film than as social commentary. Which is no shortcoming - a good scare is a good scare, no matter what the medium in which it's delivered.
The film is quiet, patient, allowing for lived-in performances that get at the enormous change in the characters' lives.
The pace is fast and the action, particularly a mind-boggling shoot-'em-up in the Guggenheim Museum, furious enough. But the less-conventional elements are in many ways even more effective.
The problem with Fired Up is that it doesn't follow a simple rule of the genre: If you're going to make a raunchy teen sex comedy, go all the way.
Just Wright is probably best thought of as a fairy tale, from start to finish. It's just not a very good one.
An hour-and-a-half mopefest so complete that by the end of it, you want to give Hutton's character a smack in the face and tell him to stop whining, already.
Shrek the Third made more than $322 million. Why kill the goose that laid the golden egg? Because it's time.
Abramoff documentary is appalling, entertaining
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Honestly, by the time they ride camels, it's Ishtar in designer gowns.

It's meant to be fun, not work, but the plot is so loosely constructed it takes a lot of effort to piece things together. Better just to wait for Jake to mow down more bad guys and hit reset. Or, ahem, wait till the end.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's simply the tale of a man who decides to do something and sticks to his guns, so to speak. That the man is played by Michael Caine is what makes it worthwhile.

Greek doesn't quite know when to stop, and things aren't brought to a particularly satisfying resolution. But Brand does a nice job adding a few dramatic shadings to his character, a pleasant surprise. And Hill is outstanding.
Morphing as often as the character central to its story, Splice is an unruly mix of science, morality, family dysfunction, horror and finger-down-the-throat gross-out ridiculousness.

Kroot's film, with assists from interview subjects like John Waters, Buck Henry, Wayne Wang, Guy Maddin and Atom Egoyan, makes a compelling case not so much for the Kuchars' movies, exactly, as for their independent spirit.
Please Give is an almost perfectly rendered slice of life, buoyant with wonderful performances.
If Garcia's film never quite catches up with his ambitions for it, well, at least he's trying.
Karate Kid is a perfectly fine movie. Just an unnecessary one.
It's temping to say that you're better off not thinking about the plot and how tenuously it all holds together. The truth is, you're better off not thinking at all.
Toy Story 3 is very much a worthy entry in the series, a movie well worth making (and seeing). It continues the legacy. It just doesn't expand upon it.
Take the intriguing premise of a punk-rock Western based on a graphic novel, populate it with a good cast, add striking visuals and you come up with...a real mess.

Mangold, working from a script by Patrick O'Neill, accelerates events in a way that is either a perfect representation of how current action films are made or a demonstration of everything that's wrong with movies today. Maybe it's both.
A perverse delight, the rare film that makes you feel good about feeling bad (or at least watching others do so).
There is a message here of the necessity for tolerance, but 8: The Mormon Proposition would have been better had its makers presented it in a more consistent, artful fashion.
It's like The Big Chill made by morons.
A compulsively watchable look at Rivers, show business and the price one pays to try to continue succeeding in it.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What elevates Eclipse above the previous Twilight films is that it doesn't take itself so seriously, and Slade doesn't allow his stars to.
While the special effects are impressive enough, M. Night Shyamalan's film doesn't make a lick of sense.
It's a little too obvious and ham-handed in places to be a really good movie, but any film that lasts two hours and 20 minutes without seeming like a long, hard slog can't be all bad.
Although Hill certainly has been good in previous roles, this goes beyond what we've seen.
Equal parts travelogue and big-budget home movie, Babies is an intriguing look at the universal nature of life, albeit a longer look than it needed to be.
Bigger, louder and dumber than its predecessor, Iron Man 2 is still a lot of fun.
Brosnan, long past his James Bond days, has ripened as an actor; he's outstanding.
In the big picture, the government is the bad guy. In the moment, however, the school principal with a blood-drenched pitchfork will do quite nicely, thank you.

It's an inconsistent film, put together somewhat haphazardly, but Keenan is such a compelling presence - smart, polite, creative and seemingly so full of bottled-up rage he might tear someone's head off at any second - that it's a journey well worth follo

Carroll purists and freshman English majors may be aghast at the change in story, but for those who watched Avatar and marveled at the images but were left wanting by the wooden acting and tired story, Alice is a treat.
It's certainly interesting to see what's been reported on the manipulation of information played out as drama, and the acting is uniformly good.
What elevates She's Out of My League -- it doesn't turn a 5 into a 10, but it helps -- is heart, of which its characters have a surprising plenty.
The Runaways broke new ground. And if The Runaways doesn't, it's still a movie worth watching -- and listening to.
It's an intriguing premise, one director Miguel Sapochnik treats with all the subtlety of a head smashed in with a typewriter. Hey wait -- that happens!
Directors Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders, working from a script based on Cressida Cowell's books, should be credited for the way they develop the friendship between Hiccup and Toothless.
A movie much different from what its title would suggest, which is kind of a shame, because the title is so super-awesome.
The story is the problem here, devolving into a ridiculous situation that produces far more groans than chills or thrills.
Stiller is expert at playing self-indulgent types unaware of their boorishness, and Greenberg is no exception.

So tone deaf to the material is Leterrier that the spirit of the remake owes more to Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen than a sword-and-sandal film. Bigger, louder, more expensive? All that, for sure. But better? Not by a long shot.
There is some funny stuff here, particularly the asides between Carell and Fey, who have a comfortable chemistry. You can certainly believe that they're a harried married couple.
Terribly Happy must surely be the greatest Danish Western ever made.
Best of all is Neeson, who is nicely creepy. Whether he's genuinely gifted or knuckle-chewing insane, he's not the kind of guy you'd want to spend time with, either way.

While not all of the elements fit together tonally, on the surface level -- the level that the title suggests -- Kick-Ass does exactly what it's supposed to, as long as you're game for the language and the gutting.
There's a nicely cynical streak at the heart of The Joneses, until Borte goes soft and lets the audience off the hook.
A funny, heartfelt look at families, relationships and the lies that prop them up as much as tear them down.
They're treading woefully familiar ground with The Back-Up Plan, a movie that could have used one.
The Losers does a perfectly serviceable job of achieving its low ambitions.
Moeller is not heavy-handed in drawing conclusions; he leaves this largely to the audience.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A stupid, mean-spirited little movie that ranks down there with the worst in recent memory. Distant memory, too.
Although Doors fans will drool over the prospect of the previously unseen footage, they are unlikely to find anything new here.
Neither as rich in story nor stunning in animation as Pixar offerings, Despicable Me instead settles for simply being goofy good fun, and it hardly seems like settling at all.
Predators is a pretty good action movie for about 45 minutes. Unfortunately, it lasts 106.
Funny, that despite non-stop special effects, sorcery and such, The Sorcerer's Apprentice can't quite overcome the key ingredient it lacks: magic.
Although he doesn't look much like Lennon, Johnson captures that essence perfectly; the future icon is here a confused, hurt boy.
If you're of a mind that actors as talented as Robert De Niro and Edward Norton could make even pedestrian material watchable, Stone puts your theory to the test. And surprise! They can.

It isn't a film fixated on death so much as what comes after and how that affects the living, the type of subject typically treated in films as a theoretical conceit, but one that Eastwood pursues with his trademark straightforward style.
The acting certainly elevates the movie -- Minnie Driver, Juliette Lewis and Melissa Leo are also quite good -- but Conviction remains a good movie that should have been better.
What's unusual about these movies is that we know those scares are coming, and the filmmakers' drawn-out approach makes them even more effective when they finally arrive.
f you've been affected by the bottom dropping out of the economy -- who hasn't? -- but didn't know where to target your disappointment, your frustration, your rage, Inside Job gives you the answer:
The film comes off as one long litany of lament and tragedy that never fits together.
Due Date should be a disaster, derivative of every road-trip movie you've ever seen. What prevents that are the efforts of the two stars.
This is Ferrell's movie, meaning some inspired laughs sandwiched between annoying bits that stretch on well past their usefulness.
It's a slight movie that makes Broadcast News look like All the President's Men in comparison.
Unstoppable is a movie in a hurry, quickly building a momentum that befits its title and never letting up till the end.
Terrific acting by James Gandolfini and Melissa Leo -- and a noble effort from Kristen Stewart -- goes a long way toward salvaging it.
It's not a bad movie, but it is very much a transitional one, with Warner Bros. splitting J.K. Rowling's last installment in the "Potter" series into two films.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Gyllenhaal and Hathaway, who played a couple in "Brokeback Mountain," have a natural, likable chemistry. At least when it's allowed to shine.
There is nothing subtle about "Faster," and that's the best thing about it.
I's not interesting enough to be a disaster.
Yael Hersonski's documentary is infuriating, heartbreaking, devastating -- and scary. It depicts a lie upon a lie.
Star power can cover up a multitude of shortcomings in a film. Turns out stupidity isn't one of them.
Taken in the too-much-is-never-enough vein, "Black Swan" is a fantastic experience...

"The Fighter" easily could have slipped into boxing-film clichés, but Russell doesn't let that happen. Instead, it lands its hardest blows while chronicling the struggle of a family, which is a far more interesting fight.

Perhaps this is an old-fashioned notion, but if you're going to see a movie that admittedly features lots of digital bells and whistles as its major draw, shouldn't you still be able to tell what's going on?
True Grit is a gorgeously shot, well-acted Western that resonates more the more you let it settle.
OK, sure, "The King's Speech" obviously is feel-good Oscar bait, but who cares? It's also a terrific movie with two fantastic performances at its heart.
Red isn't a great movie, but it's great fun, and if that sounds like damning with faint praise, you take things too seriously.
Secretariat is a traditional, by-the-numbers feel-good movie that's likely to leave you cheering in the end anyway, even though you know what's coming.

This is a really good movie, good enough that whether it needed to be made is beside the point. If you've seen the original, you'll be happy with the results. If you haven't, then just sit back and enjoy.
With The Social Network, director David Fincher has come up with a movie that, in telling the turbulent story of whiz-kid Mark Zuckerberg's creation of Facebook, isn't just compelling. It's great.
Inception is either a great, mind-bending movie or one big swindle. Let's go with the former.
Honestly, if this is the best the CIA, the Secret Service, the NYPD and whatever other government agency tasked with finding bad guys can do, we're in worse trouble than we thought.
Mostly it's just Ramona making a mess of things, without the consequences of cleaning up afterward.
Winter's Bone is a genuine triumph, a great movie with astounding performances so natural, so genuine, that you forget it's a movie.
Steve Carell is the best comic actor working today.
It's all rather silly and somewhat sweet.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The reaction of a soldier to the death of another - unvarnished, disbelieving grief so raw it's difficult to watch - is among the most moving footage of war and its cost imaginable.
A documentary that delves into what happens when the ghost stories you told as kids, the stuff of urban legends, seem to come true.
Winnebago Man is an intriguing look at the effects on one man's life; whether they're worth the cost is something Steinbauer leaves up to us.
Sure, it's fun, after a fashion, to see them all in the same place, kicking and creaking. But that's about all it is.
Wright keeps the cast and the film rigidly in line for such a wild ride, and it works.
A movie that makes little sense, is dumb when it's not being stupid and yet is still at times laugh-out-loud funny.
Thompson, unrecognizable for most of the movie, is impressively dour, a sort of Mary Poppins gone to seed.
A documentary so enthusiastic, good-natured and sweet about such an abject disaster that it almost makes Troll 2 worthwhile.
It's difficult to find an ending for horror movies. Often the getting there is the fun. That's especially true here.
With Clooney it's an interesting project. Without him, it would simply be boring.
When Machete yields a weed-whacker as a weapon, there is a subtle beauty to it.
The naturalistic style Michod employs adds to the sense of dread. Is there no way out of this existence? To whom would it appeal?

Watching the film, emotions range from sadness, of course, to frustration to outright anger. This, truly, is the best we can do? Throwing up roadblocks in front of the truth, not trusting the American people to understand the nature of war...
It's a measured, strong performance, certainly one of Affleck's best. Perhaps he can credit his director.
Stone is a great technical director, and he uses his skill to excellent effect here. He loads the screen with information - montages of cable-news reports, stock listings, more, more, more.
There are no surprises here, just a by-the-numbers comedy that's better, and funnier, than it has a right to be, thanks to the efforts of the actors in it.
It seems too much at first, but Fackler's up to something.
It is affecting, surprising, heartbreaking (though not, despite the marketing campaign that would lead you to believe otherwise, scary).
There are a couple of good performances and a few funny bits, but mostly the film just bounces back and forth until coming to a flat, trite close.

It may not have any of the technological bells and whistles of the latest 3-D offerings, but no movie in recent memory immerses the audience so deeply in its look and feel as the old-fashioned, two-dimensional Shutter Island.
Percy Jackson isn't a great movie, but it's a good one, trotting out kernels of Greek mythology like so many Disney Channel references.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Wolfman ends up a disappointment, then, somewhat interesting in places, but nothing to howl about.
It's so funny it might convince you that sometimes the raunchy journey is worth the laugh-out-loud reward.
Egoyan's pacing is careful, deliberate, as it must be, because he's pulling together a complex tale, playing with time to reveal details piece by piece.
There's fun to be had in Pelham, at least for a while, but nothing more than that.
Jessica Biel gets more publicity for her body and her boyfriend than for her acting ability, but Easy Virtue may be cause for a reassessment.
The original version of The Taking of Pelham One Two Three was made 35 years ago, yet it retains a quality of cool that will remain long after people have forgotten the current version.
movie_title: The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (1974)

movie_review_blurb: So we've got a prodigal son who has the chance to deal with his father issues and discover things about his heretofore evil boss. It's like a romantic-comedy cliché twofer.
There are enormous battle sequences -- you can practically see the dollar signs -- but little effort at telling a story.
Public Enemies is a good movie -- sometimes very good -- that could have been a great one.
The animation is first-rate, and the first look at the lost world beneath the ice is stunning, particularly in 3-D.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Cheri is a serviceable period piece, but not much more.
Moon is first-rate science fiction, tackling such issues as identity, individuality and the effects of isolation on the psyche and the soul.
If Bruno is not quite up to the lofty standards of Borat, it is daring and sometimes insightful.

Half-Blood Prince is plenty good in its own right as a stand-alone piece of entertainment. But it also serves the series well, delivering on perhaps its most-important requirement: It makes you really want to see the next one.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bigelow's direction is confident -- the action sequences are tense and suspenseful, so much so that The Hurt Locker also works as a straight-up war film.
The winning nature of the performances outweighs Takita's more obvious choices.
Keaton builds the tension nicely. Payoffs aren't as important to him as establishing a mood, a tone (mostly bleak). Patient, at times to a fault, he allows the characters to build over time.
The Ugly Truth? That's half right.
Orphan works because it's a film that knows exactly what it wants to be -- creepy as all get out -- and does everything possible to achieve that goal.
What's good about Funny People is really good, and that starts with Sandler, who's outstanding.
It's probably best to think of the film as an extended music video, a watershed moment for movie sound tracks, and not much more.
Although the calories ultimately are empty, they sure are enjoyable.

It's an unconscionable waste of talent, an immediate embarrassment for Jeremy Piven, Ving Rhames, David Koechner, Ed Helms and Tony Hale. Who knows how much they got paid, but if it wasn't a lot, they were robbed.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tarantino crams enough movie-loving passion into the film to keep you not just entertained but occasionally riveted. Above all else, it's a really enjoyable ride.

Many of the bits are far too adult for children, yet no adult with a brain bigger than a walnut -- inside joke the filmmakers evidently thought was hilarious -- would find the story the least bit compelling.
Going gloriously over the top, Raimi simply aims to make us laugh and scare the pants off us, and he hits the mark on both fronts.

Through its writing, direction and execution, Up doesn't just achieve hipness, it transcends it. With its spirit of fun and adventure, it echoes Raiders of the Lost Ark (only funnier) -- it's a thrill ride, but a thrill ride with heart.

Rian Johnson's direction is as self-conscious as his script, but, helped by winning performances from Adrien Brody, Mark Ruffalo and Rachel Weisz, it comes off as clever, even if the writing seems strained at times.
Although the movie isn't without merit, it's all Jay, all the time, and that gets a little old.
Perry brings his own sensibility to every movie he makes and has enjoyed great success by following his own path. But he leaves you wanting more.
Deliberately paced -- slow, even -- it's nevertheless an amazing, timely parable for increasingly desperate times.
A (mostly) faithful re-creation of the comic. But it could have been so much more.
What elevates Two Lovers beyond the mundane is the strength of the performances.
Someone somewhere will probably try to foist The Last House on the Left remake off as some sort of social commentary. Don't be fooled. It's not.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a pleasant-enough diversion. Who knows, maybe the sequel will improve on this. Because from the looks of things at the end, there's bound to be one.
It's all very creepy, satisfyingly so.
It's just a well-made, ribald comedy by people who are really good at this kind of thing.
It eventually falls victim to one or two twists too many, needlessly complicating an already complex plot.
These are people whose company you enjoy, in good times and bad. Taking place over a short period of time, it's a small slice of life, yes. But as the title implies, it's a tasty one as well.
It's pleasant enough, which is an OK description for a summer afternoon, but not for a movie. At least not one with ambition beyond the standard fare.
Don't overthink Monsters vs. Aliens. Just enjoy it.
A worthy effort, several cuts above the teen comedies that came out of the era it depicts while managing to capture it thoroughly.
You have to respect Hill's willingness to continually go to any length without so much as a flinch to get a laugh. But that doesn't mean you'll continually enjoy it.
You don't eat a Twinkie to lose weight, and you don't see this film to challenge yourself emotionally or intellectually.
State of Play, based on the outstanding British television series, is a first-rate political thriller, but it's also something more.

Wright has Jamie Foxx and Robert Downey Jr., both outstanding. Their performances make up for the meandering plot and occasional missteps; neither actor is ever anything less than compelling, giving The Soloist an emotional heft it might not have enjoyed.

While packed with effects and action, without the attention to story and emotional investment present in such films as The Dark Knight and Ironman, Wolverine ultimately doesn't rise above its comic-book roots.
A new creation, one that serves as a self-contained film and a launching pad for a continuation of the franchise, one that should live long and prosper.

The film starts out as an empowerment story, gravitates toward romantic drama, has bits of lame comedy, and, of course, there's the dancing. Something for everyone, presumably, just none of it very good.
Credit where it's due: Director Ron Howard, also back from Da Vinci, keeps things moving fast enough -- the clock is ticking, after all -- that you don't linger over the implausibility of the story.
Director McG proves perfectly adept at blowing things up in interesting ways, but there's not so much acting here as there is yelling at different volumes.
It's not a bad movie. Just an unnecessary one.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There are good performances here, but the sheer number dilutes their power, leaving the movie a bit of a mess.
Part shopping fantasy, part cautionary debt tale and all chick flick, Confessions of a Shopaholic is like Sex and the City with a lower IQ.
It is Woodstock light, which is one thing. It is also Ang Lee light, which is another thing altogether and far less satisfying.
It's too scary for small kids and, frankly, too dreary for everyone else. The most intriguing question it asks is what Acker will do next.
If only Cameron, who also wrote the script, had spent as much time on the story as he did the effects he uses to tell it.
Whatever limited charms the first version had -- mostly David Cross' portrayal of Ian, the greedy manager who exploits the furry creatures -- have since soured.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Jeff Bridges' portrayal of broken-down, liquored-up country singer Bad Blake may be the best of his career, and that's saying something.
One of the year's more satisfying films.
There's a lot of high-powered star wattage in Nine, but it never generates much heat.
It's Complicated is basically Wild Hogs for smart people, big stars playing below their gifts in a crowd-pleasing movie.
Playing literature's greatest detective as a sort of self-loathing action hero, Downey has an absolute blast. And thanks to his performance in Sherlock Holmes, so do we.

Doubleday's Sheeni is charming, smart and pretty and has just that hint of knowing danger that drives teenage boys insane. And Cera? No one does this kind of thing better, which is presumably why he keeps doing it.
If you're game, Parnassus is a richly rewarding experience. If not, it comes off like pretentious nonsense.
Daybreakers isn't a great film, but it's a good one, and in a market oddly lousy with vampire tales, it's an original.
Lovely woman, Amy Adams, just a delightful on-screen presence, and a fine actress, as well. What's she doing in this?

You'd think that getting Allen, Sigourney Weaver, J.K. Simmons, Kelsey Grammer, Jeanne Tripplehorn and Ray Liotta together for a comedy would be at the least intriguing, but as it turns out, not so much.
It's a competently made movie -- in Jackson's hands it could hardly be anything but -- yet rarely a moving one.
Truly, if one must wander a barren, post-apocalyptic landscape with somebody, who better to wander with than Denzel Washington?
The road to mediocrity is paved with good intentions.
Tooth Fairy is a strictly by-the-numbers affair, except when Merchant is clowning around. He doesn't make you enjoy the film so much as he makes you wish he acted more. Guess that's something.
This is psychotic behavior as performance art, and Hardy makes it irresistible.
The film depends on Gibson's performance, and he comes through.
Of course, von Trier wants us to react, to be repulsed, shocked, offended. Mission accomplished.
Morel unwisely switches to a more-serious tone midway through the movie, in a misguided attempt to make it appear to be weightier than it is.
Awash in mawkish sentimentality, Dear John still will move you deeply - if you're a 12-year-old girl.
Marshall, working from a script by Katherine Fugate, probably would have done better to pare some of the elements to concentrate more fully on... something. His golf game, maybe.
There is a predictability to the story, but that's OK. The acting is superb, Holbrook in particular, making That Evening Sun an understated pleasure.
If the joke is somewhat one-note and eventually told too long and too often, at least it's a good joke.

Eastwood too often veers into trite territory, undercutting some of the story's power. An unlikely World Cup run may be a soothing balm on a nation's wounds, but it's not a cure-all, no matter how inspiring it may be.
Everybody's Fine is a fitting title. The movie may well be fine. But it could have been a lot better.
Brothers is a powerful statement on loyalty, love and the cost of war.

While Fox's performance as a high-school girl possessed by a demon would seem key to the fortunes of the film, Amanda Seyfried, as her unlikely best friend, Needy, makes it more interesting than it would be.
The Informant! is a hoot, an ever-escalating tale of corporate crime, greed and out-and-out craziness.

Bright Star shines brightly indeed, not only on the strength of a couple of powerhouse performances, but also as a look back at a time when poets were rock stars, with all the skinny British attitude that implies.
Capitalism may be flawed, but it is nevertheless entertaining. Which counts for a lot.
Lying is good, but it could have been great. And that's no lie.

Zombieland skimps on nothing. That includes graphic violence, naturally. But just because you don't need a lot more brain power than the zombies employ to enjoy it doesn't mean you won't enjoy it plenty.
Couples Retreat plays like the NBA All-Star game: What seems like a dream-team exhibition of pros at the top of their game too often turns into an undisciplined mess.
If The Boys Are Back takes some emotional shortcuts, it still manages to convey some of the more mystifying aspects of parenthood.
There is some real magic here. But there is also the feeling that something's missing, that Max's journey isn't quite complete; the dour mood of the monsters doesn't help.
It's fantastic stuff, so over-the-top, so scabrous, so bitterly brilliant that you have to assume that, on some level, it rings true.
As a social statement, Law Abiding Citizen is a flawed attempt at holding the legal system accountable for its shortcomings. As a movie, it's a ridiculous execution of a misguided concept.
A curious combination of workplace comedy and midlife crisis, it's not as good as [Judge's] best work -- the characters are too one-dimensional -- but the laughs are generous and genuine.
Tenma wisely powers the boy's heart with positive energy, something that spreads to the movie as well.
Any evidence of eccentricity, scandal or anything else that marked our perception of Jackson the last few years is missing. In its place is a performer in full command of his gifts.
An Education is just what the title promises, and a delight, as well.
For a movie that searches constantly for a consistent feel, sometimes within the same scene, The Men Who Stare at Goats is remarkably entertaining.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pirate Radio is a great soundtrack in search of a movie. It never really finds one.
It's the end of the world as we know it, and I feel...like I have a headache.
It's too long, it's poorly acted, the story's clunky and the dialogue is laughable.
Director Walt Becker's film goes for humor and heart, achieving neither.
The Messenger delivers what it has to say without sensationalism or political posturing. That restraint, along with the quality of the performances, makes it all the more powerful.
Fantastic Mr. Fox may be the perfect kids movie for grown-ups.
The Road can be a tough slog, but the journey is a rewarding one.
Nicolas Cage is so gleefully over-the-top as the troubled cop of the title that you will either be repulsed or fascinated by his performance and, since it lives or dies by it, the movie itself.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: We are used to seeing Tautou play the sweetheart. Here, she's anything but. Constantly smoking, dour, unsmiling, critical, she plays a character difficult to warm to but fascinating to watch.
At least this time it seems like they're trying. A little, at least.
"Megan Leavey" is an affecting look at the bond between a Marine and her dog. It's not quite so successful on the human front.
It's a strong debut for Moshe, who, with the exception of some of the oater dialogue, shows both a reverence for and a knowledge of the genre that's intriguing.

Fun, happily, is one of the many ingredients in copious supply here. When you include Paul Rudd as Ant-Man, how could it not be? Then again, there isn't a lot of room for him, so he's kind of wedged in there, but it's pretty swell when he's around.
Compelling and weird ...
"The Man Who Knew Infinity" is a good movie about a great subject, but one that should have been better.
It's a feast for the senses, as they say, and for once, that's not hyperbole.
While this isn't the best movie you'll ever see, for the curious it's worth exploring.
The film whirs along with such entertaining efficiency that you may not realize that, by the end, it has shifted its blame ...
It's the cinematic version of inventing a chocolate bar that makes you lose weight - something really tasty that's actually good for you.
The porn, the drugs, the smog, the bad haircuts - you can play it for laughs or play it straight. With terrific performances from Ryan Gosling and Russell Crowe, Black does a little of both.
Director Nicholas Stoller doesn't have any more luck stringing the story together than he did the first time around, but he knows how to get a laugh.
Osmond may tell the story to wring maximum emotion out of the audience, but so what? Isn't that why people make these movies? It is. And more importantly, it's why people watch them.
People say this kind of thing all the time - I'm pretty sure I have a time or two - but "The Lobster" is unlike any movie you've ever seen.
Magnetic. And harrowing. And frustrating. And maddening. And a little sad.
It feels flat, disjointed, with too many moving parts.
Too often "Alice Through the Looking Glass" feels like a slog through time.
The plot is filled with clichés and the attempt at the bigger picture - the value of a life - is muddy at best. You may find the film courageous, but you're more likely to find it ... sad.
Credit Rosenberg for tackling the big ideas. If he bit off a little more than he can chew, so be it.
It's an unforgiving film, one whose story you may question when it's over. But you won't forget it.
With big success comes big expectations, and "The Conjuring 2" is loaded with them. It doesn't live up to them, quite, but it's still scary and worth seeing.
Guzman overpowers the rest of the movie - but like LeBron James and his one-man show during the 2015 NBA Finals, that's not ideal.
Like the original, "Finding Dory" makes us understand the fears, joys, struggles and triumphs of family. See it with yours.
It's a trip we've been on before. Johnson and Hart make the journey a little more pleasant than it could have been.
If you love movies, it's time well spent.
The film has its fascinating moments. The performances aren't really among them.
The story of the great writer and man's man in decline could have been fascinating, but director Bob Yari's film is not.

De Palma is a deceptively simple documentary film: Director Brian De Palma sits in front of a fireplace for nearly two hours and talks about his life and career. If you love movies, it's time well spent.
Fear brings out the truth, even in would-be punks. And there is a lot of fear in "Green Room."
It's weird movie. In a good way.
It's all silly and meant to be fun, except when Najafi tries to throw in some serious bits, which wind up being sillier still.
It's an interesting movie, odd and disturbing by design. But it's also effective.

Wholly original and brand new, director Ciro Guerra's "Embrace of the Serpent" immediately feels like some kind of lost classic, a movie that has been around for a long time but only talked about in film circles, finally unearthed.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Trachtenberg is patient building this world, and the actors do a good job inhabiting it.
It's art-house fare, yes. Is it more than that? Is it even that?
The animation isn't showy, but it's beautiful, providing clear delineations between Taeko's past and present. The attention to detail is fantastic. But the story is what sets the film apart.
War is hell, they say. Hood shows us the many ways how.
"Hello, My Name Is Doris" is at times self-consciously quirky and precious and implausible - and Sally Field is so good in it that those complaints seem pointless.
If you think the name is inelegant, wait until you see the movie.

Questions regarding violence and mayhem are drowned out by violence and mayhem. Such is the superhero life as directed by Zack Snyder. There is no problem that can't be solved with a cranium-rattling explosion or two.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Frot's performance is so towering, so convincing, that it smooths out all the film's rough edges. It's a triumph.
Plummer is, by far, the best thing about the film.
As cultural archaeology, unearthing the relationship between food and a city, food and a critic, a city and a critic and a swirling stew of all the above, it's fantastic.
If you've always thought, as I have, that Tom Hiddleston was such a good actor he could salvage any movie, well, welcome to "I Saw the Light."
It's a weird film, one you'd probably have to call science fiction if someone made you pick a genre, and a deeply satisfying one.
I appreciated the effort Delpy, directing her sixth feature, puts forth in trying to spice up the genre. But that doesn't mean I enjoyed it.
From the first scene of "Krisha," writer and director Trey Edward Shults puts us off balance, and for the next 83 minutes keeps us that way, almost daring us to look away.
Everybody Wants Some!! is a terrifically entertaining movie that proves Linklater once again a master of perfectly capturing moments in time without judgment or apology.
Gyllenhaal [proves] once again that he's one of the most interesting actors working today. Unfortunately Jean-Marc Vallée's film doesn't measure up to Gyllenhaal's performance.

Cheadle isn't always successful, but his efforts work out more often than not. And I'd rather see an ambitious film occasionally fall short than a by-the-numbers biography, something this movie avoids at all costs.

The easiest way to describe "My Golden Days" is as a coming-of-age romance, but Arnaud Desplechin's film, with its memories and carefully nursed grudges and moments of heartbreak and betrayal, feels weightier than that.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "April and the Extraordinary World" is a visual delight, an animated French steampunk adventure that is smart, exciting and wonderfully weird.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As befits the modern fairy tale, there isn't so much a happily ever after as there is the promise of another sequel. Or prequel. Or whatever they come up with to take the Snow White concept to the bank one... more... time.
A delightful film that is almost impossible to watch without a smile on your face.
The film is visually striking, even if the images don't always make sense.
We're gonna need a bigger boat?" "We're gonna need a smaller bikini," more like.
It's compelling, and of course the music, taken from all parts of the world and played by musicians on every sort of instrument, is intriguing.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The comedy hits more than it misses; this is a really funny movie. And it's thoughtful, in its @$*# way.
I enjoyed it immensely.
This is a genre that has been elevated by great films. "Hands of Stone" is a decent boxing movie, but it won't be counted among them.
A nice little mix tape of a horror movie, incorporating elements of familiar films into something satisfyingly different.
Hartigan touches on loneliness, fatherhood, casual racism and the difficulty of trying to figure out who you are and where you fit in, no matter your age.
A good start for Portman, with promise of better things to come.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Much is promised and too little is delivered.
"Morgan" ... is creepy, and sometimes pretty smart. And sometimes not.
There is something compelling about someone who simply shows up for the job, day after day, carving out the remarkable from the unremarkable.

Kwedar doesn't offer any easy answers. Instead he points out the problems, how entrenched and intertwined they are, and asks other questions: How far will you go to survive? And will it be enough in the end?
Without real innovation or story evolution, "Blair Witch" becomes a trip down a rabbit hole of misery and suffering. Life's too short - especially in these woods.
"Come What May" is a paint-by-numbers account of a real-life World War II event, the displacement of eight million people from their homes in France.
Harrowing to the point of being off-putting - but not quite.

Joseph Gordon-Levitt is good as Snowden (his voice alone is terrific), capturing his nerdy intelligence and passion for patriotism. Shailene Woodley is even better as Lindsay Mills, Snowden's girlfriend.

I've heard "Rubber Soul" and "Revolver" and "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" probably thousands of times, too, and I still like hearing them. So it is with Howard's movie - the story is so incredibly good, it's worth repeating.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Winslet and Davis salvage what they can from the movie - a heroic effort, almost, making it a fun trifle, albeit one with some deadly serious overtones.
It's a fun movie, a nicely made Western in which bad guys get to be good guys sometimes. Maybe that should be enough, but you can't help wanting more.
Moretti and his actors establish a kind of instant empathy that makes the story all the more affecting.
Fueled by empathetic performances and by... well, fuel, "Deepwater Horizon" is an interesting hybrid: a disaster movie with heart.
It's often funny, but it never quite hangs together as a coherent movie.
"Operation Avalanche" is an inventive grab-bag of a film, a movie about making a movie that no one was supposed to know was a movie at all.
It's a complicated movie about a complex man that courts controversy, both intentional and not. If that doesn't make it a great movie, it makes it a necessary one, now more than ever.
Not every chance director Rosemary Myers takes in her debut feature pays off. But the point is, at least she takes some, and when they work, they work to perfection.
A sweet movie with a good message about how magic can be found, if you know where to look.
It's another showcase for Streep - nothing new on that front, but still enjoyable.
Let's make it easy: If you like sitting in a dark room looking at pictures that move, you should see "Hell or High Water." It's terrific.
It is a movie about ideas and living with them. Well, that and sex.
"Free State of Jones" is a well-intentioned slog through a potentially fascinating bit of Civil War history, brought to life only by Matthew McConaughey's performance, and then only occasionally.
You honestly don't know what to expect, and when the film is done, you're not exactly sure what has happened.

Look, this isn't supposed to be Serious Cinema. I get that. I also know that there is a cinematic place for over-the-top action. I also know that it doesn't have to be stupid, because I saw "Mad Max: Fury Road."
There are some good ideas in there, even timely. But eventually, like everything else in the movie, they're washed away in a sea of blood and a hail of bullets.
"Swiss Army Man" is crazy, magical, absurd, funny, sad, creepy - all that and probably more.
"Les Cowboys" keeps you off-kilter from the start.
While there is some magic here, it's not the transportive experience it might have been.

Dennison is a marvel, completely unself-conscious in his portrayal of a kid who is lost but thinks if he acts tough, it'll look like he's found. Neill, playing a different sort of character for him (quiet, unfriendly), is also outstanding.
A lot of movies abandon smart ideas. "The Secret Life of Pets" is one of them. There are still some laughs, and the animals are cute.
"Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates" gives us too much hangover and not enough buzz.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to Cranston's performance - along with a game supporting cast - and Brad Furman's tension-building direction, the movie works.
Thanks to Fey, as well as the other actors, it has grit. But it doesn't have teeth.
"Ghostbusters" is a pretty good movie. Will it capture the public imagination like the first one? Probably not.

Ross doesn't explicitly take sides. In fact, he strikes a little too neat a balance at the end, if anything. But that takes nothing away from the intriguing idea and Mortensen's terrific performance, both of which make the film more than worthwhile.
What's most notable about the new film is how closely it hews to Gene Roddenberry's original TV series, at least in spirit.
In some ways the film is like an amusement park ride. You see the curves and twists coming, but if you're going fast enough, they're scary anyway.
It'll probably never make it into anyone's list of the 10 most-important Allen films. But I'd watch it again over a few movies that would.
This thing is madness.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Phantom Boy" is a quiet, peaceful little animated film, arriving just in time as a salve for a noisy, angry world.
Damon is still compulsively watchable as Bourne, still haunted even if he's found some of the answers he's been looking for.
It comes off like a combination of "The Hunger Games," "Saw" and Pokemon Go. Maybe that sounds like a good thing. It's not.
Fontaine ("Gemma Bovary," "Coco Before Chanel") has just the right touch. There is no melodrama here, simply women of faith living day to day.
It's probably best to think of "Suicide Squad" as a primer, an entry into a side world of the DC Universe that may pay bigger benefits in later films.
A tiny gem, a delightful film as surprising as it is satisfying.
You don't have to be a fan of Frank Zappa's music to enjoy "Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in HIs Own Words," Thorsten Schutte's documentary.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is a somber slog through the lives of one miserable wretch after another.
It's a movie as warm and fuzzy as a comfortable blanket, and as safe as the milk Edwards prefers to anything stronger. Not as exciting, perhaps, but it gets the job done well enough.
It's a tough world out there, and Costandin has found a way to survive in it. It's not always pretty, but in "Aferim!" it's never less than interesting.
Schwartzman ... gives Larry enough humanity and a modicum of personal growth that you keep coming back for more.
Gibney, much like Jobs, takes a lot of existing information and packages it attractively. There isn't much new here, but if the story is familiar, Gibney at least tells it in an interesting way.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What drives these men? "Because it's there" merely scratches the surface. "Meru" may not answer the question completely - likely nothing can - but it is a thrilling, harrowing attempt.

We've seen plenty of stories about the arrival of a mysterious stranger upsetting the order of things. But "The Second Mother," Brazilian writer and director Anna Muylaert's outstanding film, is different.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The acting in "Black Mass" is tremendous.
"Everest" is a sprawling mess of a movie, one you feel like could have been great but instead roams all over the place and winds up being just pretty good.
Director Wes Ball's film is a mad dash from one place to the next, with little time in between for rest, recuperation or plot development.
It's pretty regular in terms of plot and story - the kind of thing we've seen many times before, though usually with less likable actors and without all the dirty jokes.
"Queen of Earth" isn't a laugh riot, not by a long shot. But it is a good movie, and a fascinating study of descent.
"The Intern" is idiotic, unrealistic, Boomer wish fulfillment that has no business working on any level. I quite enjoyed it.
Genius is fascinating, particularly when it is complicated, as it always seems to be.
What an oddly tone-deaf film.
Hotel Transylvania 2 is better than the original. Mind you, this is a low hurdle to clear.
Zemeckis ... nearly sinks the film before redeeming it in spectacular fashion.
It's tempting to call this a horror movie for people who don't like the genre, but it's more accurate to call it a movie for people who like good movies, no matter what type.
Damon is terrific. But this is by no means a one-man show.
Mendelsohn manages to make us simultaneously feel sorry for him and hope, against what seem like steep odds, that he somehow succeeds.
Was anyone clamoring for the story of how Hook and Peter came to be? Maybe, but they won't find it in "Pan," not really.
Bahrani's film asks a timely, yet timeless, question: How far would you go to save your home? Would you be wiling to lose yourself in the bargain?
Todd Strauss-Schulson's meta send-up of '80s sex-equals-death slasher movies keeps its goofy good humor throughout, and tosses in a little almost-genuine feeling into the mix for good measure.
A well-meaning movie whose sterling intentions, timely and provocative subject and terrific cast are muted to near oblivion by uninspired storytelling and direction.
The acting is superb, no easy feat when trying to recite Sorkin's words while walking down seemingly endless hallways. Fassbender doesn't look a thing like Jobs and it doesn't matter a bit.
Is it too much? Oh, yeah. But if you like this kind of thing, too much is never enough.
The Shaun the Sheep Movie manages to be smart, moving and hilarious without the inclusion of a single word of dialogue.
A film that is so old-fashioned and comforting that, for much of the time, watching it feels like cuddling up under a soft good-movie blanket.
A reminder that the architects of a massive tragedy remain present and unrepentant, the personification of the evil men do and a warning that it could happen again.
Bang, boom, bam. That's about the size of things in No Escape, a movie banking on its admittedly first-rate action drowning out its political tone-deafness.
It's a short film, weighing in at 79 minutes, but that feels about right. You probably wouldn't want to spend a lot more time with these folks, no matter how intriguing their company.
Turns an intriguing idea into a B-movie action flick.
It chugs along happily enough, but never kicks into the higher gear you keep waiting (and hoping) for.

Once the romance takes off, the entire film shifts. It becomes more of a conventional romantic comedy, albeit one with really dirty words. And it remains hilarious, because Schumer seems to be incapable of being anything else.
Ugly, absurd, mean-spirited, nonsensical - shall we continue?

Sherlock Holmes is a kind of detective Superman, and what makes "Mr. Holmes" so intriguing - in addition to a terrific performance by Ian McKellen as the title character - is seeing him facing his own personal Kryptonite.
Allen builds to a climax that is ridiculous and a comment on ... I don't know. Fate? Folly? There are plenty of both in "Irrational Man," but they're not often a comfortable mix.
Rodriguez and Taylor are terrific. Their confidence is infectious, yet they never let us forget the challenges their lives offer.
Cynics can carp. Let them. But don't be one of them.
We've seen the elements that make up "Paper Towns" before, but that's OK. Schreier proves adept at avoiding clichés, and is helped by his actors.
It falls to Helms to carry the movie, and he's not quite up to it.
This is in many ways essential film education. Yet the consumption of it is never a chore.
It's an interesting film, consistently entertaining, a mile wide and an inch deep.

Hoss is perfect in a challenging role, a woman trying to recover bits of the person she once was, but having to do so in service to a greedy scheme that robs her of the very identity she is trying to recover.
What might have been must be better than what's here, because what's here isn't much.
The film consists of the two men talking, and not a lot else. But the performances, by Jason Segel as Wallace and Jesse Eisenberg as Lipsky, are perfect.
You think the man could act? You should hear him talk.
"Straight Outta Compton," F. Gary Gray's biopic of pioneering gangsta rappers N.W.A., manages to feel urgent and alive, even as it plays like the coolest episode of VH1's "Behind the Music" ever.

Bacon can play just about anything, and he's having a good time here as a guy not quite smart enough to keep himself out of trouble, but wily enough to try to dig himself out of it. It's fun to watch.
It almost works. Actually, it does work, hitting the requisite number of hip notes. It just doesn't dazzle, and that's kind of a surprise.

There is something about the siren call of the TV camera that can turn even big thinkers into brawlers. It was true then and it's true now, and "Best of Enemies" serves as a thoroughly enjoyable reminder.
With top-shelf talent like Bill Plympton, Tomm Moore and Nina Paley on board, it's no surprise that the segments are as attractive as they are different.

There was a dark side to this complex man, and while it takes director Daniel Junge a while to get there, he does eventually in "Being Evel," his entertaining and sometimes uncomfortable documentary about the daredevil.
Efron and Bentley seem woefully out of place as would-be electronic dance music DJs.
