The film goes too wide and gets a little soft at the end, but not fatally so. It's the rare horror film - well, sort of horror - that you and your children can enjoy together.
"Room" is a terrific movie, one that has two outstanding performances, confident direction and a story line that is both harrowing and moving.
The planning must have been herculean. But it's a testament to the skill on the part of Schipper and the actors that it plays realistically.
Absolutely beautiful and sometimes maddening while never offering easy answers.
"The Big Short" manages to entertain you while making you really, really mad.
Tarantino seems to have no shortage of creativity or inspiration. What he needs to find is someone who isn't afraid to occasionally say, "Cut."
Cate Blanchett is outstanding as a married woman who falls for a younger woman. As that younger woman, Rooney Mara is even better.
Smith's performance, in which he resists the urge to go over the top, and the subject matter make "Concussion" an interesting movie, but not the urgent one it could have been.
The script feels not half-finished, but maybe three-quarters. Lawrence does what she can to make up the missing 25 percent, but even she can't perform miracles.
Director and co-writer Iñárritu is aiming high with this film, based on a true story - and he never lets you forget it.
It's fair to say that "Anomalisa" is unlike any movie you've ever seen, which is something fair to say about pretty much any movie Charlie Kaufman is involved in.
"The Forest" is one of those horror movies that starts with an intriguing idea but has no idea what to do with it.
A Holocaust drama like you have never seen before.
It's when bullets fly that Bay is at his best. He stages the battles well, and builds tension effectively and at times inventively.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The burden rests on Eid's shoulders, and he more than carries it. He's a natural, showing us Theeb's curiosity, loyalty and ingenuity while still retaining the innocence of a boy who has been sheltered from the world outside the desert.
This is not an actual horror movie, but the tension grows so great in some scenes you might mistake it for one.
Jack Durant was, by all accounts, a larger-than-life personality, someone who would make a fascinating subject for a really good movie. "Durant's Never Closes" isn't it, alas.
The "Kung Fu Panda" formula works, still, and if directors Alessandro Carloni and Jennifer Yuh don't reinvent the panda-as-martial-artist wheel, they avoid making the story seem stale.
Welles' vision and imagination is unmatched in film. His use of light in a forbidding, dark castle is a wonder.
The pencil and crayon drawings come to vivid, colorful life to tell a more complex (if hardly subtle) story than you would expect.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While individually some of the scenes are terrific, they don't add up to much, making "Hail, Caesar!" one of the Coens' lesser comedies, better than "Intolerable Cruelty," say, but nowhere near the genius of "The Big Lewbowski."
It takes a strong stomach for extreme violence and over-the-top obscenity, but if you're willing to roll with that, "Deadpool" is a hoot.
We hear how great the store is, how important its status as an arbiter of taste among the wealthy and, occasionally, there's a little dig here and there.
Dalio's use of images, particularly "Starry Night," is at first creative and then a little over the top. But his story is intriguing.

With incredible attention to detail and an unwavering commitment to the world he has created, Eggers slowly, surely builds tension until it's almost unbearable. And that's delightful, if you're a horror fan. It's a terrific film.
It's not especially challenging. But it is several steps up from some faith-based fare, and it will doubtless appeal to its target audience.
"The Danish Girl" is beautifully shot and tastefully made and acted, but only Vikander seems willing to take chances. Happily, she does.
What Abrams has done is find and return the ingredient crucial to the original three films in the franchise that was sorely lacking in the second round: fun.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: We never doubt the enormity or ferocity of the beast, nor the trials of the men who unwisely went hunting for it. We just don't live and die by the outcome.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Why do we need another "Macbeth?" There's a two-part answer: A) Michael Fassbender. B) Marion Cotillard.
Wilson and Wilde have a light touch that makes them perfect for the comedies they often make. Here, Morano leads them to much darker places, and they plunge right in.

"The Armor of Light" can be frustrating and painful to watch. But ultimately, there is hope here.

Had it been the first Bond film with Craig in the title role, the reaction likely would be "wow!" This is some good stuff, way deeper than the silly Bonds. But with history behind us, it feels a little slight.

movie_review_blurb: The movie is much like its hero, Freddie - straightforward, sweet, hard-working and predictable.

Take away its endless trail of bodies, and Bad Boys II is a stale, tedious, woefully acted movie that wastes the talents of Smith and proves once and for all that Lawrence has precious little talent at all.
Certainly, Pirates has its moments. But it's definitely no 'E' ticket.

movie_review_blurb: A stagy romantic comedy that lacks an energetic story but is rescued by the talents of its two stars.
This is Wild Wild West meets Avengers bad.

He said he'd be back and he is, with a bang, in another sequel that pays tribute to the first two films while delivering enough dazzling action sequences and droll wit to satisfy even the most demanding fans.
Much like she saved Sweet Home Alabama, [Witherspoon] uses her inexhaustible charm and comedic timing to keep this underpowered sequel from sinking into the doldrums.
Inane claptrap that's sure to be forgotten in the time it takes to rattle off its elongated title.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Loud but listless, this sequel plays like coming attractions for a movie that never shows up.
A dreary, unfunny, painfully forced affair.
Lee's talents, though vast and subtle, are not suited to the material, and his endless quest to find meaning gets in the way of what we all want to see.
An unrelentingly morose quest for redemption, one that leans too heavily on stock characters and tends to wander in odd directions.
Despite some odd pacing and a longish, off-putting flashback, Chaos succeeds more than it fails.
A laugh-free zone among summer comedies.
Worth watching for the coming-out party of Agnes Bruckner, a relative newcomer who shows her mettle with an extraordinary performance in this very ordinary tear-jerker.
While Zus & Zo strains for style points, it's just an off-the-shelf romantic comedy, and not a very good one.
I don't know whether it can get any dumberer. But they definitely put the lame in lamebrain in Dumb & Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Has enough chills and thrills -- as well as plenty of nearly dead creatures -- to rank among the scariest and most ingenious horror movies in recent memory.
2 Fast 2 Furious is that rare film that's perfectly described by one of its co-stars' names: Ludacris.
It takes the concept of reality television and twists it into a shocking but poignant art form.
In a summer film season filled with plotless star vehicles and exploding sequels, Seabiscuit easily rides to the front of the pack.
Although it borders on exploitation in several places, Thirteen packs an emotional wallop.
A well-acted, carefully directed yet largely unsatisfying exercise.
An amiable-enough Spade vehicle that lacks that certain something, but still manages to generate its fair share of giggles.
A faultlessly constructed, artistic look at love, loss and truths we can't ignore.
Funny, poignant and vitally original.
Combines a worn-out premise -- young woman leaves unhappy home for big city -- with some of the silliest characters ever to reach the screen.
It's finally happened -- Jackie Chan has turned into a full-fledged cartoon character.
Although the film delves into an interesting topic -- black marketeers trading in human flesh -- the approach is far too clinical.
It's a pleasantly quirky love story with a wry sense of humor and standout performances from the youngish cast.
Mostly Le Mediocre.
Once the novelty wears off, the latest movie feels just like every other -- an unrepentant gorefest with little personality or flavor.
[A] comedy with no laughs.
It's every police movie you've ever seen wrapped into one, done so stiffly that the characters are barely able to bend at the waist to collect their hundreds of spent shell casings.
A compelling juxtaposition of the poignant and the bizarre, a movie that tosses moviemaking rules into the nearest Cuisinart.
Using mostly unknown and first-time actors, Loach spins a passable coming-of-age tale, which should please his fans and provides a diversion for the rest of us.
An energetic, raunchy comedy that's funnier and more creative than the last film.
There's virtually no story, no conflict, no tension and no suspense, just the endless droning of the worst dialogue written in recent memory.
It is at most a middling effort.
A harmless but singularly unremarkable oater that takes a long time to reach the Big Shootout.
When Darkness Falls, it pretty much trips over its own feet.
It is alternately ridiculous, gruesome, unlikely and stupefying.
Wahlberg is largely forgettable, and his would-be romance with Theron is sparkless and perfunctory.
A loud, disorderly descent into narcissism, a movie so in love with itself that its gaze rarely leaves the mirror.
A passable thriller.
Now we know what happens when director Gus Van Sant gets bored. He makes us bored.
After a while, you feel like you're watching natural interactions rather than a scripted performance.
There's no denying the film has a tendency to trip over its own ungainly strides, but it has enough firepower to entertain action fans -- as long as they don't look too closely.
If this is the View From the Top, I'd hate to see the View From the Bottom.
Woefully unfunny.
It is a firsthand account from an eyewitness to history, a woman who was at Hitler's elbow until the very end.
Predominantly fluffy and loveably goofy, mostly due to the presence of Bynes, who's definitely a star in the making.
... Martin doesn't have his A-game here. Bringing Down the House is a passable little comedy, but the white-haired funnyman is neither wild nor crazy.
Traffic was brilliant fiction, but City of God proves that true stories often pack the most punch.
On the big screen ... Gods and Generals plays woefully stiff, hampered by the breadth of its source material and the reams of exposition required to explain the action.
As funny as it is dumb, and that's saying something.
The Life of David Gale is the world's first movie with a penalty phase.
It is a singularly impressive work, able to generate laughs one moment and tears the next.
In a seemingly effortless performance, Caine dominates every scene in the film, not by what he does but by what he doesn't do.
After awhile, a certain sameness settles over Deliver Us From Eva.
In this tepid spy thriller, everything is pretty much what you would expect.
Tears of the Sun may make you weep, but not for joy.
A fish story that hooks you from the opening scene.
If this sounds like an awkward combination, it is.
Although languid to a fault, Spider offers some payoff for those with enough patience to stick it out.
Flat, obvious and painfully unfunny, The In-Laws offers solid evidence that some movies shouldn't be remade.
The movie works when Carrey's mugging it up ... but melts into a saccharine tub of goo when he plays it straight.

By the end, you'll probably be whistling a happy tune.
With unmatched bravado, Sokurov shows scores of celebrants streaming from the ballroom past his camera with nary a misstep.
A rollicking, tongue-in-cheek sendup.
I'm glad to see director Neil LaBute is back doing what he does best: creating some of the most memorably cruel characters in modern cinema.
A pleasant if predictable romp.
While it includes some funny scenes, one senses that the Nicholson-Sandler pairing could have achieved much more.
Ah, Clueless. Now there's a good movie. Here's guessing the guys who wrote Lizzie McGuire never saw it.
A fascinating study in the cinematic arts, as we watch a talented director and a committed crew and cast thwarted by nature, human failings and just plain bad luck.
At its best, Confidence is a weak remake of The Sting, without the charisma of Paul Newman and Robert Redford. At its worst, the movie wastes a talented cast.
It's a fun, raucous ride, with more than its share of chills and thrills.
A fascinating study in excess, a movie that seduces and repulses as it explores the merciless nature of fate.
Starts with the right intentions but quickly unravels.

An overly long, unwieldy movie.
Clearly, this movie is designed to sell action figures rather than make sense.

An entertaining if slightly skewed documentary about the short life and early death of General Motors' EV1.
With this unflinching account of that day, Stone has made the most important film of his long career.

The movie might make for a good book, but it's too awkward and lacks the necessary action for a film. And Williams' rather sluggish approach doesn't help much. Eventually, we just aren't interested in tagging along with him.
Sorry, George Lucas, but CGI creatures usually look pretty fake; the crawlers, however, are quite realistic and creepy, especially as they skitter over the walls and roofs of the caves.
Whether the engine on Talladega Nights is humming or sputtering, Ferrell stays gamely behind the wheel.

Although the movie offers a few chuckles here and there, it fails on almost every level.
As Dick's vision matches up with our times, so does director Richard Linklater's animation technique match the story's material. A Scanner Darkly is a joyful wedding of medium and message.

Superman Returns careens along at wild speeds while still stopping for thoughtful moments.

The film is wonderfully innovative.

Near the start of Flyboys, the squadron's grizzled vet hands suicide pistols to the new pilots, to be used if they find themselves in a no-win situation. Unfortunately, the audience is offered no such option.

Unsteady but often entrancing.
Director Justin Lin (Better Luck Tomorrow) goes back to basics, back to what everyone liked about the original, namely mindless car-racing fun.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

Humanizes the Iranians and shows that they're just as crazy about their sports as Westerners, if not more. If anything, it proves that soccer is truly an international language, providing an arena where anyone can communicate.

A compelling, tear-jerking look at a vital piece of our infrastructure gone awry.

The story features some surprises, and director Mikael Håfström adds realism by bypassing computer graphics for practical effects. Add in the natural fear of being trapped in tight spaces and you have a can't-miss formula for horror and suspense.

movie_review_blurb: Every bit as puzzling as its predecessor, but it's shot in such a bold, crazy way that you have to admire its pure audacity.

Beyond a few good special-effects sequences - notably the Human Torch chasing the Silver Surfer between skyscrapers, the movie is uniformly vanilla. When the heroes aren't polishing their super-skills, they sit around and complain about their lot in life.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The frustration here is that none of this leads anywhere. Perhaps that is the point, that some mysteries are never solved, but Jindabyne could give us a little more to work with.
From the nondescript voices to routine animation to an over-written story, this movie spends much of its time gasping for air.
A sequel (or three-quel, if you will) that returns to the vicarious fun of the first movie, Ocean's Eleven, and all but erases the not-so-fond memory of the preening ego-trip that was Ocean's Twelve.

A Good Year feels as if it takes a year to watch, and not a very good year at that.

If Stranger Than Fiction has a central flaw, it's overly sentimental. Although the story would work better as a tragedy, Forster and Helm can't resist tacking on a mushy love story, involving Crick and combative tax cheat Ana Pascal.

Smartly relevant and affecting, commenting not only on the isolation of the monarchy but also on a tabloid culture run wild.

It's a film worth seeing several times. If you're lucky enough to get the chance.

Before Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World, perhaps Brooks could find some jokes that work over here.

movie_review_blurb: Kung Fu Hustle will not only please martial-arts fans, it's witty and energetic enough to engage those who usually ignore such choreographed Asian dust-ups.
The film works as a highlight tape for the cast and will satisfy any desire you have to be driven to the brink of tears.
A journey into an austere land of moviemaking where few artists dare go.

Essentially one long goof, but it's a well-executed goof and a pretty fearless one at that.
A laugh-out-loud funny, adrenaline-fueled romp.
The film is passably entertaining, in no small part because of Steve Zahn.
He does, but you probably won't, especially from watching this movie.
You certainly can't question Tucker's bravery, but you may occasionally feel the urge to ask him to be quiet.
A movie worth catching.
At this point, Allen may be the only guy laughing at his jokes.
Every now and then, a movie does more than gamely defend the status quo but actually advances the art form. So it is with Sin City, a stunning, brutal vision of a city gone mad.
At this point, any humor left in the Barbershop series is limited to a few stray clippings on the floor.
A soul-baring scrapbook of a film, its audacity surpassed only by its tragedy.
Twenty minutes in, we know where the movie is going and, as a result, it loses momentum in the final half-hour.
frustrating, challenging the imagination with pure spectacle but failing to supply a clear road map to follow.
It just doesn't go deep enough.
Like certain prescriptions, The Interpreter can cause drowsiness and should not be viewed while operating heavy machinery.
As a rating, XXX is used to warn people away from objectionable material. For this movie, it's more like ZZZ.

Given the movie's peculiar context, [the book] should be required reading before anyone is allowed into the theater.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Some may consider Dark Water too leisurely paced, but it's refreshing to see a film that doesn't shoo the ghost from a closet in the first half hour.

Drawbacks aside, with War of the Worlds, Hollywood is calling on Spielberg to deliver this summer's blockbuster, and he accomplishes the task. The movie is solid all the way around, and Spielberg's touches are everywhere.
With Land of the Dead, Romero shows he still has the talent to scare us (and gross us out) in creative ways.
So what's left? Pretty much Kidman's consternation and Ferrell's one-man show, which is funny for awhile but eventually even he runs out of gags. Perhaps more cowbell would have helped.
While you won't care about the human characters, you may find yourself pulling for Herbie.
Finally, a Batman movie that's actually about Batman.
Mr. & Mrs. Smith has a beginning, but it lacks the always important middle and end.
While the digital backdrops are suitably out of this world, the movie lacks action and momentum.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In the first Ring, you watched a videotape and seven days later, you were dead. In the second Ring, you watch a movie and seven minutes later, you're asleep.
It's certain that a second viewing would reveal numerous inconsistencies and unanswered questions, but because nobody will want to see it twice, we may never know.
Crowe gives another solid performance, and Paul Giamatti (Sideways, American Splendor) adds to his shining reputation as a top character actor by playing Braddock's lippy manager, Joe Gould.
Instead of The Longest Yard, they should have called it the Shortest Route to the Bank.
A meticulously researched and ably handled chronicle of one of the largest corporate scandals in American history.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It took 22 years, but the Jedi has finally returned.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Monster-in-Law proves two things: Jane Fonda can still act and Jennifer Lopez still can't.

A masterly, intricately plotted crime story.
The film doesn't follow its own rules.

The animation, and the creation of a world populated entirely by mechanical people, is impressive, but the plot is non-existent and the all-too-distant characters blend together in a mass of clanking gears and creaky sight gags.
On the surface, the film comes off as fairly clever, but the more you examine the plot, the more flaws you'll see.

It's too fragmented, lacks pace and is filled with so many eccentricities that it's hard to discern the point, if Anderson is even trying to make one. But watching Anderson fail is still more rewarding that watching other filmmakers succeed.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Other Scorsese films have carried more passion, but none has so brilliantly captured a lost era, or a lost American icon.
Butler doesn't have the necessary screen presence, and without a good Phantom, the movie fails to capture the imagination.
Deserves an audience because much of Brooks' writing is still strong and fresh.
Carrey has proven that when he's on, he's more creative than anyone out there. And he's on as Count Olaf, Snicket's principle villain
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A better press conference than a movie.
While the first two movies were efficient if not highbrow entertainment, the latest film abandons even the pretense of having a story.
Next to Closer, most on-screen relationships seem too neat and polite, with tears shed only for effect, and feelings bruised but never really damaged.
Often-uproarious.
Though Bale deserves all the credit that can be heaped at his feet ... there is far more to this sinister psychological thriller than just exhibiting Bale's emaciated form.
I respect Stone as a filmmaker, but this movie is punishment rather than entertainment.
Almost every scene in this generic action movie is ripped off from somewhere else.
Forster builds on each scene, and the finale ... is quite moving.
Full of hot air.
Like a tropical drink served at a resort bar, After the Sunset looks pretty but has zero kick.
Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason is amusing but never groundbreaking.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It is a cold, distant and failed experiment, with a molasses-mired plotline and an obvious moral forced upon us like a mug of bad eggnog.
There's a problem when the movie about the European conquest of America seems longer than the actual conquest itself.
Succeeds, in part, because the film is as non-judgmental as the famed sex researcher himself.
The extended reception sequences are superbly done, and Vaughn and Wilson are at their best when they're being false and winning at the same time.
Saying this movie is about boxing is akin to saying Citizen Kane is about a sled.
Zhang proves that Hero was no accident with House of Flying Daggers, another Chinese period piece resplendent with a dazzling palette and soaring, ambitious fight sequences.
Pacifiers are made to appease toddlers, but for the movie version, even that may be a stretch.
Even Travolta seems disinterested in this bloated sequel, which revisits all the old gags but doesn't possess a tenth of the energy found in the original.
Most of the time, you can't go wrong with kids and dogs. Then there's Because of Winn-Dixie.
For whatever reason, it's an injustice that Bardem was not nominated for best actor.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Occult detective John Constantine (Reeves) has seen it all and responds to the most hideous threat with a puff on his cigarette and a self-assured leap into the abyss.
It's hard to find fault with the motives of the teachers and the kids. Their determination and results are admirable.
Taken at face value, Bad Education is about molestation, but from a wider perspective, it's about love, loss of innocence and the desperate quest for redemption.
Not so much movie as antidote -- to the cynicism that's rampant in most Hollywood romantic comedies.
A horrifying yet compelling story of man's inhumanity to man.
As far as Big Day experiences go, a drunken speech from a distant relative would be far more entertaining -- and funnier -- than The Wedding Date.

Travolta's performance is idiosyncratic but not particularly appealing. He's hampered by an overbearing, sophomoric script and, worse, it's apparent that he doesn't believe in the character, not for one second.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is not without merit. Ten-year-old Fanning ably handles her part, which alternately requires her to adopt a thousand-yard stare and look like a scared little girl.
If your requirements for good comedy begin and end with a swift kick to the groin, Are We There Yet? is the movie for you.
This ranks as another excellent performance from Penn.
Though Richet stretches believability near the end, action-movie fans should assault theaters for an entertaining stay at Precinct 13.
Quaid provides the film with a solid foundation by ably playing yet another strong-willed father figure.
A sometimes disturbing yet equally revealing film that examines the motivations of our worst societal outcasts and tries to make some sense of it all.
The movie's 'message' -- life is more than just sports -- is delivered with the delicacy of a piano dropped from a fifth-story window.
A hokey, recycled collection of mumbo-jumbo that unabashedly steals from a multitude of other horror films.

[Rubin and Shapiro] were good enough to recognize wheelchair rugby as a prime documentary topic and lucky enough to uncover a collection of human stories that makes Murderball more than just another sports movie.
A delightful kids movie done from a kid's perspective that alternates between feeling like a fable and a pop-up book.
A high-concept movie that director Michael Bay turns into Bad Boys III: Send in the Clones.
It's entirely possible that Billy Bob Thornton and John Cusack phoned in their parts in The Ice Harvest. But in these modern times, they probably e-mailed.
During the credits, Reynolds is again shown in the fat suit while singing a power ballad, reminding us all how funny Just Friends could have been.
In Walk the Line, Joaquin Phoenix doesn't look exactly like Johnny Cash. He doesn't sound exactly like Cash, either. But he is Johnny Cash.

The fourth installment (yes, it never ends) in the series about the little wizard with the round glasses grows so violent and ghoulish that it drains the appeal of stories that are best when they stay innocuous.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A more-than-serviceable dark comedy.
The best that can be said for Zathura is that it meets expectations, which is becoming more and more rare at the movies.
Not since Fatal Attraction have the potential pitfalls of marital infidelity been so frighteningly portrayed in a movie.
For a movie that's supposed to launch Disney's official CGI era, Chicken Little doesn't stand tall enough.
In watching Yours, Mine & Ours, you have to wonder what the director had against star Dennis Quaid.
It's a good thing Jarhead features strong acting; otherwise the uneven ratio of exposition to action would become unbearable.
The movie isn't downright bad, but it's disappointing and forgettable, failing to emulate Allen or anybody else worth a darn.

This spare, uncompromising portrait not only examines what drove the author but delves into the ethics of journalists who identify with their subjects, or pretend to, in order to report their stories.
Although not as clever as the original, Saw II takes its cuts.
The Weather Man has the chance to be this year's Sideways. If, that is, it's marketed right.
The Legend of Zorro is not only a generic actioner, it's a perfect example of a movie with two leads interested only in the number of zeros on their paychecks.
North Country is a "message movie" with a target so big that it's impossible to miss, which is part of the trouble.
Some movies about horses take us for exhilarating rides, but Dreamer circles a well-worn trail again and again and doesn't know when to head for the barn.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely do you have a movie in which both lead actors give Oscar-worthy performances, but Defiance, Ohio is one.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: With its ambiguous title and tepid love story, the only thing going for Prime is Meryl Streep.
The only downside is that you can't use cheat codes to reach the end of the movie.
Don't look now, but Jeff Daniels' days as 'the other Jeff' may be coming to an end.
The Chronicles of Narnia is not a bad fantasy film. It's just not a great one.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An abrupt but unforgettable movie with rough edges that lend it even more resonance.
Let the good times roll, and take a run at The Matador.
By knocking the edges off Glory Road, Bruckheimer has turned a raw, compelling story into bland pudding.
This animated tale about 'what really happened' among the Wolf, Grandma, Red and the Woodsman doesn't excel in any department, from unspectacular computer animation to routine voice talent.
Irredeemable trash, plain and simple, gratuitously violent and sadistic and aimed at people who derive entertainment from watching other human beings suffer.
[T]he most recent Producers is a clone of a clone, and what it adds in song and dance it loses in brevity and, as is so often the case, wit.
Casanova is just plain ordinary.
For awhile, the movie gives off an unsettling vibe, as Sarah sort of flirts with a guy who may be her dad. This is eventually explained, but the film takes one more trip to Ickville before it ends.
A risk-taking but enlightening film that takes the novel approach of examining the Israeli-Arab impasse from the perspective of the Palestinians.
Madden does a competent job transferring the film from stage to screen.
They are funny bits, but there are too few of them. Fun With Dick and Jane just isn't all that fun.
For a while, you're waiting for Memoirs of a Geisha to start. Then you can't wait for it to end.
Spielberg's usual competence is on display, in many ways, but Munich is like no other Spielberg movie.
There's no contest. Brokeback Mountain is the most poignant movie love story of the year.
As a comedy, The Family Stone is more easy listening than rock-and-roll, but some of the performances (notably from McAdams and Nelson) are comfortable and affecting.
I wouldn't take my mother, but this stand-up movie is pretty funny.
At three hours, Jackson's Kong is too bloated and digressive to match the pure adrenaline of the first film, perhaps the finest B-movie ever made.

Your enjoyment of this movie will be in direct proportion to your patience. If you can stand not knowing everything right now and wait for the story's threads to weave into a rug, Syriana makes for an engaging time.
Though The Ringer is hardly the Farrellys' best, you'll probably be smiling, too.
The visual effects, especially those used to enhance the metaphysical elements, are impressive, but the story lacks that certain something.
Franco's curly locks may make the target audience swoon, but his presence never allows the rest of us to completely sink into Tristan & Isolde.

It's an uncompromising character study of a man who found peace, and ultimately death, among some of the most dangerous predators on the planet.
Let me reiterate. This movie is really, really dirty.
The makers of Asylum pretend they're making an art movie, and although the film has the trappings, the story is mostly Hollywood.
It's encouraging that Craven cast two relative newcomers who are excited about being in the film, rather than stale stars earning a paycheck.
A nostalgic, sentimental and wholly bawdy comedy that will make you laugh until your sides hurt.
Making sense isn't a top priority for Four Brothers.
Although the story of The Great Raid may have never been told on film, it's like every other POW movie, in this case made about 45 years too late.

If you're going to make a movie about Kurt Cobain, you might as well make a movie about Kurt Cobain.

An elegant, evocative film.
Written with the glee of a scheming Catholic schoolboy, but its geniality outstrips its plausibility.
The film is marginal for what it is -- a takeoff on a farce. There are only so many layers of sendup until the movie simply spins in the mud, kicking up gravel but going nowhere.
The movie is absolutely consistent -- it's just as wildly improbable at the end as in the beginning.
Clooney, who gained weight to play Murrow's producer, Fred Friendly, has made a solid film and his sense of humor remains intact.
Nobody plays a dissolute scalawag like Billy Bob Thornton.
Intriguing but overlong and indulgent, the work of a writer too in love with his characters.
A Sound of Thunder is worth noting, if only as a real contender for worst movie of the year.
This movie about a high school for superheroes is so good-natured and self-deprecating that it's virtually impossible to dislike the thing.
[Cage] makes everything bearable, applying his usual talent for giving unsavory characters some attractive traits.
The Exorcism of Emily Rose is more courtroom drama than horror movie, playing like a rejected TV spinoff -- Law & Order: SSU (Special Satanic Unit).
Although the characters might seem controlled, Wilkinson and Watson ... lend realism to the roles, and we believe they could be a married couple.

The movie is filled with the usual Wallace & Gromit favorites, from meticulously designed miniature sets to chase scenes, double-entendres and sight gags built around tiny props and the clay figures, which seem quite alive at times.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As someone who spent time in a steakhouse kitchen, I can say Waiting . . . comes close to reality, especially with its cast of characters.
The movie offers no handholds for the audience, leaving us behind in a flurry of important-sounding but meaningless exchanges between two-dimensional characters.
The movie is funny, but there's an undercurrent of genuine feeling.
Perhaps it will take a school trip to encourage kids to see Oliver Twist, but that's one permission slip parents should sign.

It's rare to find a filmmaker who can deliver such a message and keep us riveted every minute of screen time. But Cronenberg manages it, making A History of Violence one of his best, and most realistic, films ever.
A dreary, self-indulgent, overscripted train wreck of a film.
My theory is that Jared is Aquaman, and he's probing the ocean with his mental powers, looking for intelligent life. Which is why he never finds the screenwriter down there.
The film is as insubstantial as the clouds on the poster.
None of this would work without Duris' simmering performance as Tom, a person who's struggling to find his true calling.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A well-intentioned copy but one that holds much promise for its first-time director.
Corpse Bride is a delightful mix of strange goings-on and imaginatively crafted puppetry, a wild ride through Burton's chaotic, splendidly original world.

Wong offers an artful meditation on the nature of love, making effective use of color schemes (yellows, greens and reds), placid shotmaking and diverse music to deliver a sultry portrait of postwar Hong Kong.
If you leave The Thing About My Folks thinking about your own folks, consider the movie a success.
There are enough laughs that those who enjoyed The 40-Year-Old Virgin might want to take The Baxter for a whirl.
Foster is believable, but casting her is like entering a Maserati in the soapbox derby.
First-time Sedona filmmaker Tommy Stovall can't bear to part with certain scenes, even if they lengthen his film and send the story in circles.

Just as they did in the tumultuous '60s - then again as each of us faced our own upheavals over the decades - the hopeful, tuneful, impeccably harmonized songs of Brian Wilson fade in and save the day, then sail off into a perfect California sunset.

Le Week-End isn't nearly the comic lark the trailer would have you believe. It's much better than that: a poignant look at a relationship whose embers of love are barely glowing, but whose principals still like each other too much to split up

(Director) Branagh doesn't reinvent the wheel here, but he does take the rims off a flashy 2014 Tesla and put them on a 1985 Camaro: a big, comfy muscle car asking only that you point it in the right direction and step on the gas.
Chef can take its place at the table alongside the great movies about food, among them Big Night, Babette's Feast and Chocolat.
Bristling with sharp surprises at every dark turn, punctuated by crackling performances from a first-rate cast and filmed with a haunting moodiness, Cold in July is a perfect little film
For anyone who has long suspected Wes Anderson of being a master technician in search of his heart, The Grand Budapest Hotel joyfully announces that the quest is over.
The pairing of Michael Douglas and Diane Keaton in a love story for grownups yields a dose of feel-good refreshment that merits the price of admission - especially for the age 50-plus crowd.
A crackerjack mystery that successively keeps the viewer wondering who's been killed, who's the killer, who's next, and oh yeah, has anyone been killed at all?

There are some Lord of the Rings-knockoff battle scenes between the evil humans and the good-hearted fairies-who live as one with nature, share everything, and need no government whatsoever ("Fairies of the World Unite!").

Stallone's dead eyes are betrayed only occasionally by glimmers of humanity: when he spares a would-be victim who happens to be in the wrong place at the wrong time, or when he takes vengeance upon a particularly bad bad guy.

Gandolfini died suddenly, at age 51, shortly after finishing The Drop. That leaves us hanging on his every exquisitely timed pause, and sensing the sheer weight of his personality every time he enters a room.
All too often, the desire of the audience dovetails with that of the characters: We really just want to get the hell out of this house.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The audience at which Little Boy is aimed will have no problem assimilating the film's themes of faith and miracles. But there's also plenty to admire here for those less inclined to buy into the filmmakers' worldview.

If you're a die-hard Four Seasons fan, your only complaint about Jersey Boys will be that Clint Eastwood couldn't stuff every last hit song in. But it wasn't for lack of trying - and face it, you've still got those old records at home anyway.

Like many a previous Niccol work, Good Kill is a human drama about a man hurled into a technological future no one could anticipate: a world in which we humans have come up with yet another ingenious way to torment ourselves.
Musically explosive, emotionally powerful and flat-out funky, Get on Up tells the outrageous life story of James Brown with a quirky brilliance worthy of the man at its center.

A film about actors, played by some of the best actors the movies have to offer, The Last of Robin Hood still manages to connect to the rest of us with characters whose flaws, though writ large, are all too human.

With the classic magician's tactic of misdirection, Now You See Me gets us to look at all the explosions, car crashes and pretty people while concealing that the magician's hat is empty and his cards are clearly marked.

(Director) Aronofsky has crafted one firecracker of an adventure film with spectacular effects, vast warring armies and a disaster scenario for the ages. And at its center is a splendid performance by Crowe.
Refreshingly single-minded in its aim to entertain, Wonderstone has no social agenda, no artistic aspirations, no enduring lessons - other than, perhaps, the universality of lifelong friendship.
What could possibly go wrong? Luckily for viewers, everything-and almost immediately.

Everyone in this Wellsian future loves it, except for a Luddite (Cedric Hardwicke). "What is the good of all this progress?" he declares. "We demand a rest!" He's supposed to be the villain, but I find him to be the film's most sympathetic character.
For the most part The Internship succeeds because of a feel-good vibe that resonates from beginning to end.
Great movies nearly always involve a director's galvanizing vision and an actor's willingness to let character drive performance. Captain Phillips is a great movie.
If American Hustle has anything real to say, it's some minor bromide about greed and corruption. Ultimately, like its central characters, it's is all about 'tude; of that, it's got a ton.

Gravity dazzles with images that place us at the center of space flight...but keeps yanking us into a contrived fantasy version of space in which, among other things, the world's space stations are all lined up, like a low-orbit trailer park.
As cinema, it's an interesting experiment. As a movie, it's a bloody mess.

In his own films, Woody tends to give the meatiest lines to his costars while he walks off with the wisecracks. Here he finds a most gracious host in Turturro, who happily focuses the spotlight on his prize casting coup.
The only trouble with Don Jon is the film's comfort level with the kind of material that holds its hero enslaved.
Clooney directed and co-wrote the movie, so let's give the guy credit for successfully pulling off its Ocean's 11-meets-The Dirty Dozen vibe.

(Writrer-Director) Reitman indicts our society, which has become not just wired but thoroughly trussed up. He comes down too hard, though, on the one character who is perceptive enough to see from the start where all this connectedness is heading.

Young love provides the framework for About Time, the latest movie from writer-director Richard Curtis. But the heart of the film is a story about a boy, his father and the greatest gift they can give each other: their time.

Does The Imitation Game fudge the edges of its hero's biography? Guilty. But there's artistic truth to the maxim uttered at the end of John Ford's The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance: "When the legend becomes fact, print the legend."
Her eyes glued to the horizon, that prominent chin jutting defiantly forward, (Witherspoon) leads us down the trail with gritty determination. We're happy to accompany her every step of the way.
Like Coogan's reporter, you'll want to wrap your arms around Judi Dench's Philomena and take her home. You can't, of course - but Philomena will follow you there anyway.
At nearly three hours, Interstellar occasionally makes us feel that we, too, have been transported to a planet where time stands still.

"Some people might be afraid to believe," Todd (Greg Kinnear) sighs at one point. The triumph of Heaven Is for Real is in the film's embrace of the very down-to-earth notion that such fear can lurk even in the hearts of those who have faith.
In the end we come to understand the essential role of sorrow in the human experience. It's a lesson seldom told in film - and never, in my estimation, with more grace and wit than here.
I'm not sure I would ever forbid a son of mine to play football. But I would definitely insist he see Concussion before strapping on those pads.

The detective ducks into a movie theater and finds himself watching a (heroic) film version of himself. His response - a snicker tinged with melancholy and disdain - speaks volumes about the futility of trying to dictate how we will be remembered.

Who cares if it's more of the same? For those who made the original the highest-grossing romantic comedy of all time - take that, When Harry Met Sally - this jaunty sequel is the icing on the baklava.

It's refreshing to encounter the occasional movie character who is blessedly devoid of guile. For that matter, it's also a relief to attend a film where we're not expected to hiss and throw our popcorn at the screen the moment a Catholic priest appears.
Artfully dreamlike and boasting towering performances by three legendary actors, Youth is a mesmerizing meditation on age, beauty and friendship

As he did with his gloriously realized 2002 domestic drama Far From Heaven, director Todd Haynes once more brings a story of how, in the pursuit of dreams, even happy endings can come with collateral damage.
As quirky as its characters, with an off-center sense of humor and a refusal to take itself too seriously, The Lady in the Van is a showcase for some of Britain's finest screen actors.

Does Eddie the Eagle play it too safe? Maybe. But even if it shuns the black-diamond slopes, this easygoing run succeeds in delivering us smoothly to the bottom, ready for a crackling fire and some hot cocoa.

The fabric that holds "Trumbo" together is the love story of the writer and his devoted, long-suffering wife, Cleo. As played by Diane Lane, Cleo emerges as Trumbo's most ardent supporter and most honest critic.

While the battle scenes are spectacular, the special effect I suspect will most appeal to the film's target audience - 15-year-old males - is Amy Adams in her bathtub, performing a PG-13 homage to Gypsy Rose Lee.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The stars all bring their A games, but beyond their convincingly moody performances this dour remake has little to recommend it - unless you're in the market for a circuitous, 13-year ordeal of loss, regret and missed opportunities.

Before we know it, the film morphs into a complex fable that ingeniously palpates the thin membranes dividing the tales we've been telling ourselves for thousands of years, from the Bible to blockbuster movies.
A stirring film biography, rich in period detail and inspiring in its depiction of one man's triumph over racism
"Eye in the Sky" consists mostly of big-name stars squinting at video monitors and saying, in effect: "Can we shoot now? How about now? OK, how about now?"
Thanks to its expert blend of home movies, newsreels, NASA footage and extensive recollections by Cernan, his family and fellow astronauts, this ranks among our very best space documentaries.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Part Munich, part Memento, Remember features a compelling performance by Christopher Plummer as Zev Gutman, a man with a deadly errand: to track down and kill the Nazi war criminal who murdered his family at Auschwitz.

Field delivers an artfully measured performance as Doris, first lulling us into believing she'll settle into a goofy stereotype, then stirring up subtle qualities to create a character who is alternately funny and tragic, chipper and anguished.
Still Mine has romance, passion, suspense, and a David-and-Goliath narrative that may make you want to stand up and cheer.
Please, no more sermons about midichlorians and the Force - let's get those light sabers crackin'! And crack they do,
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Maya Forbes' autobiographical fingerprints are all over Infinitely Polar Bear, a disarmingly joyful recollection of being raised by her bipolar father in the 1970s...yet the film feels universal.
Two fine hours of adventure-but as the film's grim-faced Cape Codders might say, 'Bring a slickah.'"

The film's most affecting scenes (are of) Herman Melville interviewing a survivor of the wreck.They sit in a small living room, huddled as close as the survivors in a lifeboat - and as bound by the story of the Essex as was its ill-fated crew.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Gyllenhaal brings utter commitment to his character (but the film's) homey little demolition trope becomes...a distraction for the viewer.

As fun as The Boss is, it would be nice to see (McCarthy) focus on movies with real scripts, populated by real people, tackling real life. Blending her gifts for the comic and the dramatic, McCarthy really could be the Boss.

The music is authentic, but to steal an SAT analogy, the characters are to real students as the chorus line in South Pacific was to real sailors: caricatures created to tell us things we already know about the virtues and deficits of callow youth.
As Baker, Hawke deepens his string of indelible screen creations. Lovable and infuriating, his Baker alienates virtually every person around him, while keeping the viewer squarely in his corner.

Cheadle's (younger) Davis is thoughtful, troubled and ingenious. Unfortunately, the Miles who monopolizes most of the movie - the burned-out, irrational, aimless Miles - is a lot less interesting and much more annoying.

It's hard to know what anybody involved in this misbegotten mash-up was thinking, other than 'Hey! The shooting location's in Hawaii!' (The state looks beautiful here, but that's a bit like saying Sharon Stone was attractive in Basic Instinct 2.)

The writers have decided that the more dirty words you stuff in an 8-year-old's mouth, the funnier he becomes. Even before the family leaves Chicago, the audience longs for them to visit a bar-soap factory and feed Junior a few samples.
Joy may be the story of the exceptional woman who invented the Miracle Mop - but the heartstrings David O. Russell plucks are universal.

Those of us who were never cool young guys live with an enduring hope: that someday we'll be cool old guys. It's a fantasy embodied in the flesh - specifically, in the gloriously creased, proudly aging flesh of 72-year-old Robert De Niro

'Don't look down' may be the first commandment for aerialists, but director Zemeckis spectacularly ignores it. His camera soars above Petit, swoops below him, comes in close on his face, his slippered feet, his delicate hands.

Any doubt that Steven Spielberg is a latter-day Frank Capra can be put to rest: Bridge of Spies is a celebration of an Everyman empowered by America's can-do spirit of justice and decency, in this case doing nothing less than saving the world.
The last moments of Room end with a whisper - one barely audible above the sobs and sniffles of the audience. Like so much of Room, it is perfect.
Like the crusading journalists it honors, Spotlight forges ahead with a gripping story and doesn't stop until it gets it right

In their second 007 collaboration, Mendes and Craig lighten the tone considerably. Here at last, we sense, the two are actually having fun with a franchise that originally found success, after all, as equal parts adventure, romance and spoof.
Only occasionally does a moment ring true, thanks largely to talented actors subduing a balky script like parents wrestling a petulant kid onto Santa's lap.

Like a palooka charging from his corner, Creed plunges ahead with only a few sidesteps. (Director) Coogler takes his time with each development, endearing these already likable characters to the viewer even more.
It's an adventure, pure and simple, in the tradition of Robinson Crusoe and Gulliver. And every bit as timeless.
The brothers Coen and their cast reward us with unexpected riches from a place now long gone, faded like a minor chord on a battered guitar.

The role calls for an actor who can summon affability and piteousness but burnish them with a scary edge, and Affleck lets all three qualities hum quietly just beneath the surface throughout the film.
Do your summer a favor, and plan to detour around Sin City. Unless, of course, you're determined to visit the feel-bad hit of the decade.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's an eerie rightness: the bright Dallas sun; the long Washington shadows; the delicate bouclé of that pink Chanel suit; the clarion clip-clop along Pennsylvania Avenue.
Struts down the runway in edgy, eye-catching threads. But draped over that skin-and-bones frame is an improbable getup that, like most haute couture, no one will ever buy.
A big, old-fashioned, toe-tapping, earworm-sowing extravaganza. If Gosling and Stone aren't Fred Astaire and Eleanor Powell, well, neither has anyone else been for 70 years.
Beatty...brings more than star power to the role of Hughes: He plays Hughes as an unraveling ball of ingenious nervous energy.
Fiercely human, bravely unsentimental and at times unnervingly hilarious, Manchester by the Sea washes over you, tossing and tumbling its disparate elements like a wild, bracing surf.

In the climactic scene, as stadium fireworks spark graphic battlefield memories in our hero's mind, Lee's experimental film is positively transportive. Movies always induce something like a dream state...the effect here is more like a hallucination.

Gibson makes his case that the best humanity can offer often arises amid the worst that humanity can inflict. There's no twisted pleasure in the making (or viewing) of this violence, only a solemn acknowledgment of the awful truth about war and bravery.
Bening's eyes dance with joy, darken in sorrow, flicker with anger, and mist over with regret-sometimes in staggeringly affecting sequence during the same, long take.
No grandstanding here, no Sorkin-style speeches about love, freedom and cultural legacies...Loving proves the language of love isn't always best expressed in words
As Swede, McGregor evokes an overwhelming sadness that deepens until he seems to become an emotional black hole from which no lightness can escape.

Formulaic? Sure, but Cruise is always fun to watch, and there are nice little nods to the star's 50+ status: When he winces on rising from the occasional bed or chair, it's the clear aftermath of one too many dark-alley dustups.

Depicting brutality without turning the viewer away has dogged artists since humans painted mammoth hunts on cave walls....Nate Parker's remarkable film provides a vision of slavery from which we cannot look away...while forcing us to look at ourselves
Old guys rule - for better and for worse - in Deepwater Horizon
The movie cannot escape its been-there-shot-that vibe.

In his gushing cinematic tribute to...Edward Snowden, Oliver Stone crouches in his hero's corner, cheering him on as Snowden lands one righteous sucker punch after another on a lumbering and unscrupulous nemesis: the U.S. military-intelligence complex.
If the ending of Bridget Jones's Baby leaves us approximately where we were at the fade-out of the last film, so what? Those who fail to learn from movie sequels are destined to repeat them.
Inferno preserves the series' museum-hopping intrigue while dispensing with the muddled religion-as-opiate-of-the-masses themes that made the first two installments more tedious than transporting.

A film that is much like the man at its center: Lean. Direct. Endlessly inspiring. And in his star, Tom Hanks, Eastwood has found the perfect actor to convey the casual heroism that made the real-life Sully a national icon.
The great miracle of Fences...is how Denzel Washington transmits the pain and frustration of his character through one of Hollywood's most radiant smiles.
Scorsese leaves us pondering: How far can organized religion sustain us in the face of oppression? When does pure faith kick in? And does that belief suffice?
Don't worry if you're not a big golf fan. I don't know a chunk from a chip shot-but it's the human drama that will stay with you.
Harkens back to the great epic films of David Lean. ..But at times it feels rushed, trying to cram in events while glossing over the essential moments in between.
Gere hurls himself into the role of Norman with an abandon his character would savor...perpetually wide-eyed, his hair tousled like a 5-year-old's.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bubbles with subversive observations...picking at the emotional scabs that still itch most Americans a decade after bankers...crushed the savings and dreams of millions.
A well-told story of a time in history when the true wild animals were on the wrong side of the bars.
Wilson should be an insufferable companion. But Harrelson...finds a way to make us laugh at his character's closed loop of yearning/striving/failing, even as we ache for him.
If the original was a delicate hand-drawn picture book, this computerized version is a baroque series of overwrought set pieces.
Ultimately, it hits us that we are viewing grief from two directions - youthful incomprehension and sad experience.
MacLaine and...Seyfried give this film life when it should be dead and buried.
Does for gardening what Babette's Feast did for food and Sideways did for Pinot Noir.
It's a funny idea for a movie, but...you don't believe any of these characters are remotely real. Don't stick around for the cake.
Fitzmaurice's...smart script and nuanced direction entitle My Name Is Emily to take its place beside such coming-of-age films as Sixteen Candles and Stand By Me.
Harks back to Out of Africa but Khama and Williams are no star-crossed lovers. We savor their triumph, and through it they make the world they live in a little sweeter.
I laughed more at ﻿Manchester by the Sea﻿
(Even) a potbellied, thin-haired Matthew McConaughey...can't perform alchemy on this movie's meandering and flabbily directed script.
(The Founder) may be the picture of what America calls success, but Keaton's eyes tell another story - that of a poverty impervious to wealth.
While you can't help but wish the plot would lead somewhere, the performances are all quietly powerful.
Cage hones his weary cop's character to a dull point, rough and ragged, like the lead of a detective's pencil scratching notes on a crumpled pad.

If you love to cry at movies - you know who you are - don't bring a hankie to The Light Between Oceans. Supply yourself instead with a roll of toilet paper, then thread it on a spindle in the drink holder.
Ben-Hur's epic sea encounter - told from within the confines of a prisoner's floating cell - is the most startlingly original and nerve-shattering action sequence of the year.

Murray's FDR dominates the film the way Roosevelt towered over American politics for a decade and a half. That's not always a good thing, because the central character here is supposed to be FDR's sixth cousin Daisy (Laura Linney).

(Director Tom) Hooper...cribs from musicals ranging from Oliver! to Cabaret to Disney's The Hunchback of Notre Dame. He misses the energy of those films, and doesn't accomplish the immediacy of Les Miz's stage incarnation.

I can't say you'll enjoy Amour. That would be an inappropriate reaction, in fact. Hollywood has conditioned us to expect swelling violins as characters draw close to death. (Here) there's little drama and nothing in the way of ceremony.
Christopher D. Ford's script deftly explores all the film's relationships with knowing good humor, and the action moves along swiftly enough so we never stop to say, "Hey, wait a minute ..."

It is no insult to tag Wes Anderson's Moonrise Kingdom as "charming" or "enchanting." Those qualities, sadly missing in this vertigo-inducing era of big screen alien invasions and superhero exploits, are here, three times filled and overflowing.
There's the germ of a very good action-comedy franchise in Puerto Ricans in Paris...A tighter script, a more urgent mystery and a bit more connection between the stars would have come in handy.

The two stars play off each other masterfully. Law's Wolfe is a force of nature...hair flying, arms spread. Firth's Perkins - his felt fedora seemingly pasted to his head, even at the family dinner table - remains a heroically stoic presence.

Gerard Depardieu gets the most oversold star billing since Marlon Brando was Superman's absentee father. Depardieu looms over less than a minute of screen time. Not that we miss him when he's gone; we just wonder why he was there in the first place.
A first-rate tearjerker in the tradition of The Notebook and Ghost...the movie moves briskly enough to earn its tears without wallowing. It even provides some hearty laughs along the way.

Splendid from start to finish. Miss Beckinsale emits a clear sense that her character is not only fully in control of Plan A, but concurrently beetling away at Plan B and, we suspect, subsequent plans up to and including Zed.
I'd say they don't make them like this anymore, but they just did.
A barely directed, indifferently acted, carelessly constructed comedy that slops together some of Hollywood's biggest names into one bad meat loaf of a movie.

Bateman isn't interested in a Wes Anderson-style celebration of eccentricity. Pretty soon we begin to sense the hidden scars that endure for the kids, and the deepening desperation for continued artistic fulfillment that is consuming the parents.

(Like) Bill Murray's Lost in Translation, Hologram's strongest quality is its focus on an eminently genial character, uncertain of his future, his feet sinking (this time literally) in the sands of time.
In a year that has already seen its share of delightful grownup-movie love stories, this is perhaps the most intoxicatingly sweet

Shannon's Elvis captures The King's mix of sexiness and innocence...Spacey's Nixon loses himself in Elvis' weird brand of hypersincerity, perhaps longing for a measure of the singer's utter lack of guile. The meeting, and the movie, end too soon.

Against a backdrop that looks like Thomas Kinkade has thrown up on his canvas, the figures (are) based on characters created by Lewis Carroll, but as close to the author as Beetle Bailey is to Stephen Crane.

Suffers by comparison with last year's game-changing Creed, whose fight scenes were ingeniously presented in one glorious, uninterrupted shot. The balletic result seemed to justify boxing's sobriquet as "the sweet science."

Not since Paul Greengrass sat us in coach for his 9/11 drama United 93 has a filmmaker so effectively summoned up the primal fears that, for the less air-worthy of us, lurk beneath every lurch, every "fasten your seat belts" warning.

McDonagh might have had a minor classic in the tradition of Quentin Tarantino...But by the time the characters head to the desert to pitch a tent and contemplate new screenplay concepts, we've nearly forgotten what the movie is supposed to be about.

Even... as Streep's face ignites in a glow of deluded rapture, a disquieting sense of guilt creeps over us. We like Florence, and we can't help sharing her husband's dread that some day, somehow, the elaborate jig will be up.

The film's most dramatic moment is one of its quietest: Dad sits down with Jake in the boy's bedroom...apologizing not so much for his handling of the situation as for the cruel complexities of life itself.
If there is an original idea in its ugly little head, Suicide Squad conceals it better than Batman hides his cave.
Like the character's past, this update is instantly forgettable.
You don't have to be a fan of...the TV show to enjoy...thanks to the genuine affection the lead characters - and presumably the actresses who play them - hold for each other.
Beyond the laughs, Allen's latest delivers a meditation on life's endless stream of choices - and the scar tissue that remains even when you believe you've made all the right ones.

A scene in which an Escobar confidant happens upon Mazur and his wife enjoying an anniversary dinner...morphs into the most unnerving restaurant run-in since Joe Pesci asked Ray Liotta, "What do you mean I'm funny?" in Goodfellas.

Truth is stranger than fiction, it's a fact; but when truth and fiction morph into each other, the strangeness factor increases exponentially. That's what happens in Ben Affleck's ingenious take on the real-life CIA (Iran hostage) mission.
The Royal Tenenbaums meets Swiss Family Robinson, with traces of The Great Santini mixed in

Movies based on Dahl's books have been a mixed bag, but Spielberg's The BFG may be the best of the lot. It's a visual spectacle of wonder and whimsy, crowned by a warmhearted performance from Oscar winner Mark Rylance in the title role.
A powerful performance by Matthew McConaughey and an earnest urgency drive the fact-based story... alas, those good qualities are undermined by a confused and overlong script.

DeGeneres has the funny bits down pat...But it's in Dory's quieter moments that (she) breathes a soul into her little blue character: Speaking barely above a whisper, she registers wonder, trepidation and, occasionally, heartbreaking sorrow.

Clooney and Payne share an uncanny knack for that wistful smile in the face of havoc; for conveying the peace that comes from having lived a life, from having seen disasters come and go, and from knowing that, one way or another, this too shall pass.

Little-known biological phenomenon: When a human body is shot, stabbed or punched really hard, it explodes like a balloon filled with ketchup. Also, heads and limbs detach with the ease of a G.I. Joe doll in the hands of a malevolent 3-year-old.
A good-natured walk on the mild side, as fondly remembered as a pleasant dream.
Like a big, looping knuckleball, Clint Eastwood's new movie wanders amiably, threatens to go wild, but in the end settles smack in the middle of the plate.
The cast is...perfect, especially Giamatti, whose soothing tones and reassuring demeanor nevertheless hint at closely held heartbreak.

Wilson's powerful story, which encompasses not just love, sex, race, oedipal clashes, betrayal and death, but even music and sport, has the scope of a Great American Novel. Washington and company do it justice.
Like all good kids' movies, it's more complex than it seems.
But [Alexander] Payne and co-writer Jim Taylor maintain their sense of humor, even if the film ultimately feels less like satire and more like a poignant brief for humanism
At two-and-a-half hours, with about nine separate cliffhanger endings, it's a bit long, but Johnson's keen visual sense, doses of humor and a couple of cameos buoy the film

Beyond painting Bloom as a young woman who saw an opportunity and grabbed it, the film's attempts at psychology don't pan out very convincingly. But for sheer voyeurism, this study of an illicit but unusually well-bankrolled demimonde is quite satisfying.
What should have been a cutting Hollywood satire is instead about as fresh as last week's issue of Variety.
...a run-of-the-mill courtroom drama that John Grisham could have tossed off between endorsing royalty checks.
The dialogue is sharp, and the story is highly plausible as Russian mail-order-bride thrillers go.
IHOPs don't pile on this much syrup.
A shoddy male hip hop fantasy filled with guns, expensive cars, lots of naked women and Rocawear clothing.
Sadly, Oscar-winner Swank is completely miscast and seems every bit a 20th-century woman, even in a corset and silly wig.
If you've spent a lot of time watching late-night cable, you'll laugh a lot.
One can't shake the feeling that Crossroads is nothing more than an hour-and-a-half-long commercial for Britney's latest album.
Much of it is existential mumbo jumbo.
Its freshman writer-director doesn't quite have the choppers to deliver it to a satisfying conclusion.
Black proves himself to be leading-man material.
For the preteen girls that are its target audience, On the Line delivers just what they crave... Everyone else, though, will be rolling their eyes.
The Hughes brothers (Menace 2 Society) have brought Alan Moore's acclaimed graphic novel to the screen with its icky thrills and rampant filth intact.
With its slapstick tone and cartoonish action, Iron Monkey is probably appropriate for all but the youngest martial artists.
Though it has an implausible plot and syrupy ending, Serendipity is nearly perfect as a date flick.
NATM gets in a few good jabs, but to call this a movie is to malign such thoughtful, well-constructed films as Dude, Where's My Car and Freddy Got Fingered.
Director Tom Shadyac takes the leftover sentimental goo from his Patch Adams and pours it all over Dragonfly.
Fans of the game and the genre will be disappointed with the lack of gore ... and everyone else will find what plot there is confusing and boring.
That best kind of B-movie; one that will have you alternately laughing, squirming in your seat and yelling at the screen.
Serving Sara is the kind of movie that should premiere on an airplane--it's lame but watchable, and you could read a magazine during it and still follow the plot.
Unlike the unconvincing disco flick 54, this movie completely re-creates the look, feel and spirit of a time and place in musical history.
While obviously aimed at kids, The Country Bears ... should keep parents amused with its low groan-to-guffaw ratio.
The special effects are top-notch, and the scene in which motocross racers are attacked inspires a certain glee, but after the first five or so hicks get devoured, it gets a little old.
Fearless Aussie Steve Irwin brings his TV show to the big screen with a corny but fun spy plot attached.
This powerful, understated tale of fathers and sons can proudly sit beside the great gangster films of Coppola and Scorsese.
Filled with clever writing, pop-culture references galore and ultrastylized art direction.
The freshest thing to come out of the Mouse House in a long, long time.
As predictable as the outcome of a Globetrotters-Generals game, Juwanna Mann is even more ludicrous than you'd expect from the guy-in-a-dress genre, and a personal low for everyone involved.
Director Doug Liman brings an indie sensibility to Bourne that has more in common with gritty '70s thrillers than anything from the last two decades.
Austin Powers is going to have to muster up every ounce of mojo he's got to out-funny this soul brother spy spoof.
A surprisingly effective thriller, outdistancing similar hooey like Sleeping with the Enemy and Double Jeopardy by miles.
If you're looking for something different, The Salton Sea may well be your fix.
The film's occasional flights into the absurd -- like an extremely compromising situation devolving into a group sing-a-long -- are real howlers. But the rest of this flick we've seen before.
A class act from its elegant opening titles to its intense, nail-biting climax.
City by the Sea would have been a TV movie-of-the-week without De Niro's name attached. That said, it's easily his most moving, nuanced performance in years.
Williams gets some genuine laughs, but otherwise this flick is pretty reprehensible.
A particularly anemic entry.
Succeeds only in being the most unintentionally funny film since Battlefield Earth.
What could have been light and sweet is bogged down by layer upon layer of schmaltz and sentiment, not to mention a rather ugly (on the inside) main character.
A pretentious mess.
A creepy thriller that gives Bacon his best role yet.
The casting is nearly perfect.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The best non-Disney animated film in decades!
The sum doesn't quite add up to the potential of its parts.
Lack of story, action and character depth.
Anyone with half a brain will leave the theater feeling cheated by its cockamamie premise and unoriginal styling.
While there isn't anything in M:I-2 as memorable as the first film's scene with Cruise dangling over a computer terminal, it's a more visceral experience overall.
The Rugrats team has come up with a funny, smart and genuinely moving movie that will please children and adults.
A dull, predictable and painfully unfunny comedy.
Stay far, far away from this laughably bad sci-fi action flick!
Kasdan makes good use of all the actors involved, and each one hits the right note -- Dean, Davis and Lee are particularly good.
Confusing, convoluted!
Finally, here's a TV-to-multiplex spinoff that not only matches but perhaps improves upon the original!
The script gives [the actors] virtually nothing to say.
Treads too-familiar ground, especially for anyone who has seen Return of the Secaucus 7, The Big Chill or this year's The Anniversary Party.
Exhilarating, visually astounding, thought-provoking and very, very funny.
Jason Robards gives the performance of his career as a terminally ill man trying to contact his son: He's so convincing, you fear for Robards' own health.
A muddled script and sloppy editing render the first half of the film nearly incomprehensible.
Gatliff's efforts may have been better spent on making a flamenco documentary.
As for the ballyhooed kung fu-inspired action, all that flying around is forced at times...
A quirky, clever surprise.
A piffle, but a cute one.
Even if you're nostalgic for, say, Galaxy of Terror or Death Race 2000, you're better off waiting for this one on video.
Characters and subplots fly in and out of the mix for no discernable reason as the story stumbles from one improbable situation to the next.
A well-constructed farce with more than its share of belly laughs.
One gets the sense that Thraves has seen one too many Mike Leigh movies.
Too many leaps in logic.
French and American senses of humor don't exactly mesh.
Even in his prime, Douglas couldn't have saved himself from this cliche-ridden script.
Plays like the most expensive Bon Jovi video ever made.
Though it doesn't quite rock, The Banger Sisters rolls along well enough.
The blatant disregard for reality might have been excusable if any of the execution was actually funny.
Hatosy shines beyond most of his teen peers, and Alec Baldwin could even get a Best Supporting Actor nomination.
Kudos go to newcomer Alison Lohman's unforgettable, star-making performance as Astrid.
Maybe you should let the grandparents take the kids to this one.
Stereotypes are eschewed in favor of well-drawn characters, and the hip-hop backdrop is integral to the story rather than a marketing scheme to sell the soundtrack.
Jack Black has played the in-your-face slacker many times before, but with a script written specifically to showcase his particular genius, he completely aces this exam.
The movie turns into another case of stupid people doing stupid things no real person in their right mind would do.
Forget trying to follow the convoluted plot. Just enjoy the expertly choreographed action and another killer Johnny Depp performance that steals the entire movie.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Horror fans that felt there wasn't enough bile-spewing in 28 Days Later will delight in the buckets of gooey flesh and blood thrown around here.
It's what the controversial and overrated Kids should have been -- unflinching and honest, but not bleak.
It's no Rushmore or Sixteen Candles, but The Battle of Shaker Heights is heads-and- shoulders above your average teen comedy.
The story takes a while to get going, but once it does, it includes a few Pulp Fiction-style flourishes and becomes a devil of a good time.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Breathes fresh life into the aging genre with a (sometimes morbid) sense of humor that all but removes sentimentality from the picture but still retains heart.
After a long string of bombs, Costner delivers a real winner that will remind people why he won an Oscar for Dances with Wolves.
The highest compliment than can be paid to Step Into Liquid is that even if you've never put a toe in the ocean, you will leave this movie wanting to surf.
S.W.A.T. merely aims to be no-nonsense entertainment and totally delivers the goods.
Watching Juni and Carmen dodge enemies and jump from platform to platform is about as fun as watching someone else play videogames.
Northfork will likely confound as many viewers as it captivates, but few will have seen anything like it.
Despite Berri's deft touch, the story is a little too slight to fill out the movie's running time, but engaging performances from Dequenne and Bacri make up the difference.
Once you give into this film's odd logic, its humor and charm will win you over.
Despite being entirely unrealistic, this is a mildly entertaining movie thanks to its breezy tone and a cast that seems to be having a good time.
Young boys may appreciate the flick's cool gadgets and gee-whiz sensibility, but fans of Alan Moore's graphic novel will be appalled. The rest of us will just be bored.
One of this year's most entertaining flicks.
The Coens have taken their trademark wit, style and rapid-fire dialogue and refined it into a lean mean laugh machine.
We're going to go out on a limb and say that Punch-Drunk Love will probably be the best movie ever to star Adam Sandler.

At times, the whole thing feels like a parody of the genre. Still, director John Woo makes all this nonsense thoroughly entertaining, full of the slow-motion explosions, Mexican standoffs and the doves you've come to expect.
A one joke film (and not much of a joke at that) that tries hard but mostly falls flat.
Delivers thrilling action, gorgeous cinematography, beautiful locations and Oscar-worthy performances.
One of 2003's worst, Honey lazily steals its story from a host of '80s musical-themed flicks.
April's attempts at cooking provide most of the laughs, and watching her trying to mash raw potatoes is worth the price of admission alone.

Writer-director Richard Curtis has jam-packed the story with too many characters and the whole thing borders on sickeningly sweet. But a fitfully funny screenplay and irreproachable cast keep you from suffering cinematic toothache.
For all the ponderous philosophizing found in Reloaded, Matrix Revolutions is surprisingly straightforward and more than a little cheesy.
The story is ... fascinating.
Solid family entertainment, but won't give Pixar a run for its money.
Even if you've seen it a hundred times, Alien can still make you jump out of your seat.
There's a good character study here somewhere, but Campion should have slashed the serial-killer plot right out of the picture.
David Zucker hasn't exactly breathed new life into the series, but he knows what old jokes still work.
Runaway Jury is guilty of perjury, but just barely gets away with it.
This flick's poo jokes are of a superior breed than you'd find in a Rob Schneider comedy.
A truly powerful portrait of community and lost innocence.
Kids may still giggle at the rampant diaper jokes, but this movie is hardly worthy of the Rugrats name.
It's easy to marvel at this film's epic scope and wondrous visuals, but we're left wondering how much better the original must be.
