The hints of political intrigue quickly vanish in favor of one protracted chase sequence that gets more laughable with every step.
This quiet, beautiful film from director Caroline Link puts a different spin on the Holocaust film genre.
Even if you judge it purely as a Bruce Willis action flick, Tears of the Sun hardly stacks up, with its flawed logic, black-and-white morals, paper-thin characters and anonymous videogame villains.
Borrowing liberally from Animal House, Revenge of the Nerds, and, believe it or not, Fight Club, this is one of the funniest, laugh-out-loud comedies in many a semester.
The carnage should leave horror fans laughing, groaning and squirming in their seats.
For a movie about speed, Biker Boys spends too much time spinning its wheels.
Clooney has not only made one of the best debuts since Spike Jonze's Being John Malkovich, but one of the best films of the year.
With the tiniest bit of effort, Wrong Turn could have been a fun slasher flick, but no one involved seems to have cared about anything but a paycheck.
The Hours is never morose. Instead, we feel the characters' strength onscreen.
Sandra Bullock and Hugh Grant make a great team, but this predictable romantic comedy should get a pink slip.
Though the screenplay -- written by the real-life Fisher -- seems a bit self-aggrandizing, even stone-hearted cynics would be wise to pack tissues.
Writer-director Joe Carnahan's visceral, hyperkinetic style mainlines you right into the story -- it's sort of like being pistol-whipped.
Extremely silly is more like it.

Viewed on its own terms, Treasure Planet is better-than-average family entertainment, but true fans of the Stevenson's novel will likely prefer Disney's more faithful 1950 live-action swashbuckling classic.
The plot snakes and forks like a mountain road, because it doesn't have anywhere important to go.
The best time Spielberg has provided moviegoers since Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.
You don't need to know anything about soccer to enjoy this massively entertaining film that scores on almost every attempt.
An occasionally fascinating but ultimately undercooked portrait of the young and disaffected.
Most action movies these days forgo the script in favor of slam-bang visuals and stunts, but Basic actually suffers from too much plot.
Zellweger and McGregor obviously had a blast making this movie -- and you'll have just as much fun watching it.
The comic moments are so forced that you expect a laugh track, while the dramatic moments have all the subtlety of Valley of the Dolls.
Makes the most of its low budget and has an abundance of heart to boot.
Daddy is more than happy to go for potty-training humor rather than real jokes ... But kids aren't likely to mind, and should be laughing straight through to the blooper-filled closing credits.
A fascinating look at addiction that's perhaps a little too clinical for its own good.
Nothing in The Lizzie McGuire Movie warrants the leap to the big screen.
Overloaded with meandering subplots, greeting-card sentiment and trite filial hangups, It Runs in the Family is as dull and embarrassing as watching someone else's home movies.
It's too often weighed down by clichés.
A hypnotic film that's as much about the mystique of Southeast Asia as it is about the insurance-scam plot.
Presents a realistic portrayal of the kids' complicated and confounding mental illness.
One of the most boring films in recent memory. Almost nothing happens.
The bait-and-switch ads for Bulletproof Monk promise something between The Matrix and Rush Hour, but what we get is one of the goofiest movies in recent memory.
Guest and his band of improvisers have come up with another funny and weirdly affectionate mockumentary.
Reworking the 1955 French film Bob le Flambeur, director Neil Jordan has crafted a classic of his own.
Solomon tries to convince us that reasonably sane people would be drawn to this mysterious man. In reality, you'd cross the street to avoid contact with anyone as obviously creepy as Manuel Jordan.
Despite myriad plot twists, it's a little dull.

It could have been a fun Twilight Zone-type thriller, but instead of genuine scares, it settles for spooky sets, good special effects and cardboard characters that are predictably killed off one by one.
Once again, the intelligence of gay audiences has been grossly underestimated, and a meaty plot and well-developed characters have been sacrificed for skin and flash that barely fizzle.
While Confession of a Burning Man manages to accurately capture the Burning Man spirit, it falls just short of capturing the entire Burning Man experience.
Pray's film works well and will appeal even to those who aren't too familiar with turntablism.
In this documentary, you get the feeling that people are actually listening to each other. It's refreshing in these times of Michael Moore.
Life In 12 Bars illuminates the relatively short distance been this public and private self...
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully funny movie with all the best that Jim Carrey has to give.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Superbly acted and visually impressive without being too 'artsy.'
An average film with a great group of stars.
The characters in the movie are hilarious.
A wonderful fairy tale with all the elements that make up the classics.
A movie that will finally appeal to those who can think their way through a movie but still want to laugh.
A wonderful mix of Lady Hawke and Labyrinth.
A surprisingly enjoyable movie with a storyline sure to hold the attention of those willing to involve themselves in the lives of these emotionally scarred characters.
The story is hard to follow and didn't seem to flow at all.
Full of one liners that seem to be more at home in a stand up routine than on the big screen.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The suspense that builds as you try to keep up with Cross will keep you on the edge of your seat.
Overall I'd say skip this one and see something a little lighter and a lot more uplifting.
Visually satisfying and extremely well shot.
I can't say enough good things about the actors in this picture.
I'd rather sit through The Animal again or go see Tom Green in a live show.
Washington plays the twisted character with a flair and sense of style that really fits his acting.
This one was truly funny. Full of imagination and creativity. Max is lovable and a bit mischievous all at the same time.
The plot moves along (albeit very violently) and you are drawn into the idea of discovering the identity of the killer.
A fast paced comedic race through the wilds of Alaska. Cuba Gooding Jr. and the dogs provide solid entertainment for the whole family.
A good story with solid acting.
The story is engaging and endearing.
If you enjoy good thought provoking sci-fi then you should really enjoy this movie.
Abbas could tell his interrogators nothing they wanted to know, but everything we needed to know about their tactics.
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Avenue Montaigne is a bon-bon for culture tourists.

Most of this winning drama shows [girls] bantering with their male keepers, boyish soldiers who don't want to miss the game themselves. Over the crowd's roar, they argue about Islamic prohibitions and the statistics of star players.
Manages to enchant with its simplicity and scenery.
This incisive film -- which opens with rare footage of angry monks throwing stones at Chinese troops -- nicely resists and complicates simpler views of the storied land.
The fight scenes are routine, the humor juvenile, and the Toronto locales rendered drab through muddy cinematography.
This scenic adventure is too fussy with metaphysical lore.
Briskly directed, The Valet hits the brakes for an abrupt ending, but this short ride delivers few apercus on fidelity, glamor or the nice boy next door.
An overlong exercise in sport as character-builder.
To maximize your return on this useful report, sit through the end credits where Spurlock deposits some of his best material.
Sounds like a soap opera. But Danish director Susanne Bier builds a high-minded melodrama from this plot material.
[Director] Glosserman can't match the wit of Scream, the fright of The Blair Witch Project or the satire of journalism seen in Series 7.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The charm of The Italian lies in Kravchuk blending a sentimental fable and a boy's action-adventure saga. He surpasses cliches and still delivers a novel finale that's heartwarming.
A witty, timely drama.
A gripping briefing on the post-Saddam morass of Iraq. The tactical calculus used by sheiks, insurgents, CIA operatives, soldiers, and civilians is ugly, but it's not inscrutable.

Maxwell continues his textbook emphasis on military maneuvers, but despite literally thousands of Civil War reenactors recruited for the film, the wide-screen canvas fails to map the tactics or evoke the terror of battle.
Among the squandered supporting cast are Dennis Farina, Chris Penn, Megan Mullally, and Seymour Cassel.

Commune channels a bygone era of drop-outs living an American dream on the Free Love frontier. This is the happy alternative to the apocalyptic California sub-cultures of Charles Manson and the Rev. Jim Jones.
Face-to-face encounters are affecting, if brief.
This exceptional film shows us the lower-echelon henchmen, the ones who enabled the master-racists.
movie_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Trial 1963-1965 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Armenian-American director Carla Garapedian, who got a doctorate in international relations at the London School of Economics, presents a wide-awake, high-decibel briefing on foreign policy.
[Director] Maggenti offers a cute variation on the classic Hollywood 'comedy of remarriage.'
Canadian director Jeff Renfroe builds only off-the-shelf suspense as Terry's suspicions increase.
Backstage reveals a tender, creepy transaction between idol and idolator.
Likable but negligible.
Badly dated, this sc-fi trip to the despoiled planet Dessa drags with social commentary.
movie_title: To the Stars by Hard Ways (1981)

movie_review_blurb: Steel City is a moving look at fathers and sons. [Director] Jun neither romanticizes nor pathologizes blue-collar family life. In this earnest rust belt indie, doing the right thing means tipping the scale of justice.
This experimental-style documentary invokes the waking dreams of David Lynch, Werner Herzog and Errol Morris. It's like a true-crime inquiry undertaken during a total eclipse.
The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai is far less silly than it thinks it is. The upbeat vibe of super-female power misfires with a gratuitous rape scene.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Perverse humor pervades the films of Lars von Trier.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Boe's technique has more flash than passion.
The director's existential sarcasm is muted here.
Punk's Not Dead serves as a diehard's scrapbook of three decades of living punk, not a eulogy for an extinct underground retrofitted as a fashion trend.
This Macbeth is true to the ugly-hearted original. No one is redeemed by gore, or absolved of madness. Nor do lines sound any less sublime when channeled through underlings and overlords.
If Machiavelli's The Prince and Sun Tzu's The Art of War translate to other centuries and cultures, so might Election and Triad Election.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Election feels routine at times, though less formulaic than other genre exercises from Hong Kong. The depiction of crime customs is sociologically detailed.
Slick cinematography makes this bland social comedy always watchable, but the movie has its insipid moments.
An unnerving riff on South Korean women fixated on the idea of ul-jjang ('best face').

Rock the Bells deals with the mechanics of how to pull off a concert, not with what brought Wu-Tang Clan together or split them up. The impressive teamwork of the promoters upstages the egos of hip-hop divos and their rampaging fans.
In the compelling documentary Six Days, Israeli director Ilan Ziv details the conflict that set Egypt, Syria and Jordan against Israe;.
An easy-viewing intro to a racy episode in art history.
Australian director Rolf de Heer deftly mingles two styles of storytelling: cinema and aboriginal oral customs.
A splendid documentary about one typeface, designed in 1957 in Switzerland.
[Director] Chernick's stylish yet superficial report looks more like an orientation video for museum visitors.

At 2 hours and 20 minutes, this zippy follow-up to Night Watch delivers a killer pace, blasts of heavy-metal, vexed characters, and gory allegory wherein occult terrorists suck blood, cast spells and escape to a spooky zone known as the Gloom.
I Don't Want to Sleep Alone is a title to keep in mind while absorbing this allusive, humid mood piece.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: On the index of quirk, this winsome indie scores quite high.
Resnais shapes affecting performances from a polished cast. He creates a warm, comic melancholy.
Delightful in places, the surreal stunts are lovingly crafted. As a seaworthy film, though, Fiona's folly is more pratfall than plot.
Chris Metzler and Jeff Springer found a strange place -- in California, of all places -- and made a video postcard about its colorful denizens and ecological calamity.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Splatter comedy meets comic splatter in this brash crossover film that puts seven white-collar workers in the scary wilds of Hungary where psycho killer Russian ex-military lurk.
The latest daydreamy film from this Thai auteur of languor is fragrant with tender love and sly humor.
Endless auditions get the annoying Francois nowhere closer to grasping what turns women on.
Goldberger and Giamatti strain too hard for strangeness.
Le Petit Lieutenant looks at Antoine's life with lyricism.

What viewers need to know -- if provoked by this film -- is there's far more nuance in Mary Habeck's book Knowing the Enemy: Jihadist Ideology and the War on Terror and Paul Berman's Terror and Liberalism.
movie_title: Islam: What the West Needs to Know (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bad edits include quick-as-blink cutaways, though not in any punkish poke-in-the-eye style. The directing is comparably incompetent, without any wink at DIY stardom a la Warhol.
In Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles his characters use digital communication appliances to send beautiful sentiments. Using old-school celluloid, so does Zhang.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Films like Top Gun and newscasts of 9/11 motivated some Americans to enlist. Thoughtful documentaries like The Ground Truth urge the rest of us to shoulder the consequences.
Zenide showcases Petre in a role of few words and much feeling. It's an auspicious debut in a sensitive drama, despite its less than original contours.
Cut with distractions: tweaky visuals, borrowed touches and cartoonish characters.
It takes time for this spare narrative to show its heart, but the wait is worth it.
Luminous, affecting, and at times humorous take on 9/11's aftermath.
This noisy, effects-crazed PG-13 adventure might work for 10 year-olds who are beyond Nickelodeon piffle and ready for Japanese splatter.
French director Andre Techine sketches a family with the usual flaws, but takes the unusual step of not fixing them.
Chatmon reworks many elements of Robert Townsend's erratic 1987 film Hollywood Shuffle into a fluent story that favors character over satire.
This spooky, quasi-sci-fi, psychological thriller is unclear about what's real and what's not -- and not in any interesting way.
Brazilian filmmaker Sergio Machado scores a strong debut with this look at young hustlers in a lovers' triangle.
Makes little sense as a character study, and borders on nonsense as a screed on race in America.

As if anticipating bad reviews, Russo ends his scattershot assault with a preemptive strike against the media: 'It's just the Federal Reserve System trying to save itself.' If you buy that line, then I'm the great-grandson of a 1913 conspirator.
I don't get it.
In this all-inclusive documentary, Alex Hinton introduces a spectrum of 'homohop' performers and spoken-word artists.
Composer Peter Golub adds swooning suspense, while cinematographer Albert Maysles, who has documented many Christo projects, frames rendezvous with tipsters tempted by the $5 million reward.
In his directing debut, David Vernon, formerly a first assistant and second assistant director, opts for the look of a cable TV pilot.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A semi-mythic period piece, Beowulf & Grendel offers sublime scenery that's breathtaking and bone-chilling.
Burtynsky calls for "a whole new way of thinking" about the world's economy and ecology, though he never says what's wrong with the old way.
Energetic documentary that efficiently ridicules GM for scrapping its electrical vehicle line.
Imparts a you-are-there atmosphere that's increasingly scarce as Western journalists retreat.
movie_title: The Blood of My Brother: A Story of Death in Iraq (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Moriarty, Pink and Bazzi sent back tape loaded with visual and audio detail, but the most moving moments of The War Tapes are their attempts to make sense of Operation Iraqi Freedom II.
A bracing docu-drama.

Craven has expressed a desire to get out of the horror business. Maybe that's why he's set out to make more than a horror movie. He's contributing to a long tradition of reflexive films, going back as far as the turn of the century.

Spielberg's dinos, manipulated by a small army of puppeteers, are watchable enough. But these artificial critters have little reason to be resurrected in our era, let alone on 3,300 screens over Memorial Day weekend.
The result is a teasing, if trying, exercise.

Wondrous Oblivion is a timeless tale of an 11-year-old South London boy putting aside boyish things. Writer-director Paul Morrison affirms PG-rated life lessons that could appeal to 11-year-olds and their elders alike.
It's a useful look at this Spanish auteur finding his way but lacks the elan of his later work.
Often entertaining.
This opaque tale offers meticulously crafted atmosphere, but rather less passion or drama.
A pleasant, crisply paced look at a wary character.
This informative documentary offers a sound, if uninspiring lesson in civics.

Can Mr. Smith Get to Washington Anymore? is an amusing case study in youthful enthusiasm for the electoral process, but this modest documentary skips the weighty issues posed by its namesake, the Frank Capra 1939 drama.
Zhang's script, based on Cao Yu's play, matches outlandish finery with outlandish bloodletting and body counts.
Co-directors and co-writers Eli B. Despres and Kim Roberts make their feature debut with an uneven teens-in-peril thriller.
Argentinian writer/ director Fabian Bielinksy (Nine Queens) creates a character with an intriguing set of traits that inspire an equally intriguing plot.
[Director Phillip] Bartell crafts some quips, but the momentum falters when he goes maudlin.
This unassuming drama of a nomad family brims with small marvels.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Director, writer and co-producer Richard Trank packages an alarming report with abundant news clips, quotes and interviews.
[Director] Stockwell delivers too little of the dread and titillation this genre prescribes.
Stage actress Sandra Huller delivers a stunning, understated performance...
Far smarter fun with filth, though, can be found in The Aristocrats.
Gritty, gimmicky.
Shooting in black-and-white 16mm, Bujalski nods to the pre-Sundance personal cinema of the '50s and '60s. His little circle of pals, though, offers little to outsiders looking in.
Entering his sixth decade, Chabrol remains a master inspector of the criminal heart of the French bourgeoisie.
This documentary on Miami's lethal '80s cocaine scene is cut fast.
For its retro-futurist look alone, this outdated thriller set in 2054 Paris is worth seeing.
Boasts a fertile premise but a sterile outcome.
Adultery, abuse, and astronomical art world prices are packaged with creepy background music and cliched close-ups of court records.
movie_title: The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A horse-drawn carriage crossing an expressway overpass promises a more subversive ride than Svankmajer delivers.
Marker -- something of a cine-sage known for his essay-style documentaries -- playfully decodes this unofficial icon of French street culture.
movie_title: The Case of the Grinning Cat (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Brooks overwhelms the lens with her magnetic eyes.
A compelling report.
Her teachings are trite.
Built on beats of deadpan timing and splendidly understated reaction shots.
This revelatory documentary lets us see what it's like to be an actress at an audition.
Roth ratchets up the retch factor.
Loktev creates a minimalist study of unfathomable faith.
Suspense is modest as world-famous artworks are finally installed.
Director Stephanie Soechtig gathers activists, doctors, kids, lobbyists, parents, politicians, reporters and teachers -- all with different stakes.

Ida reaches spiritual depth through affecting performances rendered in sublime black-and-white compositions. Cinematographer Lukasz Zal places faces in the lower corner of his frame to arresting effect.
Lovingly detailed with animated and archival imagery.
[A] scary inquiry.
Jim Jarmusch stocks his latest low-key indie with more than his usual characters in low-velocity drift.
Gripping and at times agonizing.
Frank Savich's diverting documentary lets the 85-year-old filmmaker revisit a saga from the mid-'70s: his stellar two-year failure to adapt Frank Herbert's Dune for the screen.
A nuanced romance for grown-ups.
Non-narrative films can be opaque in deep ways. Visitors slips into pseudo-profundity. That said, I'd see it again.
May errs, however, in styling this human interest saga.
Director Scott Derrickson and his co-writer, Paul Harris Boardman, deliver a routine procedural with unremarkable frights.
Like Father, Like Son is always wise about the quandary faced by the two fathers and the two mothers.
At Berkeley earns credit for documenting a distinctly articulate community.
Italian writer-director Giuseppe Tornatore... designs beautiful sets around Virgil, who holds the screen in nearly every shot.
Iranian writer-director Asghar Farhadi creates detailed characters in distinctive circumstances, bypassing script cliches of domestic tension.
Dhoom:3 is crowd-pleasing populist fare.
Writer-director Kerry Candaele incisively documents the ideological legacy of opus 125 in Chile, China and Germany.
movie_title: Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven's Final Symphony (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Atrocity and beauty somehow co-exist in War Witch.
A family implodes with a biting commentary on patriarchy.
This buddy/road film builds tension with its missing person quest in a border-crossing underworld.

Drawing on four news stories, writer-director Jia Zhangke portrays the plight of workers in the new China. Set in four provinces, A Touch of Sin is humanist critique of the country's turn to capitalism.

The quiet time that Johann and Anne spend during museum hours -- and after his shifts on trips around the city -- offer solace in their mutual solitude. Museum Hours is an introverted companion for its viewers.
How I Live Now offers adolescents a lovely vision of holistic healing in the same countryside.
[Writer-Director Will] Slocombe may not carve up his kin for Cold Turkey" but he serves a wry repast.
A disquieting film about testing faith.
Troell invokes '50's and '60's Swedish cinema: masterly black-and-white cinematography, philosophical angst, a lifeless marriage and loved ones visiting from the afterlife.
Puenzo's initial premise is more promising, though, than her sensational tone.
A smart, tender love story.
You simply will walk out -- or perhaps dance out -- of the theater feeling very happy yourself.
"The Handmaiden" is 145 minutes of clever, erotic entertainment.
An outstanding sci-fi film with an intergalactic language lesson.
An intriguing variant on the usual tale of writer's block.
Konchalovsky more recently directed "The Nutcracker in 3D." Set in 1920s Vienna, that PG-rated film trivialized Auschwitz. "Paradise" atones for that mistake.
Spritzes of humor skewer adults who are forgivably incompetent at managing their lives.
Serebrennikov deploys ornery irony in this scathing critique of a self-radicalized fundamentalist and local unbelievers.
This unpredictable portrait thankfully never defaults to the comeuppance of an overthinker.
Paterson's writing may never earn such notice, but his perceptions on everyday existence are a quiet delight.
This SF spoof eventually turns silly, but not in an interesting way.
Benaim forgoes any archival footage, capturing instead the texture of memory.
Ultimately the film's medley of interpersonal crises widens into a moving vista of modern Europe.
The films are enchanting for their irony, their humanity, and their reflexiveness.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 1 - The Restless One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 1, O Inquieto) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Illuminating German-Israeli documentary.
This moving, Oscar-nominated documentary is an odyssey of a tragic observer.
Hogtown is the most original film made in Chicago about Chicago to date.
Jean-Luc Godard is the acknowledged mascot, if not master, of intellectual cinema. In "Goodbye to Language 3D" the 84-year-old auteur... reprises his longstanding suspicion that words are worthless.
Servillo charms in his dual turn, then takes it up a notch when one brother shows off his childhood knack for impersonating his look-alike.
The masterful script deals with telling words.
The office comedy is weak. The gross-out gags are too safe. A covert lesbian crush is underused.
This thoughtful film is designed with taste.
Like too many films on athletes and artists, Keep on Keepin' On seems afraid of going over our heads by examining the technique of its two musicians.
A poetic if occasionally opaque film essay on the 1945 Battle of Okinawa.
A sweet tale of a sad girl who moves to a new place and meets supernatural pals.
Lobbing zingers at Islamophobes does not illuminate Islam.
Granted, "The Grandmaster" is not a primer on Chinese philosophy. Yet it may score as crossover cinema for Wong fans and Lee fans.
Zurich-born Stefan Haupt, however, interrupts his rapturous tour of this basilica with lackluster interviews.
Like A Hidden Method, David Cronenberg's drama about Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, Hannah Arendt takes seriously the life of the mind.
If you missed the first One Missed Call, made in Japan in 2004, you now can miss the American remake.
Live-in Maid is a study of two women who appear not to like each other very much, yet their link makes for a moving drama about friendship.
[Director] Swanberg nails the inane fun of youth.
Drawing a line between official and unofficial forces is irrelevant since both are paid with our taxes, Shadow Company throws light on that bottom line in the war on terror.
Artful framing and 23 peppy songs on the soundtrack lend a gloss to subject matter that alternately repels and fascinates...
'Hitchcockian' is the less than lilting compliment used to hype this Long Island noir.
Unfortunately, the couple's intimacy is not especially interesting.
This trivial film toys with the postmodern lifestyles.
After a promising start, Griffin Dunne's film bogs down and simply turns into a predictable mish-mash of a movie that is shrill and heavy-handed and totally trite.
On all counts, the co-directors of this persuasive documentary set the right tone.
A little voiceover commentary might add more than the sound of his panting.
This artfully muted film pays off with a desperate act of eloquence.
In its gore, Hatchet is not especially inventive
Osmond and Rothwell do a commendable job of mining a rich archive of material.
Don't bet on this Israeli drama exploding any cliches.
This verite digital video about coping with natural disaster contains exotic characters, tragic hardships, bureaucratic indifference, inner demons and the birth of a crack baby.
Dennis Bartok writes this lackluster anthology of four juvenile horror stories dripping with sexual dread and goofball gore.
Dans Paris has a lot of whining about women, interrupted with impulsive trysts and bouts of dancing.
International talents converge for an entertaining genre exercise.
The fright is crafted well enough, but the twist at the end calls for more originality than filmmakers David Moreau and Xavier Palud wield.
Unlike the intense cadets for Christ and creationism in the recent documentary Jesus Camp, the kids in the sweet Summercamp! have fun!
The camera work is always note-perfect.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Belle Toujours lets us peer at one master embroidering on the legacy of another master.
This stunning "documentary of the imagination" shows Anwar and other thugs staging scenes of torture and murder for the camera.
Moliere hardly matches the clever mockery of its 17th century inspiration.
Steep is a throwback to the early days of movies when the sight of things in motion was a thrill in itself. Seeing leaves rustling in the wind or waves on the sea was a marvel.
A blunt look at how anger binds generations.
Too bad co-writers/co-directors Debbie Melnyk and Rick Caine don't investigate -- and ingratiate -- the way their target does in his own films.
Smacks of an audition exercise.

Jia Zhang-ke is a new auteur making his mark. Embraced abroad on the international festival circuit, if less welcome on screens in China, this writer-director works in a genre that could be called globalist.
French physician Jean-Martin Charcot hypnotized, photographed and exhibited a hysteric, as does French director Alice Winocour for a clinical love story and empowerment tale.
Hungarian animator Marcell Jankovics adapts Imre Madach's 1861 poem for a pessimistic epic on existence. This illustrated theology lectures: after the Fall, no one is free.
Alt horror about a Seattle surgery drop-out is a mediocre specimen of the Canadian kinky flesh genre of "Antiviral," "Crash" and "Kissed." End credits say "For Eli Roth."
This coming-of-ager in suburban Ohio is confected with easy-pleaser fillips of pretty, including sylvan interludes of sophomoric lyricism.
Gushing "Googliness" with no trace of corporate cool in its design, this embarrassing comedy has an unoriginal triumph-of-misfits plot.
Ryszard Bugajski ("General Nil") turns a 2009 scandal victimizing Gdansk entrepreneurs into a political thriller with anti-state solidarity.
Documenting how five authors changed from anti- to pro-nuke energy stances, Stone is less persuasive at translating this logic into reality.
A theater director's wife directs an admiring diary, as he rehearses an Ibsen play. Andre Gregory fancies himself a shaman but just comes off as an irrepressible raconteur.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Who is "We" in the title We Steal Secrets? There's no need for a spoiler alert, but it's neither Gibney nor Assange.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Radical experiential/experimental video of bloody viscera and abstract beauty. Embedded/embodied lens as in Brakhage's "The Governor" and Geyrhalter's "Our Daily Bread."
John Cusack replays his role as a lethal operative with occupational angst for a routine thriller with a female cryptographer at secret CIA site. Dire workplace issues ensue.
Thou shalt not borrow, nor maim those who owe interest, preaches this obsessive auteur, offering one more near-mute seeker of justice. The tragic perversity is gripping.
Bay is an ambiguous booster of bootstrap Americanism with this perverse salute to numbskull entrepreneurship, with mantras for self-made manhood from a self-help huckster.
Perceptive and poignant, Caramel observes the love lives of the establishment's owner, her employees and their customers.
Screenwriter Kate Boutilier provides plenty of sharp patter.
This is vicarious cinema at its best.
It's laced with literate humor, and the directors cite N.C. Wyeth's illustrations for the 1911 Scribner's edition of Treasure Island as the inspiration for their marvelously detailed fantasy world.
How sick can fans of a celebrity get? Very, answers "Antiviral." Imagine fan fetish culture metastasizing. A pox on consumers and capitalists alike, Brandon Cronenberg sneers.
Despite the heroic exertions of the rafters and filmmakers, this apolitical film is oddly lacking in drama.
The girl and the hospital patients and staff also turn up in his improvised adventure, extravagantly garbed by costume designer Eiko Ishioka.
Jordan starts to tell an intriguing tale about living with fantasy but falls back on plot turns cued to the flashing lights of cops and paramedics.
A pleasing if not surprising sampler of apercus, bon mots and clips.
Unfortunately, the subdued tone only adds distance, not depth, to their unstated issues.
A good documentary that is good for you.
Double-billing comic and tragic tones, the biopic "The Look of Love" follows a father and a daughter over three decades in London's swinging Soho.
Re-imagining the Spanish cinema
While The Hours is certainly a triumph of photography, impeccable production design, costuming and editing, it is the cumulative emotional impact of its writing that carries the day.
The lagoon is the locale to which this new movie disastrously returns.
Emotionally, this film will leave you grim-faced and shaken. It hits hard where so many films aim and miss -- at the heart.
No matter your age, you will warm to the young men and women in Singles who are striving to find their balance in the pleasant ambiance of Seattle.
Its heart is so in the right place and its tableau so appealing that it's easy to come away from this sweet, scrappy film with a nice little buzz.
A drearily tame learning-and-growing homosocial comedy.
Local Color is a sappy brick to the audience's forehead.
A twee Danish comedy that alternates trite New Age psychological moves with outbursts of cartoonish violence.
A largely sentimental documentary of the final months of the Valhalla of New York punk clubs and the failed attempts to save it.
movie_title: Burning Down the House: The Story of CBGB (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Sex Positive uses the dual activist/sexual outlaw persona of "safer sex" pioneer Richard Berkowitz as a prism through which to view the life-and-death struggles of an era.
Structured like a comedy, but outfitted with only the most tedious sexual-identity riffs, generic characterizations, and no singular point of view.
A sibling drama of unsentimental urban grit and swooning lyricism.
It's a slug's-eye view of autumnal Greater Boston, remote when not sleazy; even when Mitchum and Boyle attend a Bruins hockey game, it's in the nosebleed seats.

Stephan Elliott is determined to contemporize a playwright whose rhythms, concerns, and craft are all permanently bonded to the '20s art of British sophisticated escapism, art being short for "artifice."
Huston's Wise Blood is a sharp, busy canvas that, like a man with a good car, doesn't need to be justified.
To the annals of romantic stalker comedies, the appallingly creepy Management adds pretension and may blaze new, jaw-dropping territory: the predatory Beast totally rehabilitates Beauty.
Sergei Loznitsa's choice to intersperse footage of smiling farmers and dogma-spouting steelworkers with folk dancers and village choirs throughout Revue doesn't feel flippant, or even discordant.

This Star Trek essentially turns out to be a war film, with the occasional philosophical timeout to discuss love, friendship, and duty until the next bone-crunching fistfight or multi-weapon rumble with the Romulans.
moothly compelling with its sleek, mass-produced shapes and beautiful minds that fetishize ergonomics and the ideal of perfectability.

Gael García Bernal and Diego Luna reunite in Rudo y Cursi to denigrate rubes from Jalisco as slow-witted provincial brothers and banana plantation workers whose unlikely rise to soccer stardom supplies the purported comedy.

Suggests that either video artist Michel Auder culled the wrong footage from a lifetime of compulsive camera-wielding for this "fictional autobiography," or was saddled by fate or egoism with an inapt subject.

One can at least partly embrace the concept that outing pols who torpedo gay rights is defensible and still find Dick's film too frequently a would-be sensationalistic bit of tut-tutting for queer Dems and their politically-connected friends.

Exasperating for its mundane narrative of youthful non-courtship camouflaged by Manhattan street-video naturalism, The Exploding Girl occasionally suggests mumblecore with less improvisation and heaps of undergrad preciousness in place of snarky ir

A revelatory howl against the still-gestating, $8 trillion-and-counting financial-services industry bailout, American Casino follows the money that changed hands, or account columns, at every step of the subprime home-loan scam.

If you're looking for an adultery- and revenge-fueled family melodrama so subdued that it keeps a hit-and-run fatality, cuckoldry, and murder entirely off screen, Three Monkeys is your movie and Nuri Bilge Ceylan your not-so-genre-inclined auteur.

Revanche is almost fatally reluctant to get its hands dirty, its milieu shifting on a violent twist from a grimy Vienna brothel to the rural exurbs for buckets of guilt, angst, and frequently clumsy metaphors.
Troell's lens doesn't consistently uncover the beauty and character we're asked to believe his heroine finds with hers.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A baroque high comedy of endemic corruption, Il Divo doesn't treat the early-'90s scandal that brought down Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti as a tragedy, thriller, or tale of long-delayed comeuppance, but with resigned wit and florid carica
Asserts that, under a tragicomic two centuries of home misrule, the most devalued citizens of Lima have failed to be consigned to the limbo ("el olvido") the oligarchy has constructed for them.
Director Kevin Macdonald can't begin to approach the paranoid genre mastery seen in the films of John Frankenheimer and Alan Pakula.
American Violet has the necessary anger to engage its subject but also the generic topical-telefilm aesthetics that often render it glib and inauthentic.
At best a cute anecdote that scrapes by at just over 70 minutes.
An immigrant's saga more than "a baseball movie," Sugar ultimately runs headlong away from the clichés that mar formula sports-related narrative films.
The lost-world aura of the film's clumsy youths provides an inexorable dig into Brezhnev-era diffidence.
The heart of Mottola's autobiographical paean to young male mortification lies in the one-on-one scenes between his able leads, Jesse Eisenberg and Kristen Stewart.

Unmade Beds, with its occasionally twee chronicling of pogoing in funny hats and heart-to-hearts between NSA lovers, portrays its seekers as planets aspiring to bubblehood, or at least one tandem leap into the void.

With a plot recalling the fevered fictions of Jim Thompson, late Polanski, and Isabel Allende, The Fish Child banks on the sizzle of its pair of young female stars and their enactment of class and erotic tensions to flavor its Sapphic noir melodram
The problem is not the farfetched contrivance of Humpday, but how unmoored it seems from anything but self-satisfied cuteness.
A much duller tale than its Irish literary festival setting would suggest.
Taxidermia is merely slimy biological vaudeville.
In his career-debasement race against Al Pacino, must Robert De Niro inflict a moribund genre botch like Everybody's Fine on the public just in time to grinch us up for Christmas?
Ricky's quicksilver changes of mood and genre make for an engaging puzzle, but its last notes of transcendence seem insufficiently earned.
The long-delayed results don't make a great case for having dusted it off.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Oberzan is mostly successful in revitalizing the dime-store psychology and blood n' guts of First Blood through storytelling as childlike play.
movie_title: Flooding With Love for the Kid (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There might have been deeper currents of envy and displaced shame to plumb in the case of Girl on the Train, but for once this reliably penetrating filmmaker hasn't found them.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Slogs through an hour of frequently rote exposition until it hits its riveting groove when the rappelling and piton-hammering take over.
Pippa Lee is conceived as a portrait of a woman's long-delayed emotional blossoming, but its dopey, privileged-set fantasy winds up as obvious as crawling through Keanu's open window.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The post-King era of American racial tension demands better from dramatists than lugubrious historical pageants like this.
Before VH1-style unmaking-of-the-band clichés undo it, this rockpic boasts a pair of live-wire performances and some pioneering same-sex passion.
A frequently mundane ramble that doesn't often put its raison d'être on the screen.
This seven-part documentary about the decades-long fight to dismantle the murderous apartheid government of South Africa does not bend to the Great Man theory of history.
movie_title: Have You Heard from Johannesburg?: Apartheid and the Club of the West (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A Gallic counterpart to American indiedom's immigration melodrama The Visitor.
A would-be eccentric thriller not quite saved by Jim Broadbent's spectral, wacky performance.
An unholy genre mutation undreamt of on the isle of Dr. Moreau, An American Affair piggybacks the pubescent sexual awakening sapfest onto the JFK assassination conspiracy thriller.
A flimsy opportunity to rubberneck at the misfortune of a profession where the summit of aspiration is "getting lied to by a higher caliber of person."
The dualities that abound in Jean-Luc Godard's 2 or 3 Things I Know About Her are ubiquitous at whatever starting point one chooses.
movie_title: 2 ou 3 Choses que je Sais d'Elle (Two or Three Things I Know About Her) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Say Anything was a singularly three-dimensional teen romance after a decade of broad gags and breakfast-club stereotypes in John Hughesland.
The picture is hugely pleased with itself, but it's too funny and expertly calibrated to mind in the least.
That Hamilton Woman gains much from Leigh's playfulness and placid beauty.

An enviro-doc that doesn't soft-pedal the fact that the calculated, consciousness-raising media event it chronicles is a conceptual stunt, No Impact Man manages to present its New York do-gooder couple as both likably idealistic and inevitably conf
Chooses not to follow the money but one man's evolution in the pursuit of principle.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps as a result of channeling Ozu, Denis's incipient humanism comes through more directly than in her existentially forbidding The Intruder or even her acclaimed, baroque Herman Melville remix Beau Travail.
American Journey works only sporadically as a supplement to the cultural moment it chronicles, and the passionate, serendipitously intimate breadth of Frank's lens.
Even more so than in the previous film, The Yes Men Fix the World indulges in faux-naïve disappointment.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It'd be tempting to call it ambitious if the large emotions felt by its subjects were transmitted in terms other than the increasingly common tropes of the family-therapy doc.

The bilingual parrying between the withholding diva and her frustrated chronicler often seems like Sunset Boulevard re-imagined as a radio play, with sex removed from the equation but marlenus interruptus aplenty.

Director Katherine Dieckmann, who demonstrated some natural comic rhythms and efficiency with actors in Diggers, is here unable to surmount the sitcom dreariness of her first original screenplay, apparently a "write-what-you-know" misjudgment.
This immersive tour of the mortal manipulations fueling Europe's 17th-century cultural capital supplies wit and intellect while it starves the emotions.
It's still an eye-catching, fast-paced watch.
A jokey mess so far from the humane, satirical alchemy of Three Kings that a revocation of the producer-star's cinematic passport to the land of military-industrial japery seems in order.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to think of another movie of its era that makes the viewer so fully feel like a denizen of its setting; the roving, dollying, craning camera makes angels of us all.
His oft-spoken use of Michelangelo's David as a personal symbol of the individual's decision to bring "power to the people" gives better insight into this jurist's fiery heart than any case study.
Gives a convincing, contagious taste of its protagonist's playful optimism.
movie_title: Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A still relevant call for communion among diverse African-American communities, and an elegy for an activist-artist.

Crediting his passion for boxing with helping him find God, babyfaced welterweight fighter Dmitriy Salita seriously knits his brow in devotion to the rituals of Orthodox Judaism and professional pugilism in Orthodox Stance.
The crude-dude genre staples are mechanically rendered: gay panic in a biker bar, mescaline-fueled dreams, highway chases, and cancer.
Call it embalmed screwball.
Surely two decades of TV's post-Bochco dirty-cop dramas have removed this kind of potboiler not only from claims of artiness, but from expectations of being taken seriously.
Glass's status as one of America's most venerated and mocked highbrows matches gracefully with his peripatetic cultural and spiritual life.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Handicapped by an unavoidable postscript that even nonfans are apt to recall: the eventually fatal injury in the Preakness Stakes to Derby winner Barbaro.
A diverting but cool suspense puzzler whose payoff proves to be smaller and more mundane than its twisty, fluid setup.

Morris's signature touches can occasionally seem studied to the point of annoyance but the cumulative power of his busy, artsy style generally enhances the horror, making it no more palatable than necessary.
That Stop-Loss wears its generally good intentions on its camo sleeve doesn't keep it from being consigned to the missed-opportunity file.
The dominant Maddin is the narrating filmmaker, more palpably present than usual in the sound of his voice, bemoaning a lost golden age of his hometown faced absurdities of the tall tale.

Mathieu Amalric's glorified cameo as a thumbsucking baby-behavior fetishist is evidence that Kreuter uses her silly streak to enforce simplistic narrative roles: adolescent and gender-dysphoric cybernauts cool, all others ludicrous.
movie_title: 57,000 Kilometers Between Us (57000 km entre nous) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At its best a winning anecdote of adolescent male awkwardness adapting to the big city.

Malta's tourism industry will likely survive A Previous Engagement, a mirthless rom-com that sadistically strands once-prime comedic players Juliet Stevenson and Daniel Stern on the sunny Mediterranean spot in a protracted, sub-sitcom scenario.
The directors balance portraying an everyday sense of the adolescents' wartime anxiety with the more commonplace juvenile relief.
Akin's Head-On infused its hellish misfit romance with in-your-face violence; here even two violent deaths are rendered discreetly to the point of bloodlessness.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even less funny than Southland Tales and not nearly as adventurous.
For all the use of first takes and jerky camera moves, the John Cassavetes invoked by Baghead is not the indie pioneer saint but his Faustian thespian-husband character in Rosemary's Baby.
A fable light on condescension but committed enough to the pleasure principle that the audience is served one giddy act of visual sorcery after another.
How dismally arch and self-satisfied can a Chelseacore sex comedy get?
The ethical nitwittery of "fight so you don't have to fight again" and invocations of The Iliad in this context brazenly transform a dumb bone-cruncher into a putridly dissembling one.
A sour, self-satisfied dramedy possessing the same embarrassing chutzpah as its cocky-dinosaur seducer.

Where the original was defiantly not a concert film, but a chronicle of the astonished hubbub surrounding the first hipster folksinger, the follow-up's treasure lies with seven intact live performances.

Setting the action wishfully in the hilarious year of 1988 for hair and fashion points, writer-director Roger Paradiso throws a pall of desperation and contempt over his throng of caricatures before they even leave the church.
A quieter, shorter but scarcely less idiosyncratic specimen of Rorschach cinema than Inland Empire.
Both technical grace and an efficient ensemble smooth over some...clunky plotting.
This watchable but indulgent curio blings up the petty vanities and ambitions of the criminal class, and lays greater themes in their graves.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Under the Same Moon aims to get audiences to blubber at the trials of mother and child but doesn't persuasively put convincing flesh on people caught in the immigration firestorm.
The mythic nuttiness gets under your skin just as these archetypal figures gradually penetrate each other's subterfuges, skulls, and orifices.
Among the recent wave of music documentaries on the marginally infamous, this video history gets its juice from a love-hate affair with the vibe of a graying boho remake of The Sunshine Boys.
As for the nuts-and-bolts of political strategy, Nichols navigates them as prosaically as he did in his last treatment of a sybaritic pol, the trivial Primary Colors.
Director and co-writer Joseph Cedar loses all goodwill accumulated by his competent, plausibly close-knit cast with heavy-handed use of clichés.
A moral tale that isn't saddled with moralism, The Witnesses is a novelistic film in the best sense.
The umpteenth film incarnation of Henry VIII's marriage to Anne Boleyn, The Other Boleyn Girl races through the events at the Tudor court like a triple-time miniseries.
The anomic gloom that envelops Frownland, a miserabilist, micro-budgeted 16mm freak show, fatally impedes its seeming aspirations to the mercurial grit of Cassavetes.
Possibly the feeblest entry yet in the anti-corporate theatre-of-muckraking genre.
Grounds the life-and-death struggles of the downtrodden in the quotidian: where to sleep, how to get clean, who to love.
movie_title: Great Speeches from a Dying World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Operation Filmmaker occasionally verges on damning its subject--one of the most gripping characters seen this year on film--for being a cagey, arrogant, single-minded narcissist, but hey, that's showbiz.
Trumbo is most focused when it lets the man and his peers testify directly.
The sizzle of the bon mot%u2013tossing ensemble, intact from the stage original, is bracing and fuels the film's momentum.
The General isn't likely to be the favorite opus of the star's purist fans, but it's the one with the trappings of ambition and historical poesy
The novelty of the franchise reboot hasn't so much worn off as been squandered on a scenario lacking in genuine thrills and long on ill-advised navel-gazing.
An accomplished generational anecdote ... the subject still feels mostly like "just a football game."
Sembene never descends into the one-note shrillness of Spike Lee at his worst.
Frost/Nixon is a trivial afterword to a historical footnote, a showbiz story inflated into a retroactive therapy session for one of 20th-century America's biggest knaves.
Cannibalizes both the Stax/Motown era of soul music and the shopworn road movie with an equal lack of freshness.
Iconic from the get-go.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)

movie_review_blurb: The German moral tragedy of the Nazi era is obscured by the movie's ostentatious arsenal of tricks and toys.
A character study of a Nazi quisling that's frequently too muddled to reach even the level of banality.

Mondo Video is far from the most refined or successful expression of O'Donoghue's darkly antic vision, but its spray of seething, occasionally fetishistic buckshot is unmistakably in its master's voice.
Baldwin took a similarly fanciful history-mining approach for Tribulation 99, but Mock Up on Mu is more than twice as long and determinedly more obscure.
A literary fantasy with a charm deficit.
As fine-looking a 3D stop-motion fantasy that four years of top-flight craftsmanship can produce.

Gran Torino being a Clint showcase helmed by the Last Movie Star himself, Walt's reformation is nearly inevitable, but skirts being cloying on the strength of the 78-year-old icon's raspy brusqueness.
An unwieldy spoof-thriller of clashing styles that undermine each other like a parade of double agents.
A true tall tale that unfolds like the Great Unwritten Cold War Rock Novel.
Leans on players in the policymaking game as talking heads on issues and tactics, people with a personal stake in the outcome to fully humanize the issue and a few who straddle both categories.
Jacques Tati's Trafic serves as a scaled-down but inescapably fitting companion piece to its predecessor, the monumental Playtime.

Leesong Hee-il's miserabilist l'amour fou might seem on its surface to lack either the Sirkian glow or Fassbinderesque kick to make its melodrama work--and it does, but Leesong seasons the familiar hokeyness with some flair.
Beneath the meditative procession of sites, Gianvito layers an anxiety built into most viewers' gaps in 17th-to-20th-century U.S. history.
While not primarily intended as prophecy, Watkins's tale of Shorter's reign and fall has resonances of celebrity activism from Bob Geldof to globe-hopping lobbyist Bono.
A Shirley Temple movie camouflaged as political Capra-corn.
One of the period's most piercing, emotionally anguished romances.
In under 20 minutes of screen time, Jeanne Moreau supplies One Day You'll Understand with an otherwise absent emotional weight of reconciliation to the anguished history of WWII France.
Dite's limited awakening is neither tragedy nor the kind of bitter, fatalistic farce seen in Lina Wertmuller's Seven Beauties.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An anti-conspiracy lampoon of conspiracy thrillers, the Coens' Burn After Reading paints its floundering Washington inhabitants as intractably or even fatally stupid.
Its poetics of insurrection still resonate with any armchair anarchists who've even fleetingly wished death to their oppressors.
Choke makes its source material's everything-but-the-kitchen-sink absurdism broader, less expressive and cheaply reductive.
Lacking characters as cartoonishly entertaining as the bee geeks in Spellbound, director Caroline Suh doesn't dig deep enough.
This incarnation of Johnny Got His Gun is a mismatch of medium, text and talent.
An overblown nearly-real-time documentary-cum-"art installation."
movie_title: Zidane, un Portrait du 21e Siècle (Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Newman remains watchable and glamorous throughout, bloody, muddy or coated in torso-flattering sweat, but the film's efforts to sentimentally "humanize" him by psychological revelation are clumsy.
Disney-Bruckheimer digital pulp with no instincts for derring-do or beefcake inspection.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The restless, mini-DV-camera-shot visual style of Lior Shamriz's semi-improvised fiction matches the wanderlust of its twentysomething gay hero.
The result isn't drama so much as a waking nightmare of play-acting and predestined doom.
Endng in risible bathos, Tony Kaye's urban high school melodrama is all about the cute teacher's crises and the girls who love him.
Its director's romantic sensibilities wed to Terrence Rattigan's 60-year-old play, this period drama is buoyed by Rachel Weisz's poignant embodiment of a bourgeois wife seeking erotic autonomy.
This handsome mate-swapping drama never moves beyond the erotic to become incisive about the barriers built into sexual experimentation for committed couples.
A night of reckoning by a hoodlum in his haunted former home is a more sober and remote Freudian farrago than one expects from Guy Maddin.
This doc on the many forms of human debt, though often frustratingly broad, offers a path to balancing civilization's ledger with a hard-nosed brand of altruism.
A surprisingly shapeless true-crime farce which never creates a convincing context for the odd relationship between a pious East Texas mortician and his sugar mama.
An egregiously dopey mushfest where the only sparks between the stars are Nicholas-like.
A semi-documentary essay of two female climatologists at work in a mountaintop weather station imbues nature and labor with a poetry of the seemingly eternal.
A righteously outraged documentary targeting the "warm and fuzzy" iconography of the breast cancer fundraising bureaucracy and its camouflage of corporate priorities.
A direct-cinema document of the Cairo protests that toppled Mubarak, Stefano Savona's film doesn't pretend that Egypt's resolution has yet won a lasting victory.
This odd hybrid of in-search-of-mother quest and lurid border-town pulp shows a humane intimacy mostly in touches borrowed from the filmmaker's estimable parents.
"With age comes exhaustion," according to a rueful line late in the film, and it serves as a fitting diagnosis for Woody Allen's latest fallen souffle set in a European cultural capital.
Even with its (likely dictated) propaganda on behalf of the now-superfluous 1942 edition, this set restores a high watermark in cinematic comedy to nearly full glory.
A Slovakian character study of a boy ambivalently caught between worlds that ultimately squanders its promise.
A mixed bag of Nixon-era pop burlesque and vampire kitsch is ultimately undone by pedestrian gags and bloated genre boilerplate.
The layered, character-driven drama may subvert expectations of a sunny Venetian noir, but observes its five principal characters with a probing, egalitarian eye.
This potential rock-doc tragedy reveals a bromance of idol and idolator.
Re-employing the tools of Jacques Tati and Jerry Lewis, this pleasant fable reclaims artful slapstick with a bliss that's hard to deny.
A would-be dark, self-congratulatory dramedy that lacks both transgressive laughter and honest engagement with its themes of death and teen depression.
This deeply dopey travesty's worst instincts are nearly its only entertaining ones.
A digestible, globetrotting primer on the future of cities filled with bracingly plainspoken professionals and practical optimism, despite a few sketchily drawn crises.
Werner Herzog's tale of death and life is thoroughly shaped by his humanist passion and attention to emotional details.
A sometimes pedestrian multi-plot drama which authentically captures young Iranians caught in cultural and existential limbo.
The beloved gang's sweet reunion will melt nostalgic adults into laughter and tears, and maybe kids won't mind drippy new Muppet Walter so much.
A dry dream of postmenopausal-male sexual lethargy, this comedy's least musty ideas are among its worst.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Steven Spielberg's The Adventures of Tintin is a wittily kineticized adaptation of the internationally loved comic books.
A freeform, New York-based variation on the Arabian Nights tales by Jonas Mekas is both a pan-narrative and a disarming portrait of its sweetly curious maker.
Both brutal and sentimental, this Oscar-submitted Korean war drama offers up rusty tropes as telling ironies.
A bubbly 90-year-old mascot from the golden days of the American musical, this doc's subject is certainly larger than the conventional testimonial treatment she's given.
Unusually successful in synchronizing the ethos and oeuvre of its protagonist with its own visual strategies and rhythms.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A solid, affecting artifact of the cruelty of late 1950s South Africa, in which music often makes despair and long-suppressed anger bearable.
Showing its social jaundice between grotty bursts of violence, this acidly comic late-'60s noir lets Tuesday Weld's teen queen with a taste for mayhem out-psycho Anthony Perkins.
A documentary of bareknuckle fights among feuding Irish Traveller clans can't give the participants' self-perpetuating, dead-end rivalry the scope of tragedy.
Jonathan Lee's talking-head interviewees successfully bear the burden of making the iconoclast's dogged and prickly personality nearly tangible.
A historical melodrama that retains an ancient, elemental pull even as it insufficiently charts motivation and the self-denying values of antiquity.
A lumpy spoof of electoral mudslinging that offers some bracing bipartisan contempt amid the lowbrow, labored slapstick.
The Peter Landesman film's overt politics are minimal, aside from defaulting to the myth of John F. Kennedy as a martyr for...something.
An unnerving, all-archival account of Philadelphia citizens suddenly terrorized by the unchecked violence of rogue "law and order."
It's a pity that it hews to sitcom-like formula rather than using this bank of knowledge and sympathy to create something more original.
Jacques Demy and Michel Legrand's reinvention of the movie musical has tinsel, Technicolor, and a beating, broken heart.
movie_title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (Les Parapluies de Cherbourg) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: The film doesn't temper enough of Cormac McCarthy's excesses, but Ridley Scott and his ensemble find enough meat in his scenario to make for diverting, bloody pleasure.
This Polish "gay priest tempted" drama is almost as confused about the moral quandaries of its characters as they are.
Another well-upholstered but cheap exercise in luxe pandering that fails as romantic farce.
LisaGay Hamilton and Yolonda Ross persuasively embody modern urban feminine strength, but they're eventually stranded in a recycled road movie.
D.W. Griffith's masterpiece, likely the most influential film ever made, has been given new life with a gold-standard digital cleanup.
Bille August's film is a protracted, soporific trip into Portuguese history that would like to be a romantic thriller.
This pair of hour-long docs depicts a community of agrarian or hard-laboring citizens without condescension and with a touch of populist poetry.
It chronicles the quest of a self-described "geek," and there are pleasurable frissons of discovery in the detective work.
Dino Risi's well-cast leads can't quite sell his heavy-handed irony as truths about masculine character.
Godfrey Reggio's symphony of pristine 4K images doesn't add up to one grand epiphany, but an intermittent cluster of small ones.
Though its ballast of jokes and spectacle are formidable, it often lurches about at a remote, enigmatic distance.
An ostensible Danish Hangover that more closely resembles Two and a Half Men with nudity and unexpurgated dick jokes.
It bubbles with an optimistic portrait of a happily married young couple, and a lively gallery of supporting characters worthy of a Preston Sturges farce.
The debate over the evolution of the movies' depiction of native peoples is not always on the mark.
A serviceable primer on the digital-celluloid divide in commercial cinema, if a bit unwieldy in scope and in danger of being made obsolete by the next version of the RED camera.
This adaptation of a prize-winning Australian novel is a stodgy slog save for some sporadic moments of blunt force supplied by Judy Davis and Charlotte Rampling.
In a character study of an ex-con who gives her heart and mind to animals rather than people, Melissa Leo's risky performance is ultimately framed with a disappointing, distanced pity.
While crediting free-form radio pioneer Bob Fass with changing the culture of broadcasting, this doc remains clear-eyed about the decline of community radio and the New Left.

This chronicle of two athletes throwing baseball's funkiest, least respected pitch is given depth by their stranger-than-fiction underdog status and camaraderie with mentors who've had the same struggles.
A rock-doc that mythologizes the tragicomic flame out of power pop's seminal band, and the fan-made afterlife that brought them long-delayed success.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An overmatched star and a scarcity of eccentricity sink this hip-lit origin story from director John Krokidas.
Sensitively performed and laced with some forceful, quotidian grit, the film evades the larger questions behind a scandalous shooting death.
Lost in the music, mustaches, and furniture of the early '70s, this docudrama of a porn star's exploitation isn't nearly painful enough.
Sincerely angry about the crisis in polypharmacy, this narrative suffers from a documentarian form of A.D.D.
Ken Urban, adapting his own play, fumbles at injections of urban, and decidedly not urbane, levity, in addition to telegraphing entire subplots.
The film forsakes most of the underdog sentimentality found in traditional genre treatments of noble sacrifice.
A counterproductively "literary" film with no satisfying payoffs, Rutger Hauer's blind recluse notwithstanding.
Billy Bob Thornton's ensemble Southern family dramedy fails to subvert its cutesy formula often enough.
The Frankensteinian rebellion of orcas against their corporate captors turns this doc into a sort of showbiz horror film.
Drained of its stars' onetime giddy spirit, this is an Olive Garden farce for audiences who don't hunger for authentic wit.
Ultimately comes off as curiously anecdotal, lacking the dramatic dynamism that could give Marcel Pagnol's tale new life.
A wan road comedy with pretensions that can be jettisoned for the inevitable John Travolta remake.
Hall Pass zips along crudely but amiably on its sitcom-episode conceit.
A and B love C, who's oblivious, but Xavier Dolan only wrests a few chuckles from the old "is he or isn't he" tease.
An anecdotal, frequently evocative debut feature chronicling a teenage pickpocket's restless life in a Kashmiri town.
Ed Helms seeks post-Hangover glory as a meek Midwest insurance peddler out of his depth, but John C. Reilly steals this patchy wild-weekend farce as Mr. Bad Example.
Pasolini's second film showcases Anna Magnani with a minimum of sentimentality in a bleak, pitiless Eternal City of the early '60s.
This documentary of a makeshift community of Chinese citizens caught in a Dickensian charade of Beijing bureaucracy finds hope among the hopeless and pride in the hearts of outcasts.
A comedy of an Oslo gangster's fumbling attempts at post-parole living ticks off all the twee requirements of this apparently deathless subgenre.
Sylvain Chomet resurrects an unrealized, melancholy Jacques Tati script with the bittersweet beauty of hand-drawn animation.

Another romantic comedy triangle from James L. Brooks, with a scandalized executive coming between paired athletes--but neither the dialogue nor plot supply an answer (or a question mark) to the title.
Weaving performance and interview clips into an autobiographical collage on behalf of storyteller Spalding Gray, Steven Soderbergh delivers a poignant eulogy.
A cocooned, sub-generic drama of downsized executives which locates tragedy in the loss of suburban opulence and white-collar perks rather than self-annihilation.
Jim Carrey, as a queer con artist motivated by undying passion for a cellmate, brings a euphoric energy to this insubordinate farce.
This confounding potpourri of satire, sex comedy, and medical soaper smothers some good intentions and its robust stars in a genre-identity crisis.
Two loners in an Irish coastal house negotiate their emotional distance in this debut feature, with an implausible script undermining strong performances and visual ambition.
Best-case fallout from this joyless TV-land lemon: Harrison Ford is driven into retirement, Diane Keaton gets a morning show.
A plodding B-movie that exploits "don't ask, don't tell" with cheap psychology and cheaper thrills.
A somewhat hoked-up, intermittently satisfying recent-history tale that nearly limits the Plame-Wilson affair to a crucible in its principals' marriage.
Attempting to explore the dissonance between great art and a damaged artist, this documentary more often luxuriates in Spector's venom and self-regard.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film ends with a semi-touching reaffirmation that everybody's in showbiz.
A pedestrian picaresque that trivializes the suffering and yearnings of hardscrabble youth.
A middling docudrama of a pivotal Cold War espionage case is bolstered by Emir Kusturica's gloomy but idealistic KGB renegade.
Not up to adequately framing the title's question, let alone answering it.
This tedious, occasionally risible melodrama is a clumsily unconvincing portrait of gay romance in a neo-fascist underworld.
When it comes to setting up the rules for its unearthly puppetmasters' agenda and sticking to them, this fantasy adaptation doesn't know Dick.
George Clooney is a somber, guilt-wracked assassin hiding out in mountainous central Italy-but despite the bleak sheen and Anton Corbijn's spatial dexterity, the script goes all Up in the Air.
Lionel Rogosin's semi-documentary is an unflinching document of skid-row denizens, and humanist cinema at its unsentimental best.
As a chaser to Affleck's last offering of pungent Beantown brew, The Town is near-beer.
A vintage relic of the last century's most celebrated war-crimes trial, which contains implicit questions about applying equivalent judgments against recent wagers of "aggressive war."
A seemingly random tour of three French villages comes with a few sneaky grace notes on mortality and daily endurance.
Wild Target neatly and boringly makes a surrogate family out of its ill-matched trio of caricatures, and its epilogue of domesticity is enough to make you reach for your revolver.
Hitchcock's manipulative classic of "pure cinema" does have a heart that pumps human blood, in its sublime parlor scene between Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh.
As a pregnant, reforming junkie, Isabelle Carré nurses François Ozon's latest rumination on mortality and maternity to success.
A slick making-and-unmaking-of documentary about the play and film that first seriously addressed American homosexuality, and its complex role in queer cultural history.
A historical superproduction in which style, aside from committee-made, widescreen tedium, is spectacularly absent.
Despite the well-trod dramatic territory of Brontë's classic, Mia Wasikowska and Michael Fassbender stand out amid the windswept moors and woeful secrets.
This generational touchstone remains a playful widescreen fable of the bestiality that defines and destroys cultures.
This autumnal statement compensates for its fixed despair with bracing wit and a willingness to see acceptance of misery as the best of all possible options.
A grim lamentation for victims of sex trafficking in postwar Bosnia is buried beneath rote filmmaking and cartoonishly rendered villainy.
Director Mike Ott's second narrative feature cannily plays its intentions close to the vest.
Programming the Nation? fails to stick to its stated subject or to coherently fit it into well-trod America-as-propaganda-mill boilerplate.
Bereft of both spiritual and narrative spark, the loss-of-faith drama Higher Ground gets stuck in the valley of the shadow of snark.
A teen-misfit dramedy of innate decency and few surprises, with a trio of young pariahs enduring emotional wounds that fade rather than scar.
Gutting what made Graham Greene's crime-lit classic unique, this pointless re-setting of the noirish fable fails to bring its puerile antihero to compelling life.
A smoothly fractured history of a broken mother-son relationship, which even in its climactic tragedy keeps messy emotions at arm's length.
movie_title: I'm Glad My Mother Is Alive (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A harrowing oral history of the AIDS epidemic in San Francisco whose spine is the freshly recounted horror of an "avalanche" of grief.
A trio of paper-thin plots spun into a cutesy shard of stale ribbon candy.
This sentimental tale of a barely literate man's awakening at the hands of an elderly bibliophile is generally as painless as it is hackneyed.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A wavering, intermittently smart story of daring to think differently that often flattens its narrative into formula.
Michael Shannon's haunting performance as a blue-collar Ohio man victimized by schizophrenia carries this dread-infused character study.
The film is at its best when its mythologizing is carnal and infused with cabaret, and not making the inflated claim of its title.
Preaching to the converted, a sobering but formulaic study of church activism against gay rights is more therapeutic than astute.
A muddled would-be epic of the Chinese Communist Party's founding, this all-star propaganda pageant plays like an incoherent lesson plan.
movie_title: The Beginning of a Great Revival (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Katie Galloway and Kelly Duane de la Vega's documentary doesn't let its duped young crusaders entirely off the hook.
Even Bradley Cooper lapping thirstily at a pool of blood can't save a dumbass sci-fi fable on the perils of increased mental capacity.
So soon after Deneuve and Depardieu's sublime work in André Téchiné's Changing Times, Ozon's froth looks especially trivial.
Meant to celebrate the heroism of Palestinian women, Julian Schnabel's decades-spanning drama is mostly stilted and incomplete.
The gleam in James Caan's eye is about all that illuminates this moribund comedy about a ring of Buffalo hoods who infiltrate a Buffalo staging of The Cherry Orchard.
The vitriolic comedian's career gets a photo-animated documentary treatment which drowns out his voice with a chorus of friends and family.
A New York artist of Middle Eastern background tries to mesh resistance and romance in Zeina Durra's '70s-textured seriocomic debut.
...a living testament to American callousness toward norms of international justice and the likelihood of reaping future enemies from the scapegoats among the interned.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A mother-daughter tragedy presented in a cinematic hall of mirrors, The Arbor aestheticizes its grim nonfiction narrative with mixed results.
Mel Gibson's passion is vanquished by his collaborators' retreat into boilerplate sentimentality.
The guitar solos blasting from Joseph Gordon-Levitt's sullen, arson-prone wasteoid's van can't drown out the dominant bleat of indie-therapy whine.
The 1937-38 massacres and rapes in conquered Nanking are dramatized with flawed but unflinching horror in this grim, epic lament.
An affecting chronicle of artists fighting eviction from their historic Carnegie Hall studios against the full power of a corporatized New York institution. Guess who wins?
Hitchcock's rich and strange fable of love lost, and lost again, makes the case for him as a grand experimental artist who labored in genre cinema.
Those who find Rohmer heroines difficult might even be won over by the depth and poignancy of Marie Rivière's Delphine.
A Spanish Civil War story ill-married to a saint's biopic, Roland Joffé's muddle is sunk by three unfocused narratives, clunky dialogue, and Wes Bentley.
The Lottery insufficiently dares a more probing documentary approach in addressing the crises surrounding inner-city education.
Even the inescapable hype cannot diminish the fact that this is one great film.
[Some] may be taken aback by the exhibition of sheer ego in what is clearly a form of replacement therapy for those whose ambitions exceed their talents.
The drawings of Eric Orner's comic strip on which the movie is based are more animated than the actors who fail to give any dimension to their characters.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In trying for realism, Machado only achieves dramatic inertness. His three fallen characters drift through life with no purpose other than to satisfy their immediate physical needs.

Purporting to expose the role of American public-relations companies in foreign political campaigns, Our Brand Is Crisis is never more than a dull and confused film about Bolivia's 2003 presidential election.
The most ridiculous period film since rappers took on the Old West in Posse.

The movie is funny without disrespecting its characters. But there is a sadness at its heart, because, although the possibilities for romantic happiness diminish after the age of 65, the dynamics of sexual attraction and coupling never change.
Laurent Cantet directs his adaptation of Dany Laferreiere's La Chair du Maitre as if it were a Danielle Steele novel.
The Groomsmen, while as corny as a Staten Island marriage proposal, rings true on many levels.
This is a film about brave women who left home as teenagers and have been on their own ever since. Now, nearing the end of that road, they face their inevitable decline with a cheerful vivacity.
The fleeting emotions of domestic conflict are captured more succinctly than any film since John Cassavettes' A Woman Under the Influence.
What the world knows of Chile in the 1970s, it knows through the films of Patricio Guzman.
First time director Lynn Shelton breaks too many narrative laws for it to work as a feature.
From lovely touches such as a group of bananas resting on a wooden railing, to a gorgeous sequence filmed in the unearthly Stone Forest, Zhang is a master of detail and spectacle.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There are worse things to be found in the slimiest corners of the Internet, but this second film installment of the MTV series brings the lowest excesses of webcam exhibitionism to the mutiplex.
An exceptional Italian film becomes an average American one in this bland remake.
Works better as a sad meditation on the spiritual hopes of a poverty-stricken people than as a portrait of a charismatic guru.
