What is ultimately so special about this film is its handling of the relationship between Lennon and wife, Yoko Ono.
Then-and-now footage of aging legends such as Erkin Koray and Sezen Aksu offers an insight into the musical continuum that bridges a rich heritage with a promising future.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With wonderfully natural performances by the children, this is a family movie that crosses cultural boundaries in a celebration of the magical possibilities inherent in everyday objects.
Recommended for its endearing performances, captivating locations and a poppy soundtrack that amiably underscores the bubbly sensuality of a summer in the sun.
Not only are the shifts in time unclear, but the film lacks a stable emotional tone.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Johnston's obsession with self-documenting his life by means of amateur films and tape recordings has yielded a wealth of material from which Feuerzeig has fashioned an often fascinating portrait.
Captures both the spirituality and humanity of monastic life.
Actors Laia Marull and Luis Tosar explore the intricate details of a relationship based on the laws of attraction and repulsion, in which the intellect is repeatedly devastated by primal passion.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Documentary on the struggle to bring justice to a Cameroon village.
The film comes to life when Cohen is on screen.
Not since the collaborations of Godfrey Reggio and Philip Glass (Koyaanisqatsi), have music and visuals been so satisfyingly combined.
'Why don't you just flush the money down the toilet?' asks one character. The same might be asked of the people who produced this bomb.
A thrilling and scary ride through the side streets of a third world that is rarely seen in the movies, and carries a revolutionary message that is frightening in its political implications.
The film plays like a 1950's B-movie with artistic pretensions.
Marchbanks captures the essence of a melting pot neighborhood where economics, not race, is the dividing factor.
An inspirational portrait of an unwanted kid who brought culture to a world that had known only violence.
Clark's vision of Los Angeles, where extravagant fantasies and inner-city social issues wildly intersect.
Cuesta ... has a weak grasp on the behavior of contemporary youth.
Wooley is more interested in emulating Nicolas Roeg's 1970 film Performance than in making the story his own. In style and content, this movie is a weak imitation.
Provoking more ideas than it presents, Vajra Sky Over Tibet is a sketchy introduction to a fascinating subject.
movie_title: Journey into Buddhism: Vajra Sky Over Tibet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The concert footage, which is exceptionally well photographed and recorded, offers clips of varying lengths from a wealth of songs. The rest of the film glimpses the stress disorders that can develop when average people with problems become popular.
movie_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film About the Pixies (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Offer insights into the director's methods and motivations.
So extreme in its sacrilege that it achieves a kind of sacredness, The Holy Mountain is a transcendental feast of the grotesque and the sublime.

Director Michael Polish and his co-scenarist and brother Mark don't fall into the trap of trying to redo Frank Capra. They have their own approach to the material, with an eye for the eccentric amid the commonplace adding just the right touch of humor.
At nearly three hours, this overlong and repetitive film is not for everyone, but patient viewers will find their time well-invested.
... captures the open-air rock festival experience more completely than any previous film of its kind.
Most of this is harmless enough, but Kasdan's Hollywood logic is simply too implausible.
It is a frightening epitaph for what is surely one of the 20th century's most heartbreaking cautionary tales against giving one up to the will of another.
In its best moments, The Cats of Mirikitani captures both the tragedy and transcendence of his life.
The script is undone by confusing romantic developments, a convoluted murder mystery and a facile and maudlin resolution.
Scenes that should be revelatory, such as a lyric-writing session, are sketchy and fail to give a sense of the work being done.

At times the film is a bit random and rambling, but these vignettes are an invaluable record of life in Ireland during the '60s, with the final images of children running through the streets a symbol of hope for an unfettered future.

As in his previous films, such as Crimson Gold, director Jafar Panahi does not embitter his story with acrimony, but lets the absurdity of its situations bear silent witness to the injustices portrayed.
Director Denis Dercourt proves there are still unexpected twists to be found on the well-traveled road of the revenge mystery.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Both a history lesson on the birth and death of an American city and a portrait of people who refuse to give up on a dream. It is also a grass-roots ecological tract made up of equal parts science, folklore and kitschy nostalgia.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Life on the freeway is hell, but what comes next for these workers might be worse.
The cast is perfect, but the script is like a low ceiling, keeping a lid on what should have been a confluence of riotous misadventures.

[Writer/director] Lipsky has something to say about the impossibility of human beings to love each other, but his language is that of an amateur playwright who does not know when he is only repeating cliches.

From his irritating squeak of a voice to an infantile stage presence that includes dressing himself as a multifruit-bearing tree, Smith's comical incompetence wins him the adoration of adolescent misfits.
The script offers neither character revelations nor plot twists. It unfolds by the numbers, like the product of an amateur screenwriter's salon.
There are shocking facts and supportive images, but the film lacks investigative spirit.
Where is Bret Easton Ellis when you need him?
movie_title: Love Is the Drug (Addicted to Her Love) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is full of fortune cookie aphorisms and stilted literary phrases that were never meant to be spoken aloud.
The definition of liberation as the act of being delivered from the hands of one lunatic into the hands of another who is equally mad remains universal in its political and social applications.
Clips of dozens of bands, including DOA, TSOL and SS Decontrol, are as short and fast as the music itself in this informative look at one of the youth culture's last grass-roots movements.
For its first half-hour, Cedric is the whole show.
Writer/director Marc Rosenbush's first film, from the false toughness of its surface to its soft, pulpy heart, will please neither aficionados of the detective genre nor devotees of Eastern religion.
When the little girl tells her decapititated doll, 'It's not just a bad dream,' she is right. It's just a bad movie.
It is a heartbreaking story of betrayed trust, broken faith and the misuse of privilege.
The film suffers from its non-linear approach to the subject.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The most dishonest thing about this ranting montage of a movie is its technique of panning between opposing viewpoints to simulate debate, when in fact each of the more than 35 celebrities was separately interviewed.
... The Architect is filled with ciphers and symbols, without a smidgen of narrative reason to hold it together.
Walters is alternately zany and poignant, with Grint the perfect foil, a bemused, confused innocent who only wants to do good.
Director Francois Ozon, who can define physical desire in a swift gesture or extend a moment of self-reflection with acute stillness, has become more confident and specific with each film.
A portrait of repentant convicts that is both heartbreaking and unnerving.
Sprecher's facile nihilism overwhelms the petty gestures of goodwill that are intended to exonerate her isolated characters.
CSA is best when inventing, not amending, history.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A film that will stand as an essential document on one of the world's most spectacular obsessions.
Enchanting and mesmerizing film, in which reality is often mistaken for a dream.
Berlinger and Sinofsky, with their knack for penetrating the diabolical pretensions of weak and disaffected human beings, have brought Metallica to its knees.
By no means a good movie.
It fails ... to deliver a balanced portrait of the man's life and work.
movie_title: Tom Dowd and the Language of Music (2004)

movie_review_blurb: With the exception of some minor glitches in the sound synchronization and a nighttime performance of The Band's 'The Weight' that is uncharacteristically grainy, the film looks and sounds great.
A film as multifaceted and monolithic as its subject.
A warm exception to coming-of-age stories that accent the tacky and vulgar aspects of adolescent awakening.
Captures the infantile fantasies of rock 'n' roll's self-made messiahs with an honesty that is rare in today's MTV world of promotional entertainment.
Despite picturesque episodes and nicely observed characters, the film lacks suspense.
There is little in this film to interest those who are not groupies of the Ramones.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some iffy moments, Lighting is the closest one to get to the music from which, as Hubert Sumlin notes, 'there is no retiring. You stay with it until the end.'
For such a downbeat story, the film is full of humor and vivacity. The characters, though frustrated and delusional, are fully realized by the exceptional cast.
The reconstruction is a bigger, longer and better movie than the one released in 1980, but is less than the revelation for which one might have hoped.
Those audience members whose gullibility has not been thoroughly tested may find themselves in search of a new Herzog film that could prove as elusive as the Loch Ness monster itself.
Mario Van Peebles, bearing an uncanny resemblance to his father, illuminates the soul of a man driven by a belief in himself and a love for his community.
As a portrait of a collaborative artist at work, the film is an invaluable document, not to be missed by anyone with more than a passing interest in theater.
Despite its shortcomings as objective reporting, Power Trip offers a glimpse into a sputtering culture that, after decades of communist rule, has little chance of survival in the modern world.
A television director and two musicians have made a miracle of a movie that is both fairy tale and slice of life.
Pumpkin wants to have it both ways.
Not since Jean Luc Godard filmed the recording sessions for the Rolling Stones' Sympathy for the Devil has a filmmaker gotten this close to the creative process of musicians at work in the studio.
movie_title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The film makes a strong case for the importance of the musicians in creating the Motown sound.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: While providing a total immersion in music and politics, its ultimate effect is a whirlwind of images and assertions that leave few lasting impressions.
movie_title: Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Commentary from shockingly outspoken Watts residents on topics ranging from revolution to infidelity are a vital part of the documentary, as are the several Richard Pryor monologues upon which the film is structured.
A love letter to the state of Montana and a landscape that is biblical in its desolation and splendor.
A strange and convoluted film that is as rewarding as a Dylan song, and just as perplexing.
As a film, Gigantic is excessive and poorly structured.
A strange and challenging film that questions a world in which human beings can be so easily defined by the uniform they wear.
Although it leaves something to be desired as a true-crime expose, Stoked raises compelling questions on the nature of celebrity.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Gooding's performance is burdened with an unnecessary complexity that works against its comic potential.

Take an amateur playwright with an ax to grind, a novice director without the slightest idea of what he is doing and an actress who confuses sleaze with grittiness, and you have the makings of a first-rate flop.
MTV offers an airbrushed portrait that does nothing but perpetuate the myth of an 'angelic' hoodlum.
A proud and optimistic testament to the youthful spirit of seniors who refuse to let such a trifle as their failed lives get in the way of a bit of fun.
Kurosawa's mysterious film about Japan's disaffected and alienated youth.
A confused and improbable redemption song.
Director Uwe Boll (House of the Dead) has made a cottage industry out of this kind of junk. Maybe it's time for him to close up shop.
The film's themes are undermined by a heavy-handed use of paradox and symbolism.
A film that succeeds both as biography and poetic travelogue.
The perfect cup of bubble tea for those struggling with philosophical issues such as 'What is happiness? Making clothes or wearing them?'
Amounts to little more than pictures from a family album.
Get Rich or Die Tryin' is a disaster on all levels.
Just Friends is a dumb teen comedy.

Brown has put together a heartbreaking yet inspiring portrait of a transcendently tragic artist through home movies, family scrapbooks, live performances and interviews with ex-wives, record producers, and peers.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Pucci communicates both the physical and intellectual awkwardness of a perceptive teenager who has difficulty communicating his ideas and feelings to others.
Chilean director Andres Wood sharply observes and re-creates the era.
Demme maintains visual interest by shuffling the stage positions of the musicians, and changing the lighting design for each song.

Writer/director Wayne Kramer's approach to storytelling is to withhold any information that might give away the plot. The film is a string of violent confrontations between characters whose relationships to each other are unclear.
A state of the hip-hop nation address that should be seen by everyone who dismisses rap music as violent, misogynistic and sociopathic.
It is all very sketchy and superficial.

Those who only remember metal as an MTV aberration from the 1980s will learn a lot from Dunn's film, and metal heads will find vindication for their dedication to a music that has been condemned and dismissed as infantile and depraved.
The originality of subject matter makes it an inspiring reminder that we can be whoever we want, not limited by the experiences that have molded us.
The embittered men make fascinating subjects. Although innocent, they have been deeply scarred by their prison years.
Undiscovered promotes one of the stupidest visions of the entertainment industry since American Idol opened the celebrity gateway to the dregs of the karaoke generation.
Sorin's charming road comedy captures the humanity of small-town dreamers.
As a sports documentary, Murderball is tame and uninvolving.
Where other documentarians look for a charismatic personality to enliven their films, Berlin and Fab focus on the community as a whole.
His career was brief but well-documented and Andrew Horn's loving tribute includes several complete performances.
The film may prove too nerve-racking for casual viewers. It is a racing movie for the inside track.
Ripe with offbeat Americana, Beesley's rockumentary is also a portrait of growing up in a white-trash Okie ghetto.
A sublimely subjective journey from denial to acceptance as a 10-year-old boy comes to terms with the finality of death.
movie_title: Dyskoloi apohairetismoi: O babas mou (Hard Goodbyes: My Father) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Deepened by the socioeconomic undercurrent that suggests the lengths to which workers are forced to prostitute themselves to survive corporate downsizing.
Those who know the band only through its recorded work will be amazed to see it in action.
movie_title: We Jam Econo: The Story of the Minutemen (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Just another trashy look at America as the land of imbecilic perverts.
Shinkai Makoto, who made the 30-minute 'Voices of a Distant Star' by himself on a laptop computer, has written and directed an anime that favors human emotions over robot battles.
movie_title: The Place Promised in Our Early Days (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A trip reminding us that, while we continue to explore space, we have yet to fully penetrate the mysteries of our own planet.
Rize does not so much report on a cultural phenomenon as package it.
Insists that we live with our mistakes since there is no escaping them.
A trite and troubled script makes it more a visual tirade than an engaging odyssey.
Fascinating as these spiders and frogs must be to one another, a human being need not be put into such close proximity to their private dances.
Writer-director Craig Brewer has made a sensitive, low-key drama that values human life, no matter how degraded the circumstances.

movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Successful on a visual level, but fails to fully import the play into the modern era.
The dark, rotting interiors and sunless winter skies create a festering atmosphere of unexpiated guilt as Kremer ponders the question of how a decent man is to navigate the rivers of hell.
Just another high concept/low content entry into the blockbuster market.

Rather than keeping the camera aimed at the stage, Young collaborates with television journalist Mile Cerre to fashion several 60 Minutes-styled episodes on things he wishes to either promote or expose.

Who would have guessed that, in this age of excess and one-upmanship, when bigger is always better, the year's most romantic screen kiss would last a mere two seconds.
A dog watches its blind master tune a piano. It's only 10 minutes into The Silence Before Bach and already I am bored as that dog.
movie_title: The Silence Before Bach (Die Stille vor Bach) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's strongest asset is Shane Clayton, whose Kenny is the funniest thing to come out of Australia since Crocodile Dundee.

movie_title: Monster Camp: The Story of NERO Seattle (2008)

A masterpiece on all fronts.
movie_title: Ningen no joken I (The Human Condition I) (No Greater Love) (1959)

movie_review_blurb: A young man's plans to become a hotel magnate are thwarted by the fickle finger of history in this comical eulogy for Czechoslovakia.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It is an enlightening lesson in modern warfare.
Water Lilies is that rare film about female sexuality that is made for females to relate to, not for males to fantasize about.
Although rich in family scrapbooks and anecdotes, Scott Hicks' documentary on composer Philip Glass is a portrait of the artist in the present tense.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

For those whose idea of hilarity is an adult and a kid throwing fireworks at each other, then getting stoned and playing piggyback in the mall, this movie should be a refreshing tonic.

Unlike the worthless torture porn that is destroying the genre, Stuck is a horror movie with a reason for being.

... might have made a fascinating story were it researched more thoroughly and presented with clarity.

This is indeed the nerdiest rock documentary on record.
This German rip-off of Herk Harvey's 1962 Carnival of Souls replaces the junky eeriness of the original with a disassociated pretentiousness that is more irritating than creepy.

An allegory of our times, Shotgun Stories is a tragedy of biblical scale and an intimate family drama.

movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Brings home the tragedy of being ahead of one's time in popular culture.
Flow might be alarmist propaganda, but with an estimated 20 years left before California's water supply is used up, it might be time to respond to the alarm.
Rosset is a lively subject, and his interviews (over many years) provide an oral history of his life and times.
That the ending makes no sense doesn't matter nearly as much as the fact that we wouldn't care even if it did.

Contrary to its title, Virtual JFK is less a counter-history of the Vietnam years than a tribute to John F. Kennedy's stubborn resistance to a military that pressured him to go to war on six occasions during his short presidency.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: When Hill and Moore leave story and characters behind to veer off into suspenseless chases through cornfields, one wonders if the era of earnest American drama may be coming to a close.
These six tales only scratch the surface of our phobic subconscious.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As a movie, it doesn't amount to much more than an after school-special with sex and profanity.

Children and undiscriminating adults may enjoy the flurry of eye-catching activities that storm incessantly across the screen for its 2 1/2 hours, but the reigning stupidity of the enterprise is liable to tire anyone else in attendance.

Troell's profound insistence that life -- even in its most miserable chapters -- is an occasion for rejoicing, goes beyond gender politics to a place of transcendent sublimity.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of suspense, we get frustration at the stupidity of the characters.

Jens Hoffmann's perceptive portrait of Norwegian base jumper Karina Hollekim.

David Volach's understated condemnation of religious extremism makes its points in lethally solemn tones, with neither caricature nor ridicule.
Director Takashi Miike's dish of sukiyaki spaghetti ala Sergio Corbucci is badly seasoned with scraps of reservoir dogs.
H.P. Lovecraft has a history of mistreatment in the cinema, but nothing comes near the abomination of Cthulhu, which not only desecrates Lovecraft, but film craft.
A naturalistic mix of vulgarity and romanticism gives this independent effort a mainstream appeal.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: more likely to depress voters than to galvanize them.
[Director David] Mackenzie has reined in the strangeness to deliver a conventional, if better than average, mystery.

Although first-time director Christina Clausen presents this era of bad art, bad music and boring celebrities without judging it, we can't help but feel we are witnessing the last party in the mansion of pop art before its imminent collapse.
Wang fails to integrate the philosophy of Li's fiction into the action of the story.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Followers of the new Japanese cinema will enjoy getting an early look at new styles by emerging talents, but these are essentially student films that are not likely to be embraced by the casual moviegoer.
Despite its sometimes creepy tentativeness, XXY succeeds as a meditation on gender and sexuality, one that refuses an easy answer to the question, 'Is it a boy or a girl?'

Director Jia Zhang-ke sees the urbanization of China through the eyes of the relocated laborers.
For an idea of how Humboldt County plays, imagine a Lifetime original movie about a loveable but pathetic couple who passed their druggy lifestyle on to the next generation.
A heartfelt tribute to a human being by those who loved him.
The cast does excellent ensemble work, with each of its members contributing to the overall effect rather than seeking opportunities for star turns.
An initially hilarious picture that grows perplexingly trite as screenwriter Peter Straughan transforms Young's sly observations into assembly-line pap.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Loaded with graphs, facts and statistics, it is too weighty a lesson in economics to be digested in 90 minutes.

While the animation is only so-so, Mamoru is a good storyteller with a firm grasp on both the story and characters.
movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Too many of the scenes, however, are the standard fodder of which mediocre movies are made.

For those who enjoyed the camping experience as a youth, the movie, with its marshmallow roasts, canoe rides and talent shows, offers a bit of nostalgia. Others may find the whole thing a little pointless.

Director Brown has made a career of chronicling the history of American folk music, and Pete Seeger: The Power of Song is a worthy companion piece to his 1982 debut, The Weavers: Wasn't That a Time?
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With the discovery of films and audiotape from the first solo, non-stop nautical race around the globe, Deep Water promises to take us where we have never been.
This cornucopia of foibles, with its penny portraits of treachery and innocence amounts to little more than high-class soap opera.
An inspiring portrait of a saint battling for the lives of the sick and forsaken in a frightened and superstitious world.
A dreadfully obvious and predictable romantic comedy.
Westfeldt's screenplay and Cary's direction combine to make it the best Manhattan love story since When Harry Met Sally.

Gavras does not impose a political viewpoint upon her material, but respects the convictions of her various characters.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Dynner delights in presenting a wealth of contrasting testimonies, and has no intention of delivering a judgment on any of it.

Although it offers an invaluable record of a self-destructive artist at the end of his life, it is also a repellent exploitation of this artist's decline.

The first of a two-part film about the life of an 11th-century Tibetan mystic, Milarepa evokes a time when sorcery was a poor man's way of making war, and the sight of yogis flying through the sky was commonplace.
Julien Temple has assembled a complex portrait of a human being and the times in which he lived.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A chilling example of how an average person's liberties can be curtailed in the era of the Patriot Act.

Regardless of its shortcomings, there is a variety of break dancing on display here that will bring the viewer up to speed on the state of the art.

Certain shots evidence Ellis' skill at composing static images, but his messy staging of a soccer game, a painful piece of failed slapstick, proves he has not quite arrived as a feature film director.

... a top-flight example of cinematic storytelling ...
... a complicated tale that exposes how a credible case can be built upon perjuries and fabrications.
It doesn't make for much of a movie.
El Cantante is a special film, one that refuses to package a person's life into a comfortably familiar genre.

While there are some points of interest along the way -- such as a dissertation on the recruitment and training of resistance fighters -- we emerge from this patchwork of viewpoints with no real picture.

Moore redeems herself from the mediocrity of her Brat Pack years and the career-killing mistakes of early adulthood. Having matured into a convincing middle-age actor, she comes across as intelligent, sophisticated and driven.
Like a television show, The Hammer wields that mysterious power to keep you watching even though you know it isn't any good.
Lost in Beijing tells the story of a man who, when his wife becomes pregnant after being raped by her employer, enters into a series of financial negotiations with him.

movie_review_blurb: The Singing Revolution becomes a tense political thriller that culminates in one of the most significant events of past century: The collapse of the Soviet Union.

Over the six hours spent with Fox as she jets around the globe, a picture emerges, not only of a modern woman contemplating herself, but of Western society boasting of its freedom to a world struggling for mere survival.
movie_title: Flying: Confessions of a Free Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Most political films involving children are vicious or sentimental. The Year My Parents Went on Vacation, set in 1970 when Brazil was under the military dictatorship of General Emilio Medici, is neither.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A moving and touching documentary.
The camera is discrete, the characters humane and the mood introspective in director Sam Garbarski's character study of a lonely woman who finds dignity where others might see only degradation.

Interviews with the mothers and footage of the birth process combine to offer intimate portraits of women preparing for and experiencing this natural phenomenon that has become increasingly mechanized.
It is a small message, but a sincere one, about the solitude that separates us, and how the expression of this solitude can bring the unlikeliest of people together.

In a genre that has been battered by the cheap grotesqueries of special effects, it is a pleasure to be unsettled by something as simple as an invasive beam of light in the shadows of a haunted house.

movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Iranian director Majid Majidi... takes his place alongside Robert Bresson as a master of sacred cinema. His Iran is a place of natural beauty so intense that even the sightless can experience its splendor.
The film's first half contains a series of sharply satirical scenes.
A dull and dreary film that derives its entertainment value from exploiting the sociopathology of its central character.
movie_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun (2006)

movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With each turn of events being telegraphed well in advance, there are no surprises in Sayles' script. The cast, however, headed by Glover's complex portrait of a man plagued by his past, is fresh enough to cover the stale plot mechanics.

Remains stubbornly one-dimensional.

By removing the edges that gave the man's life some bite, Martin Scorsese hasn't done George Harrison's legacy any favors.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Challenging, intermittently engrossing and unflaggingly creative. But it's too long and too convoluted and it ends in a muddle.

Though state-of-the-art technically, I think you'll find there's a healthy, old-fashioned feel to this movie -- one that will make you walk out of the theater feeling satisfied, and all warm 'n fuzzy inside.

It's a sweet and uplifting film, and though quite predictable, gives us a family drama that showcases simple truths about overcoming seemingly impossible odds and leaves you with a warm and very satisfying feeling deep down.
Overall, it feels lame. A disappointing revival of a classic character.
It all boils down to a horrible waste of talent.

Yes, this is a road we've traveled down before, but at least this time, it's paved with a lot of charm and heart.
27 Dresses is one heck of a happy date movie. Smiling faces are guaranteed on all seen exiting when the credits finally do roll here.
One of the funniest movies to be released so far this year.

Suspend your ideas about what is logical or truly real and just have a nice 90-minute escape into the brightly colorful world directors Cody Cameron and Kris Pearn and their team have created here.

movie_review_blurb: We have seen many films about losers on the run, but in the directorial debut of former Chicago siblings Alan and Gabe Polsky, we get an intriguing new take on brotherly love not only gone wrong, but clearly hopeless from the beginning.

Remembering the greatness of Rocky and Raging Bull while watching Grudge Match only made me sad.
The bottom line: Kids may be mildly amused by The Nut Job, but adults accompanying them won't find much to capture their interest.

The visuals are spectacular, the 3D technology is artfully used and the story is jam-packed with so many funny lines, it's hard to catch all the jokes that are delivered in rapid-fire succession -- constantly tweaking many popular culture icons.

Issues like family harmony, justice, righting wrongs and telling the truth never go out of fashion and that comes across strong and clear in this less-than-perfect, but still solid, feel-good film.
My best suggestion for people who insist on going to see this immense waste of time? Go drunk.

No question about it, Lassie is a very traditional film, but good storytelling, fine acting and beautiful photography add up to a solid family entertainment that never lets us forget who the real star is.

... an intelligent and often very entertaining picture that deals with so many aspects of human relationships.

A pleasant jaunt through one of the most beautiful places on the planet -- encased in a story that ends up making you feel that all is right with the world.
This is a powerful film that combines a number of 'what if' situations with some true tragic moments and even a number of oddly funny situations.

Overall, this is an enjoyable ride, despite the occasional preaching.

Deja Vu takes you on a wonderfully twisting and turning journey that often will leave you wondering and perhaps confused -- but ultimately leaves you with a satisfying and totally logical explanation when the credits role.
A refreshingly unadorned example of straightforward storytelling.
Unaccompanied Minors may not be the worst holiday comedy ever made, but frankly I can't think of something from that genre that sinks lower than this frighteningly bad movie.

A film that veers, often without much direction, between a family-friendly comic romp and an attempt to touch our souls with heartfelt emotion.
For the most part, this movie feels like a just-missed effort.
A thriller like this needs to pack a lot of firepower on the backend. Unfortunately, all we get is a weak, much-anticipated little pop.
This is just another waste of time I'd really hate for you to undergo -- and pay for.
This is director Kevin MacDonald's first feature film, yet along with cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle, he has produced a motion picture that will become an instant political classic.

Overall I was delighted with Divergent and am eager to see how the remaining two films continue to take us on Tris' adventure, as she and Four attempt to learn what's really going on in their very crazy world.
[An] absolutely superb coming-of-age film.
It's as good as the first one and sure to please both the kiddies and adults with its two-tiered humor.

The agenda here is front and center from start to finish, and while the actors do a yeoman's job in presenting their characters with aplomb, the entire film simply comes off as a two-hour, jazzed-up movie version of a sermon.
[A] less-than-satisfying if occasionally entertaining fantasy romp that does feature some of the more talented actors on the planet.
The repetition didn't bother me. I just was hoping we'd get some new twists and more original storytelling this time around.

Take one part 3-D visual bombast, add a healthy dose of non-stop action and sprinkle in one helluva silly storyline -- plus those fast-talking, even faster-moving hard-shell siblings -- and you have the essence of [TMNT: Out of the Shadows].
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While there are some acceptable action sequences, it's the screenplay -- complicated by some less than inspired performances -- that dooms Warcraft at every point along the way.
This is not great moviemaking by any stretch of the imagination, but the spot-on comic timing of [Kendrick and Plaza] captured my funny bone and kept it happily working overtime from start to finish.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is an intelligent and understated film that nicely presents one very particular life experience that will, in its own way, inspire the viewer.
It's a beautiful thing to behold.
It's the relentless mugging, outrageous schtick and otherwise hilarious antics of this dynamic duo that make this movie a very fun romp.
This is one helluva compelling film that presents us with several of the very best performances of the year.

The great gift of this film, of course, is that Streep again completely embodies the character she is playing...but imbues Florence with such empathy, charm, dedication and warmth that we're cheering for her throughout this entire movie.
I cannot stress enough how truly stunning the brilliant visuals are in this movie.

While A Tale of Love and Darkness is often difficult to watch -- because of all the sadness it presents -- it is also a beautiful film in that it makes us think about existing in a world where we do not completely fit in.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All in all, Blair Witch was quite satisfying and made me think: This is what the first sequel to the original film should have accomplished.
The special effects are among the more positive aspects of Allegiant, but those alone cannot rescue this highly flawed sequel.

Frequently difficult to watch, White Girl is the powerful feature debut of a filmmaker with original vision and clear talent -- and a movie that proves a lead actress can possess the gift of transformative performance skills.
This is a disappointing waste of good acting talent, coupled with a very pedantic and not very intriguing story from first-time screenwriter Christina Hodson.

While I clearly cannot recommend this film, I have to admit there were a couple of amusing moments.
The filmmakers have decided to go for an old-school look in the animation here, an excellent decision.
While this charming movie will be targeted to senior audiences, I hope younger generations check it out - as the humor and underlying messages are truly universal.
While the plot is a bit shaky in parts, the overall effect of creating needed tension and some outright, out-of-your-seat jumps of fright is quite effective.
Not every remake is unnecessary, but the idea only works when the new movie takes the basic premise and takes it in new directions.
While this likely will appeal strongly to LGBTQ audiences, I hope it finds a wider viewing, as the acting and the dialogue make for excellent drama.
A film with a lovely, life-affirming, uplifting message - unfortunately delivered in such a heavy-handed, gooey-sweet manner that audiences will exit the theater in a near-diabetic coma.
movie_title: Same Kind of Different As Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As the film unfolds, things increasingly become further and further unbelievable, and lead to moments of would-be horror that instead made me laugh out loud, thanks to the incredulity of the situation at hand.
Just Getting Started simply never does get started. It's D.O.A.
Most important, "Ferdinand's" anti-bullying message is an important lesson kids of all ages need to see - again, and again.

In the end, the filmmakers have given us one of the most fun movie-going experiences I've had this year. Huge kudos go to Johnson, Hart and especially Black for providing some truly entertaining performances.
A solid and mostly successful attempt to introduce this important labor leader and civil rights activist to younger audiences, while reminding older folks of the impact Chavez had on this country.
"Inferno" is a grabber, and Hanks knows Langdon so well, he wears that character like a somewhat worn yet still well-constructed suit of clothes.
I constantly had the sense I was witnessing a formulaic Hallmark Channel-type approach that really did not elevate this genre in any new ways.
[The] emotional impact of this important documentary will add to the understanding of the divisions we all face in this diverse nation, especially at this time of great division.
From the very opening scene in The Witch, we are immediately thrown into an ominous journey that conveys pending doom.

Unpredictability in cinema is frequently a missing element -- especially when we're talking about movies that fall into the horror or science-fiction genres. With 10 Cloverfield Lane, there is no such problem. Trust me.
Some of these plot twists require more than the normal suspension of logic that often happens in similar comedies. Yet the characters are all appealing.

Though I enjoyed enormously this latest offering in the rebooted Jump franchise, it's the effortless, unexpected bromance/partnership between the two unlikely undercover cops is what makes this franchise work.
Not only does this second movie match the charm, wit, animation skill and intelligent storytelling of the original, I think it even exceeds it.
Though Haggis has crafted an ambitious tale, it is way too complicated and convoluted.

Planes: Fire & Rescue is a good improvement over Planes, which Disney released last year. The story is stronger, there are some wonderful additions to the voice talent and the 3D cinematography is well-utilized.
This is a beautifully crafted story that takes us on quite the journey of exploration and discovery.
The visual pop simply becomes annoying as it truly gets in the way of the storytelling.
Kinnear does an excellent job of capturing Burpo's obvious dilemma and the turmoil he and his wife endure as they work through this critical time in the life of their family.
Mirren's Madame Mallory unctuously oozes her dedication to perfection from every pore -- and it's truly delicious to watch her work her magic up on the screen.

In many ways, What If takes us down a road that When Harry Met Sally first traveled a quarter-century ago. Yet I didn't really mind revisiting the old friend vs. lover discussion, especially one with a contemporary slant and solid dialogue.
A well-acted and intelligent thriller/futuristic sci-fi romp.
This is a pretty lame computer-generated animated movie that will likely not engage kids much past the first grade.
We've seen this story told in similar fashion so many times in the past. I only wish we could have had it delivered in a fresher, less cliché-filled package.
This may be one of the least artful holiday films ever made. Even devout born-again Christians will find this hard to stomach.
This film is a winner. It will not only entertain you, but also make you think about what it takes to bring happiness into your own life.

movie_review_blurb: I can't say enough about the power of Spall's performance.

This is a good film that will be enjoyed both by pre-teen children and the parents who likely will join them at the multiplexes around the country.

This is a well-meaning film with a good idea that unfortunately stumbles on its way to its less-than-satisfying end.
This small film (virtually all of it filmed in Tobi's New York apartment) is a real gem.

This film moves effortlessly from some pretty intense dramatic moments to hilarious scenes showcasing the contrasting lifestyles of the gay and straight worlds to some vignettes of incredible poignancy.

movie_review_blurb: Like The Devil Wears Prada, this film's kicks come from watching the foibles and quirks of the uber-rich through an outsider's eyes, but the genuine sadness on display in the Nanny Diaries saves this film from being just a Prada knock-off.

A harmless but fun hot-weather diversion for the family.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In this taut drama about the trial of a Bosnian Serb general from German director and co-writer Hans Christian Schmid, we see how justice can be subverted by interests as banal as international bureaucracy, despite the best intentions...
This computer-animated adaptation of the 1950s-created future boy from Osamu Tezuka, the godfather of Japanese manga, is actually a sweet and endearing movie.
While kids older than 8 may be too jaded to sit through this cute flick, at just over an hour, it may be the perfect fit for first-time filmgoers.
While the shocks are original, gory and well mounted, by the end, you realise this director Breck Eisner ain't got what it takes to pull the trigger.

At times it just seems like people you know hamming it up for the camera.

Bumps along wide-eyed, like a queer Stand By Me from down under, blue-ing up its spacey nighttimes and redding out its heated days with lush cinematography.

movie_review_blurb: Promising turns from Booth and Chittenden aren't enough to save a slight and sloppy Aussie soap from a poor script, messy direction and Blethyn's overbearing performance.

movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Brisk, brassy and keenly observed, Neame's film is a thoroughly enjoyable social satire that will appeal to the blagger in everyone.
Overly gimmicky and ultimately frustrating it may be, but at its best The Nines feels like a triple-bill of 'Twilight Zone' episodes written by Charlie Kaufman - creepy, oddball and clever.
A giant of a movie that is sometimes lumbering, but ever watchable thanks to its uninhibited ambition, size and glamour.
A romantic heart, caustic wit, and the energy of its fresh cast ensure the film's continued appeal.
When you get that Sandler's comedic persona is meant to be annoying, like Beavis and Butthead or Cartman, the laughs come thick and fast.
This is an easy, madcap, guilty pleasure that plays like a hyperactive cross between Wacky Races and The Dukes of Hazard.
Loud, silly and choc-a-block with madcap slapstick, Hiller's film may have an alarming plot premise but it's innocent enough for all but the youngest kids to enjoy.
This utterly enchanting, family treat of a film should leave you and yours wide-eyed with wonder.
If Aunty Beeb could stick to productions of this quality, she wouldn't be in such a mess. Earth's script may grate with anyone over 12, but you can't help but be impressed by what you see.

With summer movies safely tucked away, it's the time of year where Oscar films pop up, and this week's Puncture may be a contender.

FEMA can take a day off because Footloose is one remake that won't be called a natural disaster, in fact, it's one hell of a good film.
Captain America: The First Avenger is definitely the best superhero film of the year and it's one hell of a fun ride. This is a must see!
A Place at the Table makes a strong case that hunger for one is a problem for all.
Father of Invention is not without its comic moments. Unfortunately, they take place during the end credits.
Much like the kids in this movie who come of age, so too does Robert Kirbyson's skill as a writer-director in his debut film Snowmen.
Finally, there's a cat even cooler than Garfield who will win the box office as well as a place on your favorites list. His name is Puss and he wears boots.
Looks aren't everything, but you'd never guess that by watching Immortals. With a solid cast and breathtaking fight scenes, you almost forget that there's not much of a story.

American Reunion is of the funniest movies of the year. The filmmakers and cast captured what made the original so great while making you forget the spinoffs. Fans of the original won't be disappointed.

Headhunters is an intriguing action thriller that relies on both stunts and the acts of its diverse mains characters, played by well-cast main actors Aksel Hennie and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, in order to tell its story.
The Other Son is one of the best dramas of the year, foreign or otherwise, making a case that the strongest faith may be far away from pulpits and closer to home.
Dr. Seuss' The Lorax is an entertaining and cautionary tale that stays true to the spirit of the good doctor.
Intruders is a thriller hybrid that goes a long way and it is definitely worth the watch.
Red Lights has a decent premise, but the script lets the actors down. While it has interesting twists and bucks convention, the story is just far too weak to be enjoyable.
Easy Money is a good mob drama with drugs, girls and enough moral conflict to fool you into thinking that these events could happen to anyone.
A well-thought-out film.
Unfortunately for Casa de Mi Padre there's a very fine line between smart-stupid and slapdash-stupid.
Excellent performances by Freddie Highmore and Emma Roberts make this one an enjoyable watch.
Don't spend thirteen bucks on Trespass unless you're running from the cops and you need a place to hide, wait for it to hit VOD.
Kung Fu Panda 2 benefits from an entertaining story, fantastic direction and amazing visuals. It's one of 2011's best animated films.
Good performances by Ferrell and Wallace and fantastic cinematography make Everything Must Go an enjoyable watch.
Nothing about the film is all that titillating or revealing after years of True Hollywood stories, TMZ and weekly Kardashian adventures.

With all due respect to the dozen or so guys sharing the latest Expendables marquee, Liam Neeson is the poster child for AARP badasses.

movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Just as the Bible speaks in many ways to many people, so does Darren Aronofsky's epic Noah.

perplexing and laughable

The Gunman is among the surliest of its kind, an elder actioner of unrelenting violence and preachy geopolitical ardor. Sean Penn looks tired, and this movie grows more and more tiresome with every kill.
Pitch Perfect 2 is a summer sequel built on a foundation of bubble gum and big heart. This is a film that can be admired for its humility, humanity, and harmony.

The Cobbler's so bad that Adam Sandler may do some serious soul-searching (after his next $20 million paycheck). It's so bad that you'll be willing to actually call Comcast and ask for your money back.
There was a point where I was considering writing a will because this film made me want to leave this Earth.
I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story, for the most part, is a puff piece. A feather film, if you will. It's as nice and flavorful and yellow as a Nilla cookie.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Paper Towns romanticizes a lost-and-found teenage daydream that comes across as a little insincere and more than a bit tone deaf.
In spite of an extremely slim outline, Félix et Meira's essence and specificity make for something superior.
'71 isn't trying to impress anyone with its action violence, and that's an incredible quality.
Wasn't Hitman just a post-Matrix drip anyways? Like, are teenagers still enraptured by jet-black attire, cyber-punk imagery, and slow-mo gunplay?
Phoenix is a death-defying melodrama of rare emotional obsession. It carefully pushes its conceit to the very limits, practically begging for the truth, or better yet, reconciliation.
Ricki and the Flash is an irresistible family jam. This is the kind of movie your mom will sing during, and you won't mind, because you're having such a rocking good time yourself.
When does life ever make sense? Roy Andersson seems certain that life doesn't, and he's made the loveliest, loopiest statement to that effect.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I Am Chris Farley is a kind eulogy, a colorful parade of stars remembering the legacy of a famed funnyman. As a remembrance, I Am Chris Farley's heart, care, and, well, cuteness is undeniable.
While the hard-to-navigate hell that is a courtroom is familiar genre territory, few works of legal fiction feel this deliciously droll. Court's cynical, but absolutely never sorry.

From the bongo-heavy heist music, to the deft sight gags, to little details like the scratches Scott Lang leaves while he's tiny, there's no shortage of great stuff to see and enjoy - no magnifying glass required.

The film seems more interested in trying to get the skinny on Superman, rather than making a grand statement about the industry. What we get is a somewhat sloppy labor of love from a fan. Nothing more, nothing less.
movie_title: The Death of Superman Lives: What Happened? (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This X-Men is fun, like Bryan Singer's previous effort, the 2003 X2: X-Men United -- light on its feet, light on story.
Watching Minions is like watching a spastic colon spew little yellow turds at you. It's less a movie than a brand strategy meeting, all the way through.
Magic Mike XXL might be Channing Tatum's greatest show of muscle yet.
Max tries to sell family-friendly Alpo, but feels like we're being fed a handful of undercooked scraps under the table.
Inside Out is a superlative work of inspired imagination, one that may very well stay in your mind for a very long time.
A calm, naturalistic experience, Madame Bovary is refreshingly analog.

Testament of Youth is equal parts love and languor, blood and British history. And yet, one can't shake the all too aristocratic, snooty, and self-serious theatrics of something that comes off like a prep school's fall play.
Spy just gets so much right. You walk away thinking that Susan Cooper could totally put James Bond, Jason Bourne, and Ethan Hunt in a headlock. At the same time, of course.
Andrew Niccol has a knack for contemplating digital media ethics, and it shows in his often plain-spoken rhetoric in Good Kill.
Serena is inconsequential, stilted, and likely being shoved out right now on streaming services due to Cooper and Lawrence starring in the two highest domestic grossing films of 2014.
Like the man himself, John Wick does whatever it wants and gets the job done.
Gay panic humor, jokes about German liberation, random business dicks, and the most un-earned sentimental ending imaginable lead to a film that just doesn't work out.
Stretch thinks it's so damn clever, and is totally self-satisfied with its over-written dialogue.
The Book of Life is a Hispanic rococo feast and possibly even a positive cultural gateway for younger kids. It's great to look at, less to listen to.
Whiplash works incredibly well as a kind of psychological, academic scare, and it plays its way to a gigantic, emotionally powerful close.
Fury isn't like many war films, but it speaks volumes.
A rollicking short horror film anthology that feels like a festival. Sometimes it's gruesomely goofy, even great. At other points this alphabet's grotesque, or just plain gauche.
Nightcrawler feels like it's been building in Dan Gilroy for years. The director and his star have something interesting and even exciting on their hands. It's pretty can't miss stuff.
Big Hero 6 is just another loud action flick for the kids.
Something unoriginal isn't always pointless.
Wild is Reese Witherspoon's finest accomplishment as an actress.
Both joyous and melancholy, Isao Takahota's The Tale of Princess Kaguya is an exquisitely drawn fable.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Julianne Moore does all the heavy lifting in what otherwise feels like a TV movie.
Top Five is an arty and sincere hangout with an incredible cast of characters.
Mr. Turner isn't just pretty; it's museum-ready masterpiece gorgeous.
American Sniper makes for an engaging but frustrating debate about war.
At its best, The Interview is a deft work of satire.
Selma is a passionate and utterly important historical recounting, unimpeachable for its modern relevancy, and moving in its cinematic telling.

Turbo Kid captures the wildly discordant dreams of any budding movie lover when they were 10, creating one of the funniest works of sandbox cinema made to date. Turbo Kid is here to play, and he's loads of fun.
Alexander is funnier than one would expect. In a weird way, it's full of refreshingly cranky, dorky goofing.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Sam Taylor-Johnson, buy a ticket: The Duke of Burgundy shows us how you tackle BDSM.
The Judge will say and do anything to win over the jury of public opinion, but look at the facts, and you'll see nothing but pandering.
Take Me to the River is a good-spirited but patchy documentary, less about dropping beats and more about dropping names.
Everly seems to wanna be a badass, but winds up a dumb ass.
It doesn't have anything interesting to say, but it shows some neat stuff about movie making. My Life Directed by Nicolas Winding Refn's only real problem is its subject.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If we're to look at Focus for the qualities of its con, it'll earn your wallet, and you'll be totally okay with that.
When McFarland, USA does the sports thing, it's just doing laps. But as an intro-level family film about Mexican-American relations, it's reasonably entertaining.
Try to imagine an episode of Girls, scrubbed of honesty and told in song through a punch-drunk lens.
Timbuktu is a transfixing meditation on faith, occupation, and man's fallacies in the face of God. Abderrahmane Sissako presents an unnerving situation and elevates it into a fascinating microcosm.
Sam Taylor-Johnson's Fifty Shades of Grey is total trash. Noble trash. The amusing kind of trash, actually.
A slap shot snapshot that goes deep, peeling back the Iron Curtain for fast, fascinating, and even funny insight into the collective nature of athleticism...
Jupiter Ascending comes from a wholehearted and yet misguided place of affection.
Part '70s crime caper, part character comedy, part hit-punch actioner, Wild Card plays the hands it's dealt with an amusing and acceptable lack of ambition.
The Loft is a tawdry, twisty little whodunit, populated by unpleasant people doing even more unpleasant things.
Black or White is a toxic misstep for racial discourse. It boils a serious, knotty story down into a series of running gags, awkward moments, and grandstanding courtroom dialogues.
Mortdecai isn't all that funny, quick-witted, or even that interesting. It's yet another misunderstood outsider, fish-out-of-water, unreal, and oblivious hero scenario for Johnny Depp.
Spare Parts is a serviceable, curious, and ultimately bland true story adaptation.
When we see the consequences of a broken window, a long-harbored resentment, or a mild criticism, Winter Sleep engages with a captivating pathos.
Da Sweet Blood of Jesus is often a very mysterious, funny, and unnerving film. At other times, it feels like the best Lee could do with limited resources and a flurry of content.
Paddington is a good kind of sweet, a slightly unusual sweet.
Predestination has so little confidence in its conceit that what we're left with feels like belligerent exposition.
Where's the mania? Where's the tension? Where's the goddamn "holy crap!" moment in The Perfect Guy? Sadly, there's nothing like that in this flawed and limited PG-13 film.
This movie is action, horror, and comedy by way of Hogwarts, and it's frightfully fun. Occasionally scary, and even scarier for how often the film works.

Nancy Meyers, the maven of the upper middle-age romcom, has now cruised ever so casually into senior-itis with The Intern. It's a typical Meyers joint: breezy farce with touches of honey and commerciality.
At its worst, the new film is visually overcooked, lacking the focus, pop, and emotional brevity of its inspiration.
Verbinski's latest film is rich with invention, intrigue, and a mind-melting liveliness that's impossible to ignore.

Raoul Peck's I Am Not Your Negro is a superb invocation, a necessary new reading of a grand voice. It's a subtly drawn and impactful summation of James Baldwin's literary essence and social conscience, confidently packaged as a 90-minute essay...
You know what sucks the most about Gold? Greatness is within its grasp, but in spite of its efforts, talent, and resources, the film just doesn't dig deep enough.
At its best, there's a frenetic authenticity to the plotting. But at other times it reads like schlock, recalling the pulp realism of Dirty Harry and Black Sunday.
It's a cross-cultural sermon-turned-forum. It's a religious drama with graceful, dramatic élan. And above all, Silence is pure, as cinema and in its reflection.
Sure, this is still a children's film, but one with clarity in its intentions.
Espinosa manages to deliver his concept at a clip, with some assured cinematography, smooth VFX design, and solid performances from his doomed crew.

Allied is one of those films that has a little something for everyone, all the euphemisms fit to print on a 1940s movie poster. But the film's certainly never too stuffy, and never too showy. It's just damn fine entertainment.
Madea has returned, and she's as bad as ever. Bad in temperament. Bad and barely better than the film surrounding her.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Its sepia-tinted bones are weathered, but spit-shined real nice, sporting an all-star cast and a gold mine of studio production value.
So this is what a $100 million B-movie looks like.

If you're looking for a grand metaphor for Nine Lives, it comes early on. During a chat about charity, Brand the sourpuss hisses into his phone, "I really don't care." No kitten. It takes on a deeper meaning within Nine Lives.

Lowery's new take on Pete's Dragon embraces a certain kind of vintage, willing and able to believe in far-fetched magic. No video cameras, no VCRs, no Snapchat. It's just a tall tale about a boy and his best friend, a fuzzy green dragon.

Gleason is very much an inspirational and difficult true sports tale. But there's something skeptically melodramatic about the doc at times; it's a strange negotiation of the nature of what's "genuine" in a documentary.
Paul Feig's Ghostbusters is sturdy summer entertainment, at once a freaky comedy and an unexpectedly effective action film.
Hughes has seen his fair share of dramatizations on film, but Beatty delivers a fresh, idiosyncratic take, about the figure and the people in his orbit of oddity.
There's an empathetic streak in Sandy Wexler. And that's something we haven't seen from Sandler in a long time.
It feels like an eternity of shtick, a ceaseless rattle of cartoon imagery protracted to the point of boredom and exhaustion.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Loach and Johns have made a call for change and understanding that is empathetic, conscientious, and magnificently moving.

It's Everest. It should be scarier than the film's digitized blue skies and gobs of snow makeup on actors, as they sob into microphones that they've made huge mistakes. These dudes do it just because they can. And as always, pride comes before the fall.
The 15:17 to Paris is too unfocused, too hard to take seriously, and too short to really get invested in it. It's an Eastwood misfire.
The message is there: be kind unto others, and they'll be kind unto you - and a dollop of marmalade doesn't hurt either.
It transforms and sturdies itself into a nice bit of remembrance for one last outburst of creativity in the life of a great artist.
movie_title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg's all about news travelling fast, and to see him direct so jazzily is an unexpected treat. It's the right idea, even if the result doesn't quite feel so.
It's a testament to Carrey's still-polarizing stardom that this film gains its manic mileage.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Branagh doesn't seem to want to be the defining take on Christie's procedural genius. He just seeks an amusing and playful one, and it works.
Navigating the nexus of hype, commerce, ego, and bullshit that drives the modern art scene, The Square is almost too perfect in its cunning simplicity.
When a film's reputation behind the scenes is more interesting than the finished result, that's not a great sign.
It's insulting. Unfunny. Blunt. It'll leave a hell of a bitter taste in the mouths of general audiences and horror nuts alike.
Even when the proceedings feel a little cursory, or incomplete, this is still a lovingly painted big picture.
While the messages feel simple - no one should experience this, power corrupts absolutely, and so on - Jolie has developed an effective work of empathy.
This is a B-movie through and through, with a taste for whoop-ass. Is the action good? Well, in the beginning, at least.
When there's no more room left in multiplexes, the low-budget comedies will walk the Netflix. Barely marketed. Primed for low exposure in the dog days of summer.
Here's a classical-yet-modernist action film that will be taken apart and put on display in film schools and film clubs for years to come.
After all, what are these films if not reasonable diversions? They're also thunderously profitable diversions, but at least they're harmless.
The film's tone registers somewhere between Steven Soderbergh's The Informant! and Alexander Payne's droll sensibilities.
Warcraft is so aggressive in its accumulation of content and scale that any narrative arc, or emotional output, beneath the shimmer is hard to find.
Popstar makes a feature-length film out of what could have been a 45-minute Comedy Central special, or roughly 28 hit-or-miss SNL short films
Queen of Katwe shows that a film doesn't have to give up on the tenets of genre, but has the potential to win big if it can enliven them in new ways.
Ira Sachs' sensitively drawn Little Men occupies a rarified space of total emotional truth

The Big Short is like seeing the best of Oliver Stone return in crude, unrestrained form, reborn as a mad jester. The yells so hard that it throws out its back trying to grab your attention, but it's equally important, informative, and brazenly funny.
This is the kind of quiet film that turns out to be a surprise in so many delightful, expectation-subverting ways.
In QVC terms: Joy looks neat, sounds too good to be true, and often is.
Solemnity is key, and Chi-Raq braves the waters, but the film's stroke of genius is its ludicrous bent. The film swivels, and challenges us to not sit complacently. Get mad. Seriously.
This holiday season, give yourself the gift of time, and money, by skipping The Night Before.
The 33 is a stable studio job about a recent headline, one that sympathetically gets away from its legacy and focuses on the human element.

At one point, Byrne talks to the event's announcer, almost sheepishly, and says, "It's kinda working... It's working!" That pause, that hesitation, is everything you need to know about Contemporary Color.

If Our Brand Is Crisis were a person, it'd be a grinning politician, an empty-promise glad-hander with a nifty slogan. Or worse, it's the person who had a bad experience at a bar or family outing discussing politics...
Jem and the Holograms seems pleased enough with itself, to the point that audiences may be amused by it as well.
Say hello to Malala Yousafzai, up close, out of depth, and ultimately, only at a glance.
Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow's De Palma is a cineaste's dream. Better yet, it's like getting a minor in film studies, with De Palma as the the candid, mensch-y professor.
The Forbidden Room may be deemed too avant-garde or piecemeal for some, but there's no denying the invention on display.

Watching a man yearn for a woman isn't the defining characteristic of the film; it's the many intersections and little differences at play that will find Right Now, Wrong Then a place in narrative studies courses.
Steve Jobs doesn't reach the zeitgeisty highs of Sorkin's other tech-minded film, but goodness is everyone on board and running smoothly.
In its unexpected way, Bridge of Spies is quite the patient and special piece of work.
Mississippi Grind is a filmed series of lies, bad choices, and shaky attempts to get paid, all told through the texture, the soundtrack choices, and interesting casting.
The Walk is a flashy film that repeatedly justifies its existence, and even the inevitable 3D ticket prices.
Fey and Poehler are just looking for a good time, and it's duly appreciated. The only poison they put in themselves is a few too many shots, but if Sisters is any indicator, they're happy to share.
This is a movie that meets the minimum running time to be considered a feature film and has no grander ambition than to serve as a sneaky alternative for families when Star Wars is sold out.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Taxi is must-see, feel-good cinéma vérité of the narrative variety.
Mazer's film works half the time, but De Niro works it so hard he probably needed ointment on set.
13 Hours is just chaos. It's unwatchable, unlikable, and unworthy of respect.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It should come as no surprise that The Angry Birds Movie is a loud and dumb children's film, but for what it's worth, there are plenty of cinematic commercial ventures that are louder and dumber and so on than the well-meaning and slickly sold Birds.
By taking what's ostensibly a hazy love-in, and deconstructing it into a song of sadness and forced frolicking, Guadagnino has devised a bewitching masquerade. And the water's so inviting.
Rio, I Love You is totally the brainchild of a tourism board.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fireworks Wednesday could work just as well as a chamber play as a film, but Farhadi uses the medium to careful, cunning effects.
Barbershop: The Next Cut is less a franchise close-out, and more a movie that sits a cut above its predecessors, admirable for its tenacity
Melissa McCarthy works overtime to keep an uneven comedy humming.
Allegiant will work for completists who buy it in one of those "Four Film Favorites" deals at Target in a few years, with lowered expectations.
Another Evil may be a cheap thrill, but it has a unique take on the haunted house genre. Here's a curious horror comedy that gets richer with every unexpected minute.
Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is part rom-com, part memoir, and part apolitical social statement. Imagine a special crossover episode between 30 Rock and M*A*S*H.
Grimsby's got ball-sucking jokes, pube-flashing jokes, ribald jokes about super-sized semen and anal cavities. Jokes that would conceivably kill John Cleese. Maybe even John Waters, for that matter.
Fifty Shades of Black aims low (often at and around the crotch), and often fumbles around, missing its G-spot. That's the gag-spot, perverts.
A more fitting title might have been Jane Got a Gun, But Didn't Get to Do a Whole Heck of a Lot With it in the End.
Mountains May Depart is a patient, sedate film, but the emotional dividends leave a mark.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Simply, here's a Disney "True Story" event film that doesn't feel all that cheap, emotionally or in terms of presentation. The Finest Hours embraces both new and old.
But Race is best appreciated as an allegorical shake-up with the focus on Jesse's big moments and competitions. And they feel quite big.
Within Eddie the Eagle's core is a conventional, but acceptable message: Tis a far better thing to compete than it is to solely win.
Stiller's big failure is simple: he tries to recycle every last meme from the first film. Fashion-wise, it's like watching someone put a million buttons on a once-reliable, semi-familiar outfit.
Sound of Noise is outside the box, original and inventive. It's also hilarious, and extremely entertaining. The film is one of SFIFF's highlights.
If you choose to see TRON: Legacy, leave your brain at home, and be ready to watch what boils down to a great dramatic Daft Punk music video.
Rabbit Hole is a beautiful examination of relationships. It exceeds normal genre expectations and has some fantastic acting.
Unflinchingly honest and confidently challenging, this is an all around incredible film.
Devil features nothing new, exciting or suspenseful. Instead, it gives us shallowly developed characters and an ultimately forgettable story.
Strikingly beautiful effects and atmosphere mixed with some really great direction make for a very well done film.
Tabloid is totally fascinating. It features brilliant editing and pacing along with well thought out concepts that are expertly executed. A must see!
Terri is a very funny film with strong performances and equally strong direction.
Titillating, thought-provoking, confidently made, involving and well-written and paced all accurately describe this wonderful film.
movie_title: I'm Glad My Mother Is Alive (2011)

movie_review_blurb: End of Animal is a stunning film that should not be missed.
The film fails to reach its lofty ambitions and is really not much beyond ordinary movie orthodoxies.
A timely original take on capitalism and an impressively comprehensive history of venture capitalism.
Confident, strong directing makes for a fascinating, moving and touching film.

Black Bread is one of SFIFF's more understated films, despite a few fairly grotesque moments. It has some interesting camerawork, solid performances and an intriguing story, all of which make this one worth a watch.
Truly throught-provoking with a very original story and concept makes for a film that is a lot of fun and a great watch!
Moving and poetic, with beautiful composition and strong direction, Nostalgia For The Light has an authentic sense of gravitas.
Howl is invigoratingly fresh. It has compelling filmmaking, a great script and tremendous acting from all involved.
The Whistleblower offers fantastic performances from the entire cast. It's very atmospheric with grisly authenticity and a truly moving plot.
Enter The Void is authentically meditative and beautifully shot, making it an unforgettable film.
Bellflower is an all around great movie that benefits from excellent filmmaking and gorgeous cinematography.
Emotionally stunted at times, Never Let Me Go gets lost in its own melancholy and fails to live up to its potential.
Plenty of authentic laughs and great supporting performances make Welcome to the Rileys a decent film.

Resident Evil: Afterlife recycles nearly every horror convention. The plot is not original and the 3D is quite bad. And since we've literally seen all this before, it's only occasionally entertaining, and rarely interesting.
Even those who have found Herzog's work lacking in the past will have a hard time writing off Cave of Forgotten Dreams. It's a superb film.
Superb writing, a quickly moving plot and outstanding lead performances make this one a winner.
There are really no artistic merits to be found here. The film glorifies violence and is overly offensive in every way possible.
The Ledge has a couple very strong performances and it explores some interesting issues. There are some satisfying thrills to be had here and overall, it's not a bad watch.
Jess + Moss is a simply beautiful film with amazing sound work and nearly flawless direction.
Kaboom plays out like a a ridiculously campy, and poorly written comic book. It's not very coherent and has a terrible ending.
Tight editing and pace make for a careful and thoughtful film that is a very strong piece of cinema.
Durkin's direction is strong and assured and due to it, we get a fresh and exciting film that serves as a nice debut for Elizabeth Olsen.
Thanks to the strong directing we get a handful of really fantastic scenes and a number of thrills, which make this a wholly enjoyable film.

Easy A transcends the mold of teenage cautionary tales while still providing some serious laughs and genuine moments. It has a wildly fresh script that keeps you laughing throughout and Emma Stone is great in the lead role.
Lebanon is an absolutely stunning piece of work. Both incredibly powerful and completely captivating, it's one of the best films I've ever seen.
Outstanding cinematography and score and excellent acting make for a remarkable movie. The American is a must-see.
Authentic tension and characters make for a refreshingly humanistic take on spies and espionage.
Meek's Cutoff is a thoughtful, and intimate narrative that is beautifully shot and has outstanding direction.
Refreshingly optimistic without idealization, Jack Goes Boating gives us a fantastic cast and manages to be charming and witty without sacrificing integrity.
ELYSIUM doesn't have the striking originality and defiance of DISTRICT 9 but its prescient social commentary fused with spectacular sci-fi action makes for essential viewing.
Edgar Wright's finale to the Cornetto Trilogy's The World's End is finally upon us and it's a suitably poetic and conclusive last call for Simon Pegg and Nick Frost's 'man-child' dynamic duo.
Now You See Me puts the fun back in being fooled.
Behind the Candelabra is a fascinating peek into the secret life of an icon; the sad (reportedly) last hurrah of a cinematic maverick and proof that Douglas and Damon are fabulous.

Moving away from the iconically U.S landscape and toward the brutal, loneliness of the character shreds away the stain of Wolverine Origins & The Last Stand and gives our favourite adamantium skeleton-ed mutant the film that he and we deserve.
The Conjuring is like the horror equivalent of a 'Long Island iced tea'; mixing stiff belts of haunted house, poltergeist and exorcism into a near perfect and potent cocktail.

The Broken Circle Breakdown is the cinematic equivalent of a great album that gets played at a funeral. Ultimately it's a celebration; but the heartbreaking melancholy of love and life lost bleeds out of every note.

To the Wonder feels like a caricature coveting Malick's previously towering pieces of visual art. However there's more refined, contemplative poetry in this relative misstep than in a hundred Hollywood studio films.
Stories We Tell is cinema cutting to the profound truth of why we use narrative to make sense of the world.

The Heat runs really hot in fiery bursts of filthy and physical female comedy; but trying to even pay lip service to this husk of a story for its two hour running time really makes for a polarising view.
Only God Forgives stays with you like a traumatic memory but the sickening violence appears composed as haunting flashes of sublime beauty; reverberating long after you've finished viewing.
Upstream Color's mystery paralysed me.
PACIFIC RIM speaks the disaster language of the original Godzilla, yearns to be in the same league as Star Wars; but unfortunately its style over substance ethos delivers Transformers results.
We're the Millers is way funnier and entertaining than it should be.
The Canyons is Easton Ellis cannibalising himself, Schrader badly forging Drive and hack stunt casting of a walking appendage and a starlet that should have been in rehab.

THE BEST OFFER is a cinematic palimpsest in the vein of Hitchcock's VERTIGO. Perfectly crafted performances, inescapable choral echoes of Morricone's wondrous score, the perfect forgery awaits, and begs to be revisited again and again.
Rush will find your inner petrol head as you're faced with the reality that there's a knife's edge between death and glory.
